Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives;

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, IS October, 1949.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr J. 3. Clark)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: INCOME TAX.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Complaint s have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made to me by many men that on the

Speaker: NA
Text: death of their parents they have arranged

Speaker: NA
Text: for an elderly sister to look after their

Speaker: NA
Text: home, and that they have not been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to claim a concessional rebate for income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax purposes in respect of the services of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sister, but that taxpayers are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: claim such concessions in respect of de

Speaker: NA
Text: facto wives. "Will the Treasurer state

Speaker: NA
Text: whether consideration has been given to

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter, and i f so, whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for further consideration to be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the desirability of allowing con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessional rebates to taxpayers in such

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances 3

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Th e Bubjeet raised

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member has been con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered by a number of Treasurers and

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. I do not think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: position of a de facto wife is analogous

Speaker: NA
Text: to that of a sister who is looking after a

Speaker: NA
Text: single man. A de facto wife occupies a

Speaker: NA
Text: somowhat different position in the home

Speaker: NA
Text: from that of a sister. The conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: governing thc allowance of concessional

Speaker: NA
Text: rates in respeot of de facto wives are

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly strict, and have regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: character of the union and to children

Speaker: NA
Text: that might result from it. This subject

Speaker: NA
Text: has been considered on a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions because of the continual re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quests that have heen made that the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessional rebate should be extended to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover taxpayers such as those mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member. Up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: present the Government has not been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to see its way clear to allow a rebate in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of sisters who occupy such a posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion hi the home because such a practice

Speaker: NA
Text: would be open to very great "aBuses,

Speaker: NA
Text: CUSTOMS SEIZURE OF

Speaker: NA
Text: GBAMOPHONE RECORDS.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Som e time ago 1

Speaker: NA
Text: askod the Attorney-General a question

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the impounding of some

Speaker: NA
Text: gramophono records which had been

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to Australia by Mr Dixon, the

Speaker: NA
Text: well-known Communist. I asked the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorahle gentleman whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: would have the records examined in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to ascertain whether or not they contained

Speaker: NA
Text: certain forms of propaganda. Has he

Speaker: NA
Text: yet had an opportunity to institute an

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry to ascertain the nature pf the

Speaker: NA
Text: records, and, i f so, can he give the House

Speaker: NA
Text: any information on the subject?

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned this matter on the 30th

Speaker: NA
Text: September last. I t relates to the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration by the Department of Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs of the Customs Act. I

Speaker: NA
Text: referred the honorable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: question to the Minister for Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and Customs but I have not yet re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived a reply. A reply will be furnished

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honorable member by the Mimster

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs in this House. Power is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in the Customs Act for the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to detain certain types of records.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have already informed the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member, I do not know what is contained

Speaker: NA
Text: on the records to which he has drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: attention. However, I am obliged to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for reminding me of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: HIGH COURT.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Ha s the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General seen a statement attributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Warringah, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honorable member is reported

Speaker: NA
Text: to have stated that, i f Labour is returned

Speaker: NA
Text: to office, the people might expect the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court to be stacked with Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: supporters? Does the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: not consider that statement to be

Speaker: NA
Text: inaccurate, misleading and utterly false?

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the right honorable gentleman out-

Speaker: NA
Text: line to the House the appointments that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made to the High Court since

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour assumed office in 1941, and state

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: already had ample opportunity-

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I rise to order. I

Speaker: NA
Text: submit, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member is not asking a question

Speaker: NA
Text: but is inviting the Attorney-General to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a statement on a matter of general

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. I n so doing, I contend that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member is out of order.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Chair's impression is that the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Martin is asking the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General what appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made to the High Court during

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain period. He is entitled to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: that question.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Finally , I ask tht.

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General whether it is true that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has already had an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to stack the High Court had it

Speaker: NA
Text: wished to do so, but so far from doing so,

Speaker: NA
Text: it has actually appointed only one justice

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1941.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: M y attention was

Speaker: NA
Text: directed last night toa statement made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Warringah,

Speaker: NA
Text: and, I think, repeated at the week-end

Speaker: NA
Text: by another Opposition member, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Australian Country party.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take this opportunity to say' that the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement is completely inaccurate. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: a complete untruth from beginning to end.

Speaker: NA
Text: The matter has never been considered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government, and such a thought

Speaker: NA
Text: has never occurred to members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. There has been only

Speaker: NA
Text: one vacancy on the High Court bench

Speaker: NA
Text: during the regime of the Curtin and

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley Administrations. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's appointee to that vacancy was tho

Speaker: NA
Text: then Chief Justice of Queensland, Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: William Webb, and not the slightest

Speaker: NA
Text: objection to his appointment was raised

Speaker: NA
Text: by any member of this House, or any

Speaker: NA
Text: political party, or any representative of

Speaker: NA
Text: the legal profession of Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: same may be said without exception of

Speaker: NA
Text: other judicial appointments made by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. There has not been one

Speaker: NA
Text: -breath of criticism of such appointments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I say that i t is wrong and

Speaker: NA
Text: wicked that statements such as that re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to by the honorable member foT

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin should be made, without authority,

Speaker: NA
Text: in an attempt to mislead the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, there is no justification for the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Wh y not hold a

Speaker: NA
Text: referendum on banking?

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Richmond now talks about a referen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dum. I pointed out yesterday in answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to another honorable member that, during

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole period of the war, a vast per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of the High Court's decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: favoured the Government. The question

Speaker: NA
Text: of additions to the High Court Bench is

Speaker: NA
Text: not being considered, and, to use the words

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member for Martin, the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement to which he has referred is

Speaker: NA
Text: inaccurate, misleading and utterly false,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I prefer to call it a simple, downright

Speaker: NA
Text: untruth.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Tim e will tell.

Speaker: NA
Text: CANBERRA.

Speaker: NA
Text: LOCAL GOVERNMENT.

Speaker: Mr BLAIN
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Interior whether he has read the

Speaker: NA
Text: report on civic administration made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr H . J. R, Cole, A.l.C.A., Town Clerk

Speaker: NA
Text: of Hobart, which recommends the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of a city council for Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tf so, will the Minister consider making

Speaker: NA
Text: similar provision for Darwin and Alice

Speaker: NA
Text: Springs? I draw tho Minister's atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the foUowing passage which

Speaker: NA
Text: appears on page 9 of Mr Cole's report:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The difference between the maintenance

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the vote and the revenue derived from

Speaker: NA
Text: the residents in rates, fees, charges and fares,

Speaker: NA
Text: is in effect a Federal subsidy to' the local

Speaker: NA
Text: government of the city.

Speaker: NA
Text: "Will the Minister bear that statement in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind when he establishes, as I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: he will establish, councils in Darwin and

Speaker: NA
Text: Alice Springs?

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Text: I have read the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port that has been submitted to the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment by Mr Cole. I t is now being

Speaker: NA
Text: considered by an inter-departmental com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee that has been established for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of making recommendations re-

Speaker: NA
Text: garding the implementation of Mr Cole's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals i f they are considered to be

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate to the Australia]! Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. I t is too early to say what will

Speaker: NA
Text: be the outcome of the very comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: report that Mr Cole has prepared. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have not yet received the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations of the inter-departmental

Speaker: NA
Text: committee to which I have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred. The honorable gentleman has

Speaker: NA
Text: asked whether councils will be estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished in Darwin and Alice Springs

Speaker: NA
Text: if one is established in Canberra. That

Speaker: NA
Text: matter will be considered, i f neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary, at a later stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: TRUSTEESHIP TERRITORIES.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: M y question, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is addressed to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: External Affairs, in the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for External Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories, relates to the criticism of the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of Australian trusteeship

Speaker: NA
Text: territories that was voiced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Russian delegate at a recent meeting of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Trusteeship Council of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. The Russian delegate stated

Speaker: NA
Text: that no steps have been taken by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government to place natives in

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of any aspect of the administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of its trusteeship territories. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister in a position to inform

Speaker: NA
Text: me whether that statement i9 true?

Speaker: NA
Text: If natives have not yet been

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to any significant posts

Speaker: NA
Text: in the administration, are any steps

Speaker: NA
Text: being taken to so appoint them? Are any

Speaker: NA
Text: natives being trained for such purposes?

Speaker: NA
Text: I f they are, what is the nature of the posts

Speaker: NA
Text: to which they may be appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: and where is the training taking place?

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: I am aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: por- general nature of the attacks to which

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable gentleman has referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were made not only by Russia but

Speaker: NA
Text: also by other countries. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: delegates at Lake Success replied to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot say offhand the present stage of

Speaker: NA
Text: the plans of the Minister for External

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories to provide for natives hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: some degree of administrative responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility in the territories. I shall obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: the information for the benefit of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman and inform him

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOMERS CAMP.

Speaker: Mr RYAN
Text: M y question relates to a

Speaker: NA
Text: recent transaction in which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment purchased for £145,000 a property

Speaker: NA
Text: known as Somers Camp and which they

Speaker: NA
Text: sold two years ago for £20,000. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Interior aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: the shareholders of the company that

Speaker: NA
Text: bought the property two years ago have

Speaker: NA
Text: made a profit of 100 per cent, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: transaction ? Were they enabled to do so

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the actions of the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Interior? Does this profit

Speaker: NA
Text: come out of the public funds? Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister lay on the table the file relative

Speaker: NA
Text: to the transaction?

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Text: I have already ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained very fully the whole of the circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances of the acquisition of the property

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria that is known as Somers

Speaker: NA
Text: Camp. The business was carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: under the provisions of the Lands

Speaker: NA
Text: Acquisition Act. When properties

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be acquired by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, sworn valuators are engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Australian Government to value

Speaker: NA
Text: the property that is to be acquired. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: valuations are then checked by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner of Taxation or by some of his

Speaker: NA
Text: officers. When there is a divergence in

Speaker: NA
Text: valuations, a conference of the valuators

Speaker: NA
Text: is held before any recommendation is

Speaker: NA
Text: made to me by my officers. I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: make the file available to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders because the valua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions were sound and there is nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: hide. After a question was asked in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House recently concerning this matter T

Speaker: NA
Text: examined the papers with an officer of

Speaker: NA
Text: tlie Department of the Interior, and

Speaker: NA
Text: am convinced that the purchase of the action

Speaker: NA
Text: land at the figure quoted by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders was quite justified.

Speaker: NA
Text: PROPOSED MINISTRY OF

Speaker: NA
Text: HOUSEKEEPING.

Speaker: Mrs BLACKBURN
Text: Ca n the Prime submit

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister say whether he has received

Speaker: NA
Text: request from the Federated Association

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian Housewives in terms of a

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution passed by the members of that

Speaker: NA
Text: body at a recent conference advocating

Speaker: NA
Text: the establishment of a department of

Speaker: NA
Text: housekeeping and the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: that department by a woman Minister?

Speaker: NA
Text: Can the right honorable gentleman inform

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of the details of similar action

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in Denmark and in other European

Speaker: NA
Text: countries? Does he agree that, in place

Speaker: NA
Text: of concentration on various matters

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the war, for the administration

Speaker: NA
Text: which Commonwealth departments were:

Speaker: NA
Text: established but have now ceased to exist,

Speaker: NA
Text: our domestic problems should receive a

Speaker: NA
Text: high priority?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I bave received remost

Speaker: NA
Text: presentations from' one, and maybe

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations advocating the appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: of a Minister for housekeeping or thc

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation to such a service of a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: with some similar appropriate title.

Speaker: NA
Text: head of the Government charged with

Speaker: NA
Text: the duty of allocating portfolios, I

Speaker: NA
Text: given consideration to the matter, but at to the honorable member that the

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment I cannot approve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of such a portfolio. I n any

Speaker: NA
Text: event, honorable members would probably

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the holder of the suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio by such a term as " Mother

Speaker: NA
Text: Hubbard" or by some similar colto

Speaker: NA
Text: loquialism. Whilst I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: in one or two countries, notably

Speaker: NA
Text: Denmark, action has been taken along

Speaker: NA
Text: the lines indicated hy the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member, I shall ascertain exactly what

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done in this aspect of social

Speaker: NA
Text: and when I have obtained that informathe

Speaker: NA
Text: tion I shall give further consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member's request.

Speaker: NA
Text: NATIONAL WORKS PROGRAMME.

Speaker: Mr BERNARD CORSER
Text: An-

Speaker: NA
Text: nouncements are made from time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: that particular works in the works

Speaker: NA
Text: grammes of the States have been approved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the National Works Council. Will

Speaker: NA
Text: I the Prime Minister indicate what local

Speaker: NA
Text: is necessary for local authorities to

Speaker: NA
Text: have proposed works, such as the con-,

Speaker: NA
Text: struction of shipping ports and the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of water facilities, included in the

Speaker: NA
Text: national works programme?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Loca l authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: particulars of projects that they

Speaker: NA
Text: a desire to have included in the national

Speaker: NA
Text: works programme to State governments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the first instance. The projects are then

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the co-ordinator of works in

Speaker: NA
Text: each State. I think that Mr Kemp is

Speaker: NA
Text: the co-ordinator of works in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: and that Mr Swift is the co-ordinator of

Speaker: NA
Text: works in New South Wales. I n the other

Speaker: NA
Text: States various officers have been appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the State governments to co-ordinate

Speaker: NA
Text: the works programmes of the States. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sultation then takes place between the

Speaker: NA
Text: durState co-ordinator of works and the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commonwealth Co-ordinator-General of

Speaker: NA
Text: Works, and those officials are guided in

Speaker: NA
Text: their deliberations very largely by the

Speaker: NA
Text: availability of materials and labour. Thfty

Speaker: NA
Text: then set out what, in their view, are the

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent works, and the Co-ordinator-

Speaker: NA
Text: two, General of Works makes reports and

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations to the National Works

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of the order of urgency that

Speaker: NA
Text: should be given to the various projects,

Speaker: NA
Text: As always, of course, on the understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: that money is available to carry out the

Speaker: NA
Text: have works. Perhaps I should make it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: v

Speaker: NA
Text: Premiers themselves do not desire the

Speaker: NA
Text: general publication of all the lists of works

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been approved, because from

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time they may wish to alter the

Speaker: NA
Text: order pf priority that has been allotted

Speaker: NA
Text: projects in the respective States. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Co-ordinator-General of

Speaker: NA
Text: Works is guided by the State co-ordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nators of works. J f a State body desires

Speaker: NA
Text: to have certain proposals considered, its

Speaker: NA
Text: representations should be made to the

Speaker: NA
Text: life, State Government and be dealt with by

Speaker: NA
Text: State co-ordinator before the matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: to raised with the Commonwealth Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinator-General of Works.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETROL.

Speaker: Mr GEORGE LAWSON
Text: Wil l the

Speaker: NA
Text: proPrime Minister infonn me whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it is a fact, as reported in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne press last Saturday, that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has received advices from the Act-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing High Commissioner for Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Kingdom, Mr Norman

Speaker: NA
Text: Mighell, to the effect that the Polish

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has refused to supply petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia? I f that is a fact, has the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tight honorable gentleman any comment

Speaker: NA
Text: to make upon the matter, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the many statements that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made by leaders of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: parties in the tory press that petrol was

Speaker: NA
Text: available from Poland for the asking?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I made a comment

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier about the matter, and I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: -desire to add to i t now. The position is

Speaker: NA
Text: .thait an Australian company submitted

Speaker: NA
Text: .a request to the Commonwealth for a

Speaker: NA
Text: licence to import petrol from Poland.

Speaker: NA
Text: -Speaking from memory, I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the petrol was to be loaded at Stettin.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were not quite sure about the currency

Speaker: NA
Text: position, and, naturally, we consulted the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank of England and the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: <d©in Treasury, which are the British

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities responsible for exchange con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol in regard to dollars, in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves about the situation. We inti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated to the applicant company that i f

Speaker: NA
Text: it could buy petrol for sterling, and pay

Speaker: NA
Text: the freight and insurance charges in

Speaker: NA
Text: sterling, the import licence would be

Speaker: NA
Text: granted. Later, I received from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting High Commissioner for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia i n the United Kingdom a

Speaker: NA
Text: cable i n which he said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the applicant com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany had approached him on the subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: They had found that a difficulty had

Speaker: NA
Text: arisen in obtaining an export licence

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Polish Government, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: asked whether the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would make representations to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Polish Government about the matter. I

Speaker: NA
Text: sent to Mr Mighell a icable in which I

Speaker: NA
Text: asked him to inquire of the Polish repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentative the reasons, i f there were any

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons, for his Government's decision not

Speaker: NA
Text: to grant the export licence for the petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: which, the company had said, could be

Speaker: NA
Text: bought in Poland. The Polish Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has briefly informed us that it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: able to grant the export licence. We

Speaker: NA
Text: already knew that it had to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: crudes from the Persian Gulf to Stettin,

Speaker: NA
Text: and then take them inland for refining.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petrol would be extremely expensive

Speaker: NA
Text: in such circumstances. I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: Poland has not sufficient petrol to meet its

Speaker: NA
Text: own requirements. The Polish Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has made it clear that the only

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for its refusal to grant the export

Speaker: NA
Text: licence is the unavailability of petrol.

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: I ask the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister whether it is true that the petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption of Commonwealth depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and instrumentalities amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: 800,000 gallons in June and 942,000 gal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lons in July, compared with an average

Speaker: NA
Text: monthly consumption of 680,000 gallons.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the coal strike did not affect consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in June, what was the reason for the

Speaker: NA
Text: big increase in that month? Will th»

Speaker: NA
Text: Government instruct departments that

Speaker: NA
Text: they must keep their consumption within

Speaker: NA
Text: the quota of 800,000 gallons a month,

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Prime Minister told the

Speaker: NA
Text: premiers was the Commonwealth's petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation, just as all other fuel users are

Speaker: NA
Text: compelled to limit their consumption of

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol to quotas? Is it a fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: numerous new inspectorial activities,

Speaker: NA
Text: which were not previously considered to

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfy be necessary, are being undertaken by

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental officers with the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: motor cars, thereby increasing the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth's use of fuel?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: I t is true that the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption in June was higher than in

Speaker: NA
Text: previous months. I have taken the trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a personal examination of returns

Speaker: NA
Text: which show the use of petrol by Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth departments and by Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: which have been supplied to me by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Interior. I have also

Speaker: NA
Text: asked the Public Service Board to direct

Speaker: NA
Text: its inspectorial staffs in the various States

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that petrol is not used for other

Speaker: NA
Text: than what can be reasonably regarded as

Speaker: NA
Text: essential or reasonably essential pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses. I made an inquiry into the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for the increased petrol con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption in June and learned that prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tically all of the fuel was used for

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely essential services, mainly in

Speaker: NA
Text: connexion with the carriage of materials.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable gentleman mentioned the

Speaker: NA
Text: coal strike. Before the strike actually

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced coal was being rationed, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales Railways Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had reduced the number of goods

Speaker: NA
Text: trains engaged in the carrying of building

Speaker: NA
Text: materials, &e. I examined details of the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of petrol for the month mentioned,

Speaker: NA
Text: and found that at least 90 per eent. was

Speaker: NA
Text: used iu tiie maintenance of essential

Speaker: NA
Text: services, and in the carrying of neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary materials. That being so, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no justification for taking anj

Speaker: NA
Text: action against departments or depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental officers. I told the Premiers

Speaker: NA
Text: what quantity of petrol was being

Speaker: NA
Text: used by Oommonwealth departments,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I cannot remember telling them

Speaker: NA
Text: that that quantity -would not be exceeded.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is obvious that i f there were a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete cessation of railway traffic to Can-

Speaker: NA
Text: berra, where much building is in progress,

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be necessary to use motor lorries

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring cement here from the factories.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, it is even now very difficult to get

Speaker: NA
Text: cement carried by the railways because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the shortage of trucks. I assure the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member that I have examined

Speaker: NA
Text: particulars of mileages covered by Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth vehicles, and the quantity

Speaker: NA
Text: of petrol consumed. Upon occasions, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to take up cases with the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters in charge of departments, when

Speaker: NA
Text: I thought that there had been excessive

Speaker: NA
Text: travelling by administrative officers, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I have asked Ministers to make persona]

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries. There will be no unavoidable

Speaker: NA
Text: use of petrol by Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: departments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr ABCHI E CAMEEON -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has stated that people who

Speaker: NA
Text: hoard petrol will be dealt with. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth has no power to

Speaker: NA
Text: ration petrol, can the Prime Minister say

Speaker: NA
Text: whence it will derive power to prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: people from hoarding petrol, or to punish

Speaker: NA
Text: them for doing so?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Th e point that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable meniber has put is that i f some

Speaker: NA
Text: persons-an d the practice has been par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly pronounced among certain

Speaker: NA
Text: wealthy primary producers-hav e hoarded

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive quantities of petrol, the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has no power to take action

Speaker: NA
Text: against them.

Speaker: Mr ARCHIE CAMERON
Text: I ask whenco

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government would obtain power to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with persons who hoard petrol.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Tha t question has

Speaker: NA
Text: been closely examined. Certain legal

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties are associated with the matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we believe that they can be overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: not, perhaps, in the way that the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member thinks, but i n an indirect

Speaker: NA
Text: way, in the distribution of future supplies

Speaker: NA
Text: of petrol. I shall arrange to have that

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of the matter explained to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member when there is a law on

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: CIVIL AVIATION.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Ha s the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Civil Aviation seen reports to the effect

Speaker: NA
Text: that Melbourne is likely to be bypassed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the international air race, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been organized by New Zealand to taka

Speaker: NA
Text: place in 1953, because there is no inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national airport in that city? As Essen-

Speaker: NA
Text: don is the busiest airport in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and as there is accumulating evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of disability caused by the lack of inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national aircraft landing facilities i n

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, will the Minister review the-

Speaker: NA
Text: decision not to make Melbourne an inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national airport?

Speaker: Mr DRAKEFORD
Text: I have not read;

Speaker: NA
Text: the reports to which the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber has referred, but I can quite under-*

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the reasons for the decision not fd

Speaker: NA
Text: make Melbourne a point on the route

Speaker: NA
Text: of the international air race to New Zea-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. So far as I am aware, that city

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be on the direct track to that

Speaker: NA
Text: dominion, and competing aircraft would

Speaker: NA
Text: need .to make a diversion in order to pass

Speaker: NA
Text: over Melbourne. The honorable membei

Speaker: NA
Text: has also suggested that Melbourne should

Speaker: NA
Text: also be made an international airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: The explanation why that has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: done already has been made before,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I repeat it now for the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman's information. The agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment between the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America and Australia provides for an

Speaker: NA
Text: international airport at each terminal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Airports have been established in

Speaker: NA
Text: accordance with that agreement, and any

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal for a variation of the agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to be made by either the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of the United States or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government. Personally, I

Speaker: NA
Text: see no necessity for such a variation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: net result of making Melbourne an inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national airport, and of permitting any

Speaker: NA
Text: international service to terminate at Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne, would be that the designated air-

Speaker: NA
Text: line of the United States of America,

Speaker: NA
Text: Pan-American Airways, which might be

Speaker: NA
Text: more heavily subsidized than Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: airlines, would be able to send their air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft to Melbourne, and compete with Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian National Airways Proprietary

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited, Ansett Airways Proprietary

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited and Trans-Australia Airlines

Speaker: NA
Text: causing a total loss in revenue to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian airlines of £400 to £500 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. No doubt it would cause the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Balaclava and his

Speaker: NA
Text: associates in the Opposition a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of satisfaction i f Australian airlines wero

Speaker: NA
Text: to incur such losses.

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Text: I have received repreCasas

Speaker: NA
Text: sentations from the Tasmanian Farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation and from individual farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: who have made overtures to Titan Nail

Speaker: NA
Text: and Wire Proprietary Limited, of Hobart,

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of their urgent requirements of

Speaker: NA
Text: feed wire, which is used in the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of barbed wire and staples. The company

Speaker: NA
Text: also manufactures nails, and is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: asset to Tasmania's expanding economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the Minister representing the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Supply and Development take

Speaker: NA
Text: action to ascertain whether there is any

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of increasing Tasmania's quota

Speaker: NA
Text: of wire feed, which is manufactured at

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryland's works at Newcastle?

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Unti l recently, the

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution of supplies of wire for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of nails was under .the juris-

Speaker: NA
Text: diction of the Division of Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Development of the Department of Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: war Reconstruction. However, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government was advised that it no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer had any constitutional authority to

Speaker: NA
Text: decide what allocations should be made

Speaker: NA
Text: to the respective States, it informed the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments that, as from the

Speaker: NA
Text: lst July, it could no longer undertake the

Speaker: NA
Text: task of allocating materials to the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the Commonwealth has no

Speaker: NA
Text: power in this matter, the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Post-war Reconstruction has referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the manufacturers various representations

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been made to it from time to

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and the manufacturers have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to accede to many of those requests.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall be happy to make representations

Speaker: NA
Text: to the company with a view to securing

Speaker: NA
Text: greater supplies of wire for Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPORTATIONS.

Speaker: Mr LANG
Text: A t the beginning of this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, I addressed a question to the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Immigration about Tunica y Casas

Speaker: NA
Text: and his wife. Tunica y Casas was

Speaker: NA
Text: formerly secretary of the Communist

Speaker: NA
Text: party in New Caledonia, and a contact

Speaker: NA
Text: man for the Communist party in South

Speaker: NA
Text: blast Asia. The Minister stated that they

Speaker: NA
Text: had been given until the end of May to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave Australia. He added that i f they had

Speaker: NA
Text: not left by then they would be deported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Have they yet left Australia ? I f not, has

Speaker: NA
Text: any order been served on them? Were

Speaker: NA
Text: representations made on their behalf and

Speaker: NA
Text: if so, by whom ? Has the Minister stayed

Speaker: NA
Text: WIRE. his hand i n this case because Tunica y

Speaker: NA
Text: and his wife are an embarrassment

Speaker: NA
Text: to their landlords, or is he trying to help

Speaker: NA
Text: their landlords? Have reports been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived about visits paid to these people by

Speaker: NA
Text: native crews of ships that come from New

Speaker: NA
Text: Caledonia and Indo-China? Did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Security Intelligence Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation recommend the deportation?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I remember when

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member asked me a series

Speaker: NA
Text: of questions about these people, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the answers I gave. On that

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion, I stated that these people occu-

Speaker: NA
Text: pied a building in Ash-street, Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: This particular partnership of sandwich

Speaker: NA
Text: suppliers occupied the cellar and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal party occupied the garret. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: members of native crews have been visit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the place, they may have been coming

Speaker: NA
Text: to join the Liberal party. I shall make

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries, and answer at a later date the

Speaker: NA
Text: various questions asked by the honorahle

Speaker: NA
Text: member.

Speaker: NA
Text: PASSPORTS.

Speaker: Mr HAMILTON
Text: Ha s the attention

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Minister for Immigration been

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn to a report that John Brownlee, the

Speaker: NA
Text: well-known tenor, and his wife were barred

Speaker: NA
Text: by French authorities when they

Speaker: NA
Text: attempted to enter France on a new Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian passport, and that they were

Speaker: NA
Text: escorted back to their boat and returned to

Speaker: NA
Text: England the following day? I t is a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that every person who desires to enter

Speaker: NA
Text: Italy on a new Australian passport is

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to pay 50s. Australian for a vise

Speaker: NA
Text: and extra passport photograph, whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: until the word " British" was deleted

Speaker: NA
Text: from the passport, such persons were

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted free to that country ? Is it a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that whilst British people have no diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culty in entering Spain, Australians can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not obtain Spanish vises in London ? Will

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister take appropriate action to

Speaker: NA
Text: end this humiliation of Australians?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I take i t that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member can vouch for the

Speaker: NA
Text: accuracy of the statements to which he has

Speaker: NA
Text: referred.

Speaker: Mr HAMILTON
Text: The y have been pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished in newspaper reports.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Tha t is the best of

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that the statements are entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: incorrect. The report to which the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member has referred is the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: stupid report upon which the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman would base a question. I

Speaker: NA
Text: heard from somebody a few days

Speaker: NA
Text: ago that there had been some com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaint of the sort that the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member has voiced. The truth of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter is that Australians experience no

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty in entering any country pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided they make arrangements to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: vises. However, Great Britain and a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of European countries have

Speaker: NA
Text: entered into an agreement whereby they

Speaker: NA
Text: mutually agree to discard the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: vis6s. Australia was asked .to become a

Speaker: NA
Text: party to that agreement. Switzerland was

Speaker: NA
Text: one country that asked us to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, Italy was not a party to any

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement, because at that particular time

Speaker: NA
Text: the peace treaty in respect of Italy had

Speaker: NA
Text: not been concluded. Thus, I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: what Italy's position would be. I ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained this matter when it was raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Parramatta

Speaker: NA
Text: after he returned from a trip abroad. I

Speaker: NA
Text: then pointed out that for security reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not desirable that Australia, which

Speaker: NA
Text: situated 13,000 miles from Europe, should

Speaker: NA
Text: permit persons to enter this country with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out a proper vise. As we are not prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow other nationals to enter this

Speaker: NA
Text: country without vises, we cannot expect-

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries to allow entry to our

Speaker: NA
Text: nationals without vises. However, per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons who wish to travel would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the slightest difficulty in obtaining vises

Speaker: NA
Text: if they make proper application to the

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities of the countries they desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter before tliey leave Australia or at the

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomatic and consular office of such

Speaker: NA
Text: nations in British countries.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Ar e our passports stilt

Speaker: NA
Text: marked " British passport" ?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: The y are marked

Speaker: NA
Text: " Australian citizen ".

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: The y used to he marked

Speaker: NA
Text: " Britisli passport".

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Tha t is so; but

Speaker: NA
Text: under the new nationality law we describe

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves as " Australian citizens ", and

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain has altered its passports

Speaker: NA
Text: similarly so ithat residents of Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain are not described now as " British

Speaker: NA
Text: subjects " but are primarily described as

Speaker: NA
Text: " United Kingdom citizens ". The whole

Speaker: NA
Text: of the alterations are consequent upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of new legislation. The whole

Speaker: NA
Text: of thc issues raised were answered when

Speaker: NA
Text: they were first mentioned by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Parramatta and they

Speaker: NA
Text: were more fully discussed when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationality and Citizenship Bill was

Speaker: NA
Text: under discussion. I shall have particular

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries made, but I remind the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman that a lot of great artists

Speaker: NA
Text: are like members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Country party: They are rather

Speaker: NA
Text: temperamental.

Speaker: NA
Text: FREEDOM OF WORSHIP.

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Text: Ha s the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Externa] Affairs seen the statement in

Speaker: NA
Text: which it is reported that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: of Czechoslovakia is passing legislation to

Speaker: NA
Text: control the church? Has he also seen

Speaker: NA
Text: the statement of the spokesman for that

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that it does not regard

Speaker: NA
Text: religion as a wholly private affair for

Speaker: NA
Text: each individual ? Is this action in accor-

Speaker: NA
Text: dance with the declarations and decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Nations? I f not, will Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia protest against this infringement

Speaker: NA
Text: is of human freedom? I f no action is

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the United Nations, for how long

Speaker: NA
Text: are we expected to perpetuate the farce

Speaker: NA
Text: of Russia using the United Nations for

Speaker: NA
Text: its own ends and yet refusing to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: any decision that makes for the better-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of conditions affecting humanity?

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: I f the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Maranoa wishes to criticize the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations, he should not found his

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism upon one incident of this kind,

Speaker: NA
Text: to wliicli there is, I think, a complete

Speaker: NA
Text: answer from the point of view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations. The facts are that in

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern Europe, first in Hungary, then

Speaker: NA
Text: in Bulgaria and now extending to Czecho-

Speaker: NA
Text: slovakia and Roumania, the Communist

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments have systematically pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vented the exercise of religious free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom. I t is equally true that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia took the initiative in bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: General Assembly of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. The result was a resolution,

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with the treaties of peace

Speaker: NA
Text: made at Paris with those satellites of

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany, that action should be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: under tliose treaties. The matter is now

Speaker: NA
Text: actually being discussed by the General

Speaker: NA
Text: Assembly. I n addition to the matters

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have mentioned, the very matter

Speaker: NA
Text: that the honorable member has referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to is also being discussed. The fact is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the United Nations is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: forum in the world where conduct of that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind may be brought to the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world and criticized. I am certain

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is of great value in carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: through the objectives of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations. I do not know whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman was personally

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for the sentence of his question

Speaker: NA
Text: in which he talked about the " farce " of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations. I venture to say

Speaker: NA
Text: if that is his opinion

Speaker: Mr ADERMANN
Text: I ref erred, to Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: making a farce of it.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: Ther e is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: every member nation, uses the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations as a forum, including Russia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is a part of the procedure of open dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion, just as, in this House, every

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member may bring before other

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members matters in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: are interested. That is not in fact; in-

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with the idea of a world forum:

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the very nature of it. I f Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: uses thc United Nations, it gets an answer

Speaker: NA
Text: in kind. The public opinion of the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world turns against conduct which

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudices the practice of all religions

Speaker: NA
Text: in the countries in eastern Europe to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: TARIFE BOARD.

Speaker: NA
Text: REPORTS ON ITEMS.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: reports of the Tariff Board on the follow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing subjects:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Spectacle frames, lenses and cases:

Speaker: NA
Text: Spectacles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mercury contact tubes (Interim report).

Speaker: NA
Text: Mercury contact tubes.

Speaker: NA
Text: ARMED FORCES.

Speaker: Dame ENID LYONS
Text: Ha s the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army seen the report in

Speaker: NA
Text: the press of .the 5th August that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous six months 5,000 members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Citizen Military Forees had

Speaker: NA
Text: resigned ? Can the Minister say whether

Speaker: NA
Text: that is true? I f so, to what does he

Speaker: NA
Text: ascribe those resignations? Can the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister also say whether the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: troops on strength at that time was only

Speaker: NA
Text: 15,798, although the establishment pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided for a strength of 50,000 troops ?

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: I have seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: press statement to which the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has referred. I t is totally in-

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate. The figures were probably com-

Speaker: NA

Text: move-

Speaker: NA
Text: As honorable members are aware, durlations

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the war i t was necessary to supplement,

Speaker: NA
Text: defence legislation with a large body

Text: National Security Regulations.

Text: allowed to lapse, or are now no longer

Text: required. A few, however, relate

Text: matters of a continuing nature, and

Speaker: NA
Text: an important bearing on the present and

Text: future administration of the services. Tho

Speaker: NA
Text: main purpose of this bill is to give

Speaker: NA
Text: legislative effect to the substance of sucb

Text: of the remaining National Security

Text: Regulations which are administered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence and service departments, as it amended.

Speaker: NA
Text: is considered essential to continue i n

Speaker: NA
Text: manent form i n the Defence Act. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: thus forms an important part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: action necessary to be taken to bring to ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: an end war-time legislation continued

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of the Defence (Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Pro-visions) Act. Certain "other proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments of an urgent nature, outance

Speaker: NA
Text: side the scope of the National Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulations, have also been included in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: -Some provisions of the measure concern

Speaker: NA
Text: the three services; others concern the administered hy other

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Army only. A bil l to amend the Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Act to give permanent legislaappropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: tive effect to the substance of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security Regulations which

Speaker: NA
Text: relate only to the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Navy, w i l l be brought

Text: down during these sittings by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Navy ( Mr Riordan). The folfow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing National Security Regulations are

Speaker: NA
Text: now administered by the defence ana

Speaker: NA
Text: service departments:-Nationa l Security

Speaker: NA
Text: (Internment Camp) Regulations,

Text: National Security ( M i l i t a r y Forces)

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulations, National Security (Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Charter Rates) Regulations, Nauonai

Speaker: NA
Text: Security (Naval Forces) Regulations,

Text: National Security (Prisoners of War)

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulations, National Security (Women's

Speaker: NA
Text: Services) Regulations, certain regulations

Text: of the National Security (General) Regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations and National Security (Supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary) Regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill and the measure to amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Naval Defence Act which is to he

Speaker: NA
Text: - I brought down by the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy, incorporate the substance of such

Speaker: NA
Text: of these regulations as are still required,

Speaker: NA
Text: or provide f or the making of similar regu-

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Defence A ct or Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Act. F r o m the l s t January, 1950,

Speaker: NA
Text: of therefore, the regulations which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: Thi mentioned w i l l cease to operate under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence (Transitional Provisions) Act,

Speaker: NA
Text: except a few provisions of the general and

Speaker: NA
Text: to supplementary regulations which are

Speaker: NA
Text: hav< administered by the defence and ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice departments and which i t is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered necessary to continue. The latter

Speaker: NA
Text: will he repealed as soon as possible after

Speaker: NA
Text: that date, and w i ll be replaced by appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate regulations to be made under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Act as i t is now proposed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill and the Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: perDefence B i l l deal with such National

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Regulations as are the sole con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern of the defence and service depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other regulations,

Speaker: NA
Text: i n however, such as the provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security (General) Regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: which relate to the handling and convey-

Speaker: NA
Text: of explosives, and the provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Security (Supplementary)

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulations which relate to the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of the affairs of persons missing as

Speaker: NA
Text: a result of war operations, i n which those

Speaker: NA
Text: departments are interested, but which are

Speaker: NA
Text: departments.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Consideration is being given by the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible departments to the taking of

Speaker: NA
Text: action i n regard to these.

Speaker: NA
Text: Among matters now covered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Security Regulations and f or

Speaker: NA
Text: which this bill makes permanent provision

Speaker: NA
Text: are tho adjustment of ranks of members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the military forces after war service,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is covered by clause 4, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: unauthorized use, possession, or supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: uniforms and emblems. Clause 15 will

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen the existing provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: section S3 of the Defence Act in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to the latter. I n addition, it is proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to amend section 124 of the Defence Act

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable regulations to be made under

Speaker: NA
Text: that act to deal with the following

Speaker: NA
Text: matters which are now covered by

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security Eegulations:-Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension, variation, or cancellation of

Speaker: NA
Text: allotments of pay of members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: military forces; the extension of exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing powers in the Defence Act to regulate

Speaker: NA
Text: and control buildings, &c, in defence

Speaker: NA
Text: areas; certification of death and the

Speaker: NA
Text: post-mortem examination and disposal of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bodies of members of the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: forces who die while on service; prisoners

Speaker: NA
Text: of war; command and discipline of bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Naval, Military or Air Force or

Speaker: NA
Text: any two of those forces acting together;

Speaker: NA
Text: aud provisions relating to the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of oaths and the execution of

Speaker: NA
Text: powers of attorney by members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apart from the provisions of the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: which arise out of National Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Eegulations, the most important amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment proposed _ is that which relates

Speaker: NA
Text: to the composition of the Permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: Military Forces. I n my statement

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Parliament on the 4th June.

Speaker: NA
Text: J947, on the Government's post-war

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policy, I said that the army

Speaker: NA
Text: programme provided for the raising

Speaker: NA
Text: of permanent forces, including a field

Speaker: NA
Text: force, certain fixed estahlishtaents,

Speaker: NA
Text: and cadres for instructional, administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive and other duties. These forces, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are known as the Australian Eegular

Speaker: NA
Text: Army, have been raised under war-time

Speaker: NA
Text: powers in the Defence Act which will

Speaker: NA
Text: cease as soon as a proclamation is issued

Speaker: NA
Text: terminating the " Time of War ". Section

Speaker: NA
Text: 31 of the act provides that, except in time

Speaker: NA
Text: of war, no permanent military forces shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be raised or organized except for adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trative and instructional staffs, including

Speaker: NA
Text: certain specified corps. I t is therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed to repeal the existing section an '

Speaker: NA
Text: to replace it with a section which will

Speaker: NA
Text: give the necessary statutory authority for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Eegular Army.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other provisions to which I invite the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of honorable members are to

Speaker: NA
Text: be found in clause 14, which gives statu-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory recognition to the Australian Cadet

Speaker: NA
Text: Corps, and in clause 19 which regulates

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment of officers to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Eegular Army. With the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment for the first time of an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Eegular Army, it is considered that the

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions imposed by the existing sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 148 of the act are too rigid, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill therefore provides such relaxation

Speaker: NA
Text: thereof as is considered necessary. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: intended that the amending act should

Speaker: NA
Text: commence on the lst January, 1950, that

Speaker: NA
Text: being the date up to which the continuance

Speaker: NA
Text: of National Security Eegulations is

Speaker: NA
Text: authorized by the Defence (Transitional

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions) Act 1948. Provision is made

Speaker: NA
Text: in clause 20 of the bill for the continuance

Speaker: NA
Text: in force, under the Defence Act, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security Eegulations specified

Speaker: NA
Text: in that clause. These will be amended or

Speaker: NA
Text: repealed as soon as it is practicable to

Speaker: NA
Text: prepare and gazette new regulations under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Defence Act as now proposed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: amended. I commend the bill to honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NAVA L DEFENCE BILL 1949.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr RIORDAN) agreed to-

Speaker: NA
Text: That leave be given to bring in a bill for an

Speaker: NA
Text: act to amend the Naval Defence Act 1910-1948.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented, and read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: SECOND EEADING.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: Kennedy-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Navy) [11.31] -b y leave- I

Speaker: NA
Text: move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill for an act to amend the Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Act 1910-1948, was referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Minister for Defence ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dedman) a few moments ago when he

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced the bill to amend the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1903-1948, and, like most of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of that measure, its purpose is to

Speaker: NA
Text: obviate the necessity for a further ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tension of certain sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence (Transitional Provisions) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1948. As a consequence, the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Security (Naval Forces) Eegulations and

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Security (Naval Charter

Speaker: NA
Text: Eates) Eegulations, which will cease to be

Speaker: NA
Text: effective after the end of 1949, will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be further extended. I t is desired to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the necessary provision to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: the services of certain senior commissioned

Speaker: NA
Text: officers and commissioned officers who

Speaker: NA
Text: received their appointments by virtue of

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Security (Naval Forces)

Speaker: NA
Text: Eegulations to be continued. Normally,

Speaker: NA
Text: those officers would not be eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: employment, being over the prescribed

Speaker: NA
Text: age, or lacking some other qualification.

Speaker: NA
Text: HoAvever, owing to the acute shortage of

Speaker: NA
Text: officers in the Eoyal Australian Navy, if

Speaker: NA
Text: is essential that the services of the tem-

Speaker: NA
Text: porary officers be retained whilst new

Speaker: NA
Text: appointees are entered and trained. The

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency of the Navy would be seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: affected should it become necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: dispense with the services of temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: officers before i t became possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: replace them. I point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: tbey are all volunteers for further service,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that none is being retained against his

Speaker: NA
Text: will.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the approved naval programme,

Speaker: NA
Text: many more permanent officers will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required than was the case in pre-war

Speaker: NA
Text: days. Every effort to obtain those

Speaker: NA
Text: officers is being explored, but it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: expected that the existing shortage wili

Speaker: NA
Text: be overtaken for a number of years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill also gives power to the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General to make regulations for the fixing

Speaker: NA
Text: of eharter rates and establishment charges

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of ships requisitioned for naval

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes. This will allow the making of

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations under the Naval Defence Act

Speaker: NA
Text: to replace the National Security (Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Charter Eates) Eegulations. Whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: most vessels requisitioned during the war

Speaker: NA
Text: have since been returned to their owner3

Speaker: NA
Text: or have been otherwise disposed of, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are a few still under charter, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to continue a charter rates

Speaker: NA
Text: board. The board is the authority for

Speaker: NA
Text: fixing charter rates and establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: charges in respect of requisitioned vessels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Owing to changing conditions, charter

Speaker: NA
Text: rates are altered from time to time, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is therefore necessary for the Charter

Speaker: NA
Text: Eates Board to be in a position to func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion while vessels are still under requisi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. It is unlikely that the last of the

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels will be derequisitioned before the

Speaker: NA
Text: end of 1950 at the earliest. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sfr. Riordan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion hy Mr MENZIES)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.
