Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENT OF EXTERNAL TERRITORIES.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed vote, £78,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed vote, £613,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Ordered to be considered together.)

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: North Sydney) [11.36].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I wish to say a few words about a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter that concerns us very closely. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the Minister for Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Calwell) for his immigration policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: As usual, of course, he has not hidden his

Speaker: NA
Text: light under a bushel. From time to time,

Speaker: NA
Text: he has told us exactly what progress he

Speaker: NA
Text: has been making; but let us consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures. The Minister would have us

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that he is responsible for a flow

Speaker: NA
Text: of immigrants to this country at a rate

Speaker: NA
Text: which is without parallel in our history.

Speaker: NA
Text: For everything that he has done, and is

Speaker: NA
Text: doing to bring to this country immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants who can be absorbed into the

Speaker: NA
Text: body politic, he is deserving of

Speaker: NA
Text: commendation, but I point out to him

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the country, that the results

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved so far are not satisfactory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration to Australia throughout our

Speaker: NA
Text: history has ebbed and flowed. At

Speaker: NA
Text: times the stream of migrants has

Speaker: NA
Text: swelled to a rushing torrent, and at other

Speaker: NA
Text: times it has shrunk to a mere trickle.

Speaker: NA
Text: On occasions, the stream has dried up.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the period 1910-14, long before

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia had the advantage of the efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: oi the present Minister, immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion attained proportions that have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been equalled since. During

Speaker: NA
Text: that quinquennial period no fewer than

Speaker: NA
Text: 048,512 migrants came to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The average rate of entry was 129,702

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants a year. During the period

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946-48, when the honorable gentleman's

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme was in operation, 218,381

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants entered this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: average was 72,000 migrants a year. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we consider that the population of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia during the years 1910 to 1914

Speaker: NA
Text: averaged 4,940,000 and that to-day it is,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the latest figures that are

Speaker: NA
Text: availahle, 7,794,000, we see very

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly that the results of the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable gentleman's scheme, notwith-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing the advantages that i t has

Speaker: NA
Text: derived from his association with it,

Speaker: NA
Text: have proved to be distinctly disappoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. Between 1910 and 1914 Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia gained 648,512 persons, or slightly

Speaker: NA
Text: over one-eighth of the population at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time. One-eighth of the present popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is 974,360 persons, but the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: gain that has heen made under the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's scheme is approximately 218,000

Speaker: NA
Text: persons. After the first World War,

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1919 and 1921 there was a net

Speaker: NA
Text: gain of 211,333 persons. Between 1946

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1948 the net gain was 65,000 persons.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the excess of departures over arrivals

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1946 is deducted, the figure is 50,570.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is an average of 16,000 a year as

Speaker: NA
Text: against an average of 70,000 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1919 and 1921. As I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the Minister for his efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring the right kind of people to this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, but I say to him that he ought

Speaker: NA
Text: not to grow weary with well doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have read with great interest a

Speaker: NA
Text: brochure entitled Policy and Progress

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister has made available to

Speaker: NA
Text: me. I t is chiefly remarkable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: admirable photograph of himself that

Speaker: NA
Text: appears on the first page. I admit that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has enormous advantages over me in

Speaker: NA
Text: that respect. Candidly, I hand him the

Speaker: NA
Text: bun in tiiat connexion. When I read th<»

Speaker: NA
Text: brochure, which I did as part of my duty

Speaker: NA
Text: as a member of the Parliament, I found

Speaker: NA
Text: that the photograph was much the

Speaker: NA
Text: best part of it. But although migra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is a most important factor, it

Speaker: NA
Text: has always played a subsidiary part

Speaker: NA
Text: thc growth of population of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. For over a century of our

Speaker: NA
Text: history it has borne the same relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the growth of our population by natural

Speaker: NA
Text: increase as one bears to three. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister has noticed, because

Speaker: NA
Text: few things escape his notice, that in days

Speaker: NA
Text: gone by the birth-rate in Australia which

Speaker: NA
Text: was, with the possible exception of New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand, the highest of any country in

Speaker: NA
Text: the English-speaking world had fallen

Speaker: NA
Text: to a dangerously low level. Lately it has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken an upward trend. Eor that, many

Speaker: NA
Text: thanks. I am not endeavouring now to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with the birth-rate in detail. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am merely pointing out to the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter that migration cannot, of itself,

Speaker: NA
Text: solve the problem. I am thoroughly

Speaker: NA
Text: alive to the point that although the

Speaker: NA
Text: birth-rate may swell our numbers, for

Speaker: NA
Text: a generation it will be unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide us with more people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of co-operating i n the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of our resources and, i f need be, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence of this country. I remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister that included in the 218,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people who were brought to this country

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1946 and 1948, were a great many

Speaker: NA
Text: children. That remark applies, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the migrants who were brought to this

Speaker: NA
Text: country before World War II . I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitable that the kind of people that we

Speaker: NA
Text: want will he people who bring children

Speaker: NA
Text: with them. The point I am endeavouring

Speaker: NA
Text: to make is that the situation in which Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia finds itself to-day is one that ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to cause every one of us great concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aft-ithe first World War, the world had

Speaker: NA
Text: no experience of the effects of great con-

Speaker: NA
Text: flicts. The victory had been won although

Speaker: NA
Text: at a great price. The fighting forces, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, suffered enormously more casual-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties than they did during the war of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1939-45, although civilian casualties wero

Speaker: NA
Text: much less. I was a delegate to the Inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national Peace Conference, and the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of that conference believed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: world had before it then an unbroken vista

Speaker: NA
Text: of peace, and that it might confidently

Speaker: NA
Text: look to the League of Nations to iron out

Speaker: NA
Text: the differences and settle disputes between

Speaker: NA
Text: the nations that had formerly led to war.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our subsequent bitter experence taught

Speaker: NA
Text: us, however, that although the League of

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations was theoretically capable of pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: venting war, practically i t proved a

Speaker: NA
Text: broken reed. Now we are confronted

Speaker: NA
Text: with a situation that is incomparably

Speaker: NA
Text: more menacing than that presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: us after World War I. Because no one

Speaker: NA
Text: can predict the future, I speak with some

Speaker: NA
Text: hesitation in this matter, but it cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be denied that our present position must

Speaker: NA
Text: give us great concern. I point out to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister that "UNO", the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations orgiiiiization, is simply another

Speaker: NA
Text: name for the " League of Nations",

Speaker: NA
Text: and that where the League of Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: failed the United Nations cann

Speaker: NA
Text: hope to succeed. We have all

Speaker: NA
Text: been impressed by the contributions

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt) to entertain mankind with his

Speaker: NA
Text: injunctions to " Leave everything to

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations organization. It can and

Speaker: NA
Text: will prevent another world war ". What

Speaker: NA
Text: has the United Nations done? What is

Speaker: NA
Text: it doing now? It is at once the most

Speaker: NA
Text: garrulous and futile of human insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions. Its members make speeches,

Speaker: NA
Text: but action is outside their

Speaker: NA
Text: This morning we have hepn fc"!' 1

Speaker: NA
Text: more of what it is doing. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: remains that Russia takes no notice

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever of the United Nations. Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: knows perfectly well that the United Na-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions is impotent. I am not, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: accusing the Minister for Immigration of

Speaker: NA
Text: worshipping at that shrine. I am merely

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing out that Australia is at once the

Speaker: NA
Text: most inviting and the most vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: country in the world. War may he

Speaker: NA
Text: averted because Russia is not yet ready

Speaker: NA
Text: to assault the world by armed force. One

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, however, cannot be averted, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: that I direct the attention of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and of the country: the world's

Speaker: NA
Text: population is increasing unevenly, and at

Speaker: NA
Text: c great pace. Australians are the heirs to

Speaker: NA
Text: and trustees of this vast island continent,

Speaker: NA
Text: vvhich, although it contains a great area

Speaker: NA
Text: of barren waste, can absorb tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of people, as the Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: himself very properly pointed out. With

Speaker: NA
Text: others, I believe that the potentialities

Speaker: NA
Text: of this country have not yet been even

Speaker: NA
Text: envisaged. In the fullness of time, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia must hold tens of millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: Time works great changes. Japan,

Speaker: NA
Text: vvhich was our ally during World

Speaker: NA
Text: War I., was our enemy during the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: war, and came within an ace of over-

Speaker: NA
Text: whelming us. Indeed, but for the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America, the Japanese would

Speaker: NA
Text: have overwhelmed us. Previously we were

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hughes.

Speaker: NA
Text: shrouded in remote distance, and lay

Speaker: NA
Text: securely sheltered under the broad wing

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Royal Navy until the outbreak of

Speaker: NA
Text: World War II . The British Navy is no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer mistress of the seas, and sea-power

Speaker: NA
Text: itself has declined to a secondary place

Speaker: NA
Text: in defence. During the recent war Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: although defeated, suffered little material

Speaker: NA
Text: damage. The bombs that fell on Hiro-

Speaker: NA
Text: shima and Nagasaki inflicted compara-

Speaker: NA
Text: -. tively few casualties. The present popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation of Japan is the greatest on record

Speaker: NA
Text: and is increasing at the rate of over

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr 1,000,000 people a year. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members that Japan occupies

Speaker: NA
Text: an area only one-twenty-fifth of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia whose population of 8,000,000 is

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing all too slowly-an d here I come

Speaker: NA
Text: lo the point from which I set out. Whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: war may be averted, the danger that

Speaker: NA
Text: arises from the uneven distribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: population, and particularly from the

Speaker: NA
Text: ambit. tremendous increase of population ih

Speaker: NA
Text: the densely congested nations of the east,

Speaker: NA
Text: must inevitably create a situation full of

Speaker: NA
Text: menace to this country. The present

Speaker: NA
Text: population of Japan is 80,000,000, and

Speaker: NA
Text: is, as I have said, increasing at the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of over 1,000,000 annually. I t has now

Speaker: NA
Text: reached saturation point. Japan can

Speaker: NA
Text: hold no more because she can feed no

Speaker: NA
Text: more, but still the increase of population

Speaker: NA
Text: continues. Where are those surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: millions to go? Where can they find a

Speaker: NA
Text: country at once so inviting and so

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable as Australia? What armed

Speaker: NA
Text: forces have we that can stop them?

Speaker: NA
Text: I t may 'be that the Japanese will

Speaker: NA
Text: not come with arms in their hands, 'but

Speaker: NA
Text: will knock at the door of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations, demanding a place in the sun

Speaker: NA
Text: and an opportunity to build homes in

Speaker: NA
Text: our country. Since the Japanese are

Speaker: NA
Text: human beings, what can the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations say? They have the right

Speaker: NA
Text: to live. That body will deal out

Speaker: NA
Text: even-handed justice. I t can afford

Speaker: NA
Text: to regard this matter from a detached

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view. Fifty-four nations are

Speaker: NA
Text: people. represented in that body, but only

Speaker: NA
Text: four or five of them are able to strike

Speaker: NA
Text: an effective blow for anything, including

Speaker: NA
Text: their own defence. But they may decide

Speaker: NA
Text: our fate. However, i f the Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: come with arms in their hands, we can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not stop them. The days of isolation

Speaker: NA
Text: are gone. We have to play our part

Speaker: NA
Text: in the full spotlight of the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is looking on. The world will

Speaker: NA
Text: say: " Here is a people who will neither

Speaker: NA
Text: populate their country nor allow others

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so ". 1 have not the time nor the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity now to discuss our White

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia policy; i t is enough for me to

Speaker: NA
Text: say, " I am for a White Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: policy ".

Speaker: NA
Text: M'r. CALWELL -Bu t

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: I know that the of

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister supports the White Australia incident with eastern countries and their

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, but I remind him that only yesterrulers.

Speaker: NA
Text: day a gentleman was appointed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian National University who

Speaker: NA
Text: acquired notoriety because of a book that administered.

Speaker: NA
Text: he wrote advocating that the White Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia policy should be whittled down. I and the same law.

Speaker: NA
Text: am not 'one of - those persons who

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to the White Australia policy.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Som e members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman's party are

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to it.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Neve r mind about my

Speaker: NA
Text: party. Let the Minister look at his own

Speaker: NA
Text: party. We all are affected by those

Speaker: NA
Text: whom we sleep.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Tha t is right.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: I know what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said against the Communists. I

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that his criticisms were very good.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, I could have said those things

Speaker: NA
Text: myself. But a day or so later, when

Speaker: NA
Text: he is tackled in this chamber, he says

Speaker: NA
Text: that he will not prevent Australian Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munists from going to Moscow. He claims

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have the right to be given a pass-

Speaker: NA
Text: port, and that he will grant them pass-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports. The Communists are emissaries of

Speaker: NA
Text: Satan, and the Minister sends them out

Speaker: NA
Text: to do Satan's work.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Wh y did the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman try to bribe them

Speaker: NA
Text: with government money?

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Oh , go on!

Speaker: NA
Text: The DEPUTY CHAIBM AN ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke) -Order ! The right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney is being led Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: away from the subject of immigration.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Immigratio n is inex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plicably linked with the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, and the maintenance of the kind of policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that we have to-day. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister that Australia embodied the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of White Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration Bestriction Act, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: passed in 1901, and for nearly half a

Speaker: NA
Text: century that legislation worked so effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tively and smoothly that when he came

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the scene, he found an Australia as

Speaker: NA
Text: " white " in 1945 as i t was in 1901.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: No .

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Wha t is more, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister found that the legislation had

Speaker: NA
Text: worked so smoothly that, during the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: that period, there had not been one

Speaker: NA
Text: Nearly every country in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world protests almost daily against the

Speaker: NA
Text: has manner in which this policy is being

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I t is the same policy,

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Al l that the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman does is to shut out Mrs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Annie O'Keefe, or Mrs Somebody Else.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Perhap s Mr Hughes.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Th e Minister may

Speaker: NA
Text: nofc realize that for many years, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: in control of immigration, and I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: with bother about what Mrs So-and-So did

Speaker: NA
Text: or did not do.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: O f course not!

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Afte r nearly 50 years

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was as white as i t was on the

Speaker: NA
Text: day on which the act was passed. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were not involved in incidents with

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign countries. India, China and

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan made no complaint to us about the

Speaker: NA
Text: manner in which we were administering

Speaker: NA
Text: the law. We got on smoothly with them.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: N o country has ever

Speaker: NA
Text: complained to the Commonwealth about

Speaker: NA
Text: the administration of the immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: law.

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Text: Wha t about the Philip-

Speaker: NA
Text: pines ?

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: Th e Philippines have

Speaker: NA
Text: never complained.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Th e proof of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pudding is in the eating. After 45 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: was as " white " as it was on the

Speaker: NA
Text: day the act was passed.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: An d that is when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ausright honorable gentleman deserted the

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Oh ! For some in-

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutable reason, the Minister has been

Speaker: NA
Text: permitted by providence to intrude into

Speaker: NA
Text: this sphere, and somehow, he is like the

Speaker: NA
Text: fly on the wheel. The wheel is turning,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the fly says, " I am turning i t " .

Speaker: NA
Text: But that is not the position. I heard the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Post-war Reconstruction

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Dedman) speak about our defences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taking him all in all, I hope that we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall never see his like again.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: H e will be here for a

Speaker: NA
Text: long time yet.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he will or not, just as I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know whether or not the Minister will he

Speaker: NA
Text: here for a long time.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: W e shall outlive the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman here.

Speaker: NA
Text: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN" -Order !

Speaker: NA
Text: There are too many interjections.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: I should miss the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman i f he were not here.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point that I desire to make is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are in no position to defend this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Indeed, we have never been in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to defend this country from

Speaker: NA
Text: aggression by a major power. Had it

Speaker: NA
Text: not been for the efforts of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America in World War II . ,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should have been undone; and had

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan been permitted to settle its

Speaker: NA
Text: nationals in New Guinea, we should have

Speaker: NA
Text: been undone anyhow. War may be

Speaker: NA
Text: averted, but there is danger i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: congested populations of the eastern

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in particular. For those surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: millions, there is no escape from death by

Speaker: NA
Text: starvation save by migration. They must

Speaker: NA
Text: find a way out, and I ask again where

Speaker: NA
Text: can they go but to Australia? What

Speaker: NA
Text: do we intend to do to prevent them?

Speaker: NA
Text: Without powerful friends we cannot hope

Speaker: NA
Text: to defend the country against them.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must populate and develop this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, and so order ourselves that

Speaker: NA
Text: the world will say, " The Australians are

Speaker: NA
Text: a people worthy of their freedom and of

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to the unfettered control of this

Speaker: NA
Text: great country, because they are carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: on as civilized people". Every nation

Speaker: NA
Text: has the right to say who shall come in

Speaker: NA
Text: and who shall not come in, but a well-

Speaker: NA
Text: bred, civilized people do not slam the

Speaker: NA
Text: in the face of migrants, and let it be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen that they think that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: superior to the nationals of other coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries. We are now to play our part under

Speaker: NA
Text: the spotlight on the world stage before

Speaker: NA
Text: nations of the world. Therefore, we must

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we shall be able, first to

Speaker: NA
Text: defend this country to the best of our

Speaker: NA
Text: ability, and, secondly, to develop its

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and absorb assimilable people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister is trying to do that, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend him for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now desire to make another point. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to hold this country we must

Speaker: NA
Text: populate and defend it. We must look to

Speaker: NA
Text: our defence forces. I ' believe in the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of a free people governing them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. We in this country have attained

Speaker: NA
Text: the widest measure of freedom of any

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the world. We enjoy our

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic parliamentary, institutions,

Speaker: NA
Text: although mark you, they are threatened

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Labour party.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Order !

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable gentleman's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr HAYLEN
Text: Parkes) [12.8] -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney ( Mr Hughes) is worth listening

Speaker: NA
Text: to on the subject of migration. I n fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: I listened to him with bated breath,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I suppose that he is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: spectacular British migrant that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: ever had in this country; but his in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cursions into the field of migration

Speaker: NA
Text: during thie debate were extremely limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: He yielded to his well-known political

Speaker: NA
Text: cunning to traverse such subjects as the

Speaker: NA
Text: birth-rate, the defence of Australia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations, the White Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: policy and population trends, the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the inland, the future of New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea, the possibility of another inva-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, and communism.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Al l of those are asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated subjects.

Speaker: Mr HAYLEN
Text: The y all are asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated subjects. I pay a tribute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman for having-

Speaker: NA
Text: made the hest use of his time, and, i f as he

Speaker: NA
Text: said, the sea is dotted with craft which-

Speaker: NA
Text: are bringing British migrants to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, who knows but that there may be-

Speaker: NA
Text: on the bounding ocean other right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: door able members for North Sydney who will

Speaker: NA
Text: give us the benefit of their services in time

Speaker: NA
Text: to come. That appears to he the best

Speaker: NA
Text: answer, the unpolitical answer, to any

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism of the immigration scheme. To-

Speaker: NA
Text: the refer back to the period from 1910 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1914 and attempt to prove, by a group of"

Speaker: NA
Text: figures unrelated to any other period,

Speaker: NA
Text: that that was the era of the high tide in

Speaker: NA
Text: the golden age of immigration and that,

Speaker: NA
Text: comparatively speaking, there is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: trickle of immigrants to-day, is of no

Speaker: NA
Text: avail. I f we accept the period from 1910

Speaker: NA
Text: to 1914 for the purposes of comparison

Speaker: NA
Text: with the present, we must also take into

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration factors that were not men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned hy the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney. Immigrants in those days

Speaker: NA
Text: were put on ships at the expense of either

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government or the Tjnited

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom Government and were tumbled

Speaker: NA
Text: out on the wharfs of Sydney, Melbourne,

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide, Fremantle and other ports and

Speaker: NA
Text: left to fend for themselves. The result of

Speaker: NA
Text: that policy was that, as the swelling tide

Speaker: NA
Text: had poured on to the wharfs and landing

Speaker: NA
Text: stages, so eventually many of the immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grants flooded the social welfare camps

Speaker: NA
Text: during the depression.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any man who did any social work dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the depression will realize that the

Speaker: NA
Text: poor little immigrant, who had been badly

Speaker: NA
Text: selected in the first place without any

Speaker: NA
Text: aptitude tests or anything of that sort, was

Speaker: NA
Text: the first one to go into our " Happy

Speaker: NA
Text: Valleys" and other such centres, where

Speaker: NA
Text: he was given the dole, some clothing and

Speaker: NA
Text: the lowest level of comfort. There can

Speaker: NA
Text: be no proper comparison 'between

Speaker: NA
Text: the two schemes in terms of numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: alone. Humanitarian treatment must

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken into account as well. Other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise, the comparison is too remote

Speaker: NA
Text: even to be considered. I n 1914,

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration was looked upon by the

Speaker: NA
Text: idealists as a means of increasing our

Speaker: NA
Text: population and developing the country

Speaker: NA
Text: for its eventual preservation and progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t was also looked upon by others calmly

Speaker: NA
Text: and coldly, with the business-like eye of

Speaker: NA
Text: the man looking for cheap labour in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to break down workers' standards and

Speaker: NA
Text: destroy unionism. That made an ugly

Speaker: NA
Text: story. To-day we accept immigration as

Speaker: NA
Text: a subject above politics. I have always

Speaker: NA
Text: considered that repatriation, immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and two or three other subjects

Speaker: NA
Text: should be lifted above the level of politics,

Speaker: NA
Text: though not, of course, exempted from

Speaker: NA
Text: political discussion. Unfortunately, the

Speaker: NA
Text: tributes that are paid to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Immigration ( Mr Calwell) by

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite are of

Speaker: NA
Text: a "yes hut- " character.

Speaker: NA
Text: body admits that the honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: n-an has done a splendid job in the

Speaker: NA
Text: face of competition from other countries,

Speaker: NA
Text: notably South Africa, New Zealand, and

Speaker: NA
Text: various .South American States. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite say, " Yes,

Speaker: NA
Text: he has done a good job, but he has failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to do this or that".

Speaker: NA
Text: They link the arrival of immigrants

Speaker: NA
Text: with the White Australia policy and

Speaker: NA
Text: declare that the Minister has not handled

Speaker: NA
Text: that policy effectively. I consider that

Speaker: NA
Text: his outlook upon both immigration and

Speaker: NA
Text: the White Australia policy has been ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptionally broad and statesmanlike.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite criticism from various sources, he

Speaker: NA
Text: has proved himself to be a great Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian in these matters. When, our pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent immigration scheme was commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1945, our chances of obtaining new

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens from a bruised and broken

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe and from an England engrossed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the problems of reconstruction

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared to be almost hopeless. There

Speaker: NA
Text: is no royal road to success with immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. We cannot wait until we have

Speaker: NA
Text: empty houses and everything else in

Speaker: NA
Text: readiness for immigrants. Nevertheless,

Speaker: NA
Text: the only thing that has been lacking has

Speaker: NA
Text: been adequate accommodation. Courage

Speaker: NA
Text: and statesmanship have enabled us to

Speaker: NA
Text: go ahead and to use the services of new

Speaker: NA
Text: arrivals in providing the things that we

Speaker: NA
Text: lack. Prospective immigrants are frankly

Speaker: NA
Text: told the truth about conditions in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The story of this immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme is one of the post-war epics. The

Speaker: NA
Text: project has been carried out efficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: and magnificently in spite of failures

Speaker: NA
Text: that have occurred elsewhere and in spite

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reluctance of people in Europe to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake the long trek to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have overcome indecisions and the

Speaker: NA
Text: doubts of trade unions in Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: about mass immigration. Immigrant

Speaker: NA
Text: ships are leaving for Australia in increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing numbers, and the estimated net

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration figure for this year is

Speaker: NA
Text: 148,000. I n view of the shortages that

Speaker: NA
Text: were caused by six years of war, that

Speaker: NA
Text: figure represents a magnificent achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The difficulties involved in the immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration scheme are not confined to those of

Speaker: NA
Text: Everytransporting people to Australia, but

Speaker: NA
Text: most of them have been satisfactorily

Speaker: NA
Text: overcome. As the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Worth Sydney has said, we must

Speaker: NA
Text: anticipate certain new .problems. For

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the migration of people under

Speaker: NA
Text: the auspices of the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Eelief Organization will eventu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally cease. From what other source will

Speaker: NA
Text: we be able to obtain migrants? Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people suggest Germany, Scandinavia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Norway. There are many reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: why it will be difficult to persuade people

Speaker: NA
Text: to come to Australia from those countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, we shall be obliged to turn

Speaker: NA
Text: to the surplus population of Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain. One of the really difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions that must be made relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of British migrants that will

Speaker: NA
Text: come to Australia. I predict that the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers will grow and that the propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of British immigrants to other Euro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pean immigrants will become considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: higher during the next ten years than it

Speaker: NA
Text: is now. That will be all to our advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian attitude towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: nomination of British immigrants poses

Speaker: NA
Text: an administrative problem of which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is well aware. The nomination

Speaker: NA
Text: of an immigrant, imposes a sacred duty.

Speaker: NA
Text: The nominator takes upon himself and

Speaker: NA
Text: his family the responsibility of provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for the accommodation of an immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: grant or a number of immigrants without

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting the housing of native-born

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. .Should the nomination

Speaker: NA
Text: system break down, as the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: insincerity on the part of nominators or

Speaker: NA
Text: nominees, bad feeling would be created

Speaker: NA
Text: and the scheme would be seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: prejudiced. At present, the nomination

Speaker: NA
Text: system is at the top of the news and is

Speaker: NA
Text: being treated idealistically. Ex-servicebring

Speaker: NA
Text: men's organizations are sponsoring ship-

Speaker: NA
Text: loads of British immigrants. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsored ship to reach our shores was

Speaker: NA
Text: Somersetshire, which I met in Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the Minister for Immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I was particularly impressed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the good type of ex-serviceman that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned Sailors Soldiers and Airmen's

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial League of Australia is bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia. At the back of my mind

Speaker: NA
Text: is the fear that Australians will not stand

Speaker: NA
Text: up rigidly to their responsibilities as

Speaker: NA
Text: nominators. It will not be sufficient for

Speaker: NA
Text: a nominator merely to bring an English

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrant into his home, bed him down

Speaker: NA
Text: for a few weeks until he becomes

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Haylen.

Speaker: NA
Text: accustomed to his new surroundings and

Speaker: NA
Text: then tell him to try to find accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for himself. I f we want to make

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia a greater, economically stronger

Speaker: NA
Text: and more progressive part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire than it is now, Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: will supply the people that we need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t will be up to us to provide those people

Speaker: NA
Text: with an assurance of security of tenure,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we can do that only i f we adhere

Speaker: NA
Text: strictly to the nomination system. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is only fair to insist that the native Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian shall have preference in obtain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing housing accommodation, and the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has done so. I f new arrivals

Speaker: NA
Text: seek to break away from the nomination

Speaker: NA
Text: system and obtain houses which should

Speaker: NA
Text: be occupied by Australians, the system

Speaker: NA
Text: will break down. Then the Minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: face further problems. I f the nomination

Speaker: NA
Text: system fails, he will have to decide

Speaker: NA
Text: what kind of immigrants hc will bring

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia from Europe and what pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of new arrivals will be admitted

Speaker: NA
Text: from Great Britain. Those are the only

Speaker: NA
Text: potential flaws in the present scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney related the subject of immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the population tension i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: East, to the United Nations policy in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the open door for coloured

Speaker: NA
Text: peoples, and to other subjects that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been discussed in Australia for more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 years. Neither the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration nor the Government as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole has suggested that the immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion scheme provides the answer to our

Speaker: NA
Text: low birth-rate. Immigration is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary measure. However, it will

Speaker: NA
Text: many useful citizens to our shores.

Speaker: NA
Text: Up to date, the department has touched

Speaker: NA
Text: only the fringe of the potential field of

Speaker: NA
Text: recruitment. When the difficulties of

Speaker: NA
Text: transport are lessened, when Europe haa

Speaker: NA
Text: settled down, and when we can find ont

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly how many men and women are

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to come to Australia, great things

Speaker: NA
Text: can be done. Without being mealy-

Speaker: NA
Text: mouthed, we can pay a glowing tribute

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for having done great

Speaker: NA
Text: work for our country. At the same time,

Speaker: NA
Text: he has done a great deal to ease the

Speaker: NA
Text: tensions of population and reconstruction

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties that have caused a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: of disturbance in Great Britain. Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parisons with the past or speculations

Speaker: NA
Text: about tbe future are futile. The Governbeliefs

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's migration scheme is based, not on

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers, but on humanity. Immigrants,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon their arrival in Australia, are

Speaker: NA
Text: left to fend for themselves, so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: weaker will go to the wall and the zation

Speaker: NA
Text: stronger succeed. That policy might

Speaker: NA
Text: have been accepted in the 'nineties, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia to-day would

Speaker: NA
Text: stand for it. Our immigration policy

Speaker: NA
Text: geared to humanitarianism, and i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: being applied efficiently.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a matter touching the adminisated

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of the Department of Immigraand

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to which I , in justice to certain

Speaker: NA
Text: sons outside the Parliament, should refer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eecently, the Minister appointed, with

Speaker: NA
Text: my congratulations and those of many

Speaker: NA
Text: other Australians both inside and outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the , Parliament, a planning committee

Speaker: NA
Text: tc. arrange accommodation and employbeen

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for immigrants. I t was decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: utilize for this purpose some of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: business brains in Australia, and I pay

Speaker: NA
Text: a tribute to those who have co-operated

Speaker: NA
Text: so willingly. However, some newspapers

Speaker: NA
Text: took it for granted that the Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: Advisory Council, of which I am chairthe

Speaker: NA
Text: man, had been disbanded. The honortical

Speaker: NA
Text: a'ble member for Eeid ( Mr Lang) writMinister

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the Century, that little journal

Speaker: NA
Text: which he produces for his own amusego

Speaker: NA
Text: ment--becaus e it has no circulation and

Speaker: NA
Text: no prestige-announce d that the chaircountry,

Speaker: NA
Text: man of the Immigration Advisory Counoperate

Speaker: NA
Text: cil had been sacked. Perhaps he felt

Speaker: NA
Text: that, as the leading figure in one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest sacking incidents in the history

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, when he was sacked from

Speaker: NA
Text: his job as Premier of New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: one bright, summer morning by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor of that State, he was qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: to offer an opinion on the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: sacking. His comments are immaterial

Speaker: NA
Text: to me except insofar as they affect other

Speaker: NA
Text: memlbers of the council, which includes

Speaker: NA
Text: business men in Melbourne, Canberra,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sydney, and representatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations of ex-servicemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: council consists of a group of persons

Speaker: NA
Text: with an instinct for planning and organiter's

Speaker: NA
Text: zation, who were gathered together to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist our immigration policy when it

Speaker: NA
Text: was first put into operation. I t would

Speaker: NA
Text: o

Speaker: NA
Text: be callous on my part not to make it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have done a magnificent job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although' many of them hold political

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposite of my own, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been completely loyal and tireless in their

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts to make the immigration policy

Speaker: NA
Text: not work. I have in mind particularly Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Oberg, who, being president of an organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: of employers is not of my political

Speaker: NA
Text: kidney. No one could have received

Speaker: NA
Text: more loyal support or co-operation than

Speaker: NA
Text: not I did from him when we were investi-

Speaker: NA
Text: is gating migration problems in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom and continental Europe. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Wilkins, former secretary of the Associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: Chambers of Commerce of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr L. Withall, secretary of the Asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: perciated Chambers of Manufactures of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. There are also on the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee members of the armed services

Speaker: NA
Text: who had grave problems to consider in

Speaker: NA
Text: connexion with. the admission of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: enemies. Although their feelings had

Speaker: NA
Text: bruised by their war-time contacts

Speaker: NA
Text: with ex-enemy nationals, they did a mag-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificent job as members of the Immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Advisory Council. I t i l l becomes a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of this Parliament, who happens

Speaker: NA
Text: to conduct a newspaper, to assail any of

Speaker: NA
Text: the members of the council. I f only for

Speaker: NA
Text: reason that the council has no poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: affiliations, I am glad that the

Speaker: NA
Text: for Immigration has stated

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly that the work of the council will

Speaker: NA
Text: on. Members of the council have a

Speaker: NA
Text: fine feeling for the future welfare of their

Speaker: NA
Text: and an intense willingness to co-

Speaker: NA
Text: in furthering the country's immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration policy. Those qualities are too

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable to be lost, and I take this oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to place on record my tribute to the

Speaker: NA
Text: work done by members of the council.

Speaker: NA
Text: A' tremendous amount of work remains

Speaker: NA
Text: to be done in the field of immigration.

Speaker: NA
Text: of Neither the Opposition in this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, nor any other section of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people, is justified in attacking

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Immigration for his

Speaker: NA
Text: rigid administration of the Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: Act. I t is all very well to make exclu-

Speaker: NA
Text: The sions into spirituality and liberalism-

Speaker: NA
Text: spelt with a small " 1"-bu t the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: job is to administer the law. I f too

Speaker: NA
Text: much publicity has been given to the way

Speaker: NA
Text: in which the law has been administered,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is the fault not of the Minister but of

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have seized on the situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to obtain cheap, emotional effects.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clergymen have decorated their sermons

Speaker: NA
Text: with appeals about humanity, when next

Speaker: NA
Text: door are seething slums, the inhabitants

Speaker: NA
Text: of which are much closer to them than

Speaker: NA
Text: are the evacuees who are being sent back

Speaker: NA
Text: to their own countries in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: an arrangement into which they them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves entered. I t is beside the point for

Speaker: NA
Text: people, who adopt a hypocritical, super-

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive attitude to the White Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia policy to charge the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter with committing an administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive faux pas. Such attacks may do very

Speaker: NA
Text: well for a press story or to adorn a sermon

Speaker: NA
Text: but deep in the hearts of all Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: is a feeling that we should make no con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cession on the White Australia policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney reminded us of his 50 years' ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: perience in this Parliament, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: repeated what had been said at various

Speaker: NA
Text: times during that period. I claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have much to show for our immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion policy, and we have a plan for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. That policy is our answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: call of the empty spaces of this continent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government, in its application of the

Speaker: NA
Text: White Australia policy, is applying the

Speaker: NA
Text: law, and adhering to tradition. Erom the

Speaker: NA
Text: first days of federation, the settled policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia has been to keep Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: free and white.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Richmond) [12.27].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Immigratio n ought to be a non-party

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in this Parliament, and it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been treated substantially in that way. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: general, the policy of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration ( Mr Calwell), in taking

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage of the unique opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain a large flow of immigrants from

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, has met with the approval of

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members of all parties. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that if the forthcoming general elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion should result in a change of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, tbe same policy will be continued,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we all recognize the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: populate and develop the country. Hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing regard to the changed attitude towards

Speaker: NA
Text: population among the white races, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for us to increase our numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: by bringing here surplus population from

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is a great pity, however, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should have thought it necessary,

Speaker: NA
Text: in administering his department, to bethe

Speaker: NA
Text: have as he has towards the very few

Speaker: NA
Text: Asiatics, or persons of Asiatic extraction,

Speaker: NA
Text: who were resident in Australia. This

Speaker: NA
Text: handful of persons has been the cause of

Speaker: NA
Text: much dissension and international i l l

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling. The Minister's treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: them has appeared to put us in the

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong, and has earned for us a reputa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for being harsh and intransigent on

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of colour, and has done noth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to strengthen the White Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: policy or obtain acceptance for it. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: has highliehted the objection to colour

Speaker: NA
Text: that is inherent in the White Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, and publicized that objection to our

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage throughout the world, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in Asiatic countries. On more

Speaker: NA
Text: than one occasion the Minister himself

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that the term " White Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia " should not be used, yet he has

Speaker: NA
Text: made use of it more than any one else.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret that his fine record in developing

Speaker: NA
Text: migration from Europe should be marred

Speaker: NA
Text: by these incidents which, in themselves,,

Speaker: NA
Text: are of a minor nature. I n one instance

Speaker: NA
Text: a few persons may be involved, or in

Speaker: NA
Text: another instance 27 Chinese, or indivi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dual persons as in the case of Mrs Ang

Speaker: NA
Text: and that of Mrs O'Keefe. Those inci-

Speaker: NA
Text: dents do not really amount to anything-

Speaker: NA
Text: in our immigration policy, and the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment should exercise a little dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cretion in matters of that kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dealing with the proposed vote for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of External Territories

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to discuss what I consider to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the very harsh and unsympathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment that the Government has meted

Speaker: NA
Text: out to widows of civilians who lost thei*-

Speaker: NA
Text: lives when the Japanese captured Rabaul.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is well-known that the lives of practi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally all civilians who were at Rabaul

Speaker: NA
Text: at the time the Japanese attacked were

Speaker: NA
Text: wilfully thrown away by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. I say " w i l f u l l y " because-

Speaker: NA
Text: those civilians had no hope pf defending-

Speaker: NA
Text: Rabaul. I am not now talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: the armed forces. At that time there was

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient shipping in the harbour to-

Speaker: NA
Text: evacuate the civilian population, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Curtin Government ordered that those

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians should remain at Rabaul. The-

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Administrator of New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: radioed to Australia to obtain permission

Speaker: NA
Text: to evacuate those civilians, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: request was refused. Consequently, when

Speaker: NA
Text: J apanese struck, many of the civilians

Speaker: NA
Text: were killed whilst the remainder were-

Speaker: NA
Text: captured. I n the fullness of time their

Speaker: NA
Text: fate was revealed. Ultimately, after a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable period, it was discovered

Speaker: NA
Text: that a great many of those who survived

Speaker: NA
Text: the Japanese attack lost their lives when

Speaker: NA
Text: Montevideo Maru was sunk. During the

Speaker: NA
Text: period that their fate remained unknown,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government made liberal payments to

Speaker: NA
Text: widows of male civilians on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: -of tlie salary that the latter had been

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving. However, when hostilities

Speaker: NA
Text: -ended an accounting was made to those

Speaker: NA
Text: widows and in each instance where it was

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, to get back money paid to them

Speaker: NA
Text: in excess of the ordinary pension rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: from £2 10s. a week the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: took action to recover such moneys. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: some instances it did so by making deduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions from payments that the widows

Speaker: NA
Text: were entitled to draw as superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits for which their late husbands

Speaker: NA
Text: had contributed. I am in possession

Speaker: NA
Text: of several statements issued by the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of External Territories that show

Speaker: NA
Text: that some of these widows, instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving a very substantial amount, in

Speaker: NA
Text: some cases hundreds of pounds, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: form of superannuation benefit, received

Speaker: NA
Text: practically nothing at all after these

Speaker: NA
Text: -deductions had been made by the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment. I trust that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will see that justice is done to these

Speaker: NA
Text: widows, and I propose to show how

Speaker: NA
Text: it can do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, however, I draw attention par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly to the case of Captain H .

Speaker: NA
Text: Edwards, M.C, D.O.M., M.M., whose

Speaker: NA
Text: widow now lives in Sydney. Captain

Speaker: NA
Text: Edwards had a distinguished military

Speaker: NA
Text: record in World War I . I read the

Speaker: NA
Text: following quotation from a letter that

Speaker: NA
Text: he received from General Birdwood:-

Speaker: NA
Text: I must congratulate you on your excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: record of which you may well be proud i n

Speaker: NA
Text: having gained the M i l i t a r y Cross, Distin-

Speaker: NA
Text: guished Conduct Medal, and Militar y Medal.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is indeed a fine achievement .and I trust

Speaker: NA
Text: that you w i l l meet with still further success

Speaker: NA
Text: i n the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: -Captain Edwards's brigade commander

Speaker: NA
Text: wrote to him as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: I trust that you w i l l be long spared to wear

Speaker: NA
Text: those ribbons. They betoken a spendid record

Speaker: NA
Text: of great hardships and dangers and adherence

Speaker: NA
Text: to duty under all circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like to tell honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: how the Government treated the widow

Speaker: NA
Text: of that gallant officer. He was at Rabaul

Speaker: NA
Text: at the time that the Japanese struck.

Speaker: NA
Text: He had been residing there for many

Speaker: NA
Text: years previously and was second in com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mand of the New Guinea Volunteer

Speaker: NA
Text: Regiment a few months before the Japa-

Speaker: NA
Text: nese invasion. He was president of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Rabaul branch of the Returned Sailors,

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers and Airmen's Imperial League

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. However, because at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of invasion he was not i n military

Speaker: NA
Text: uniform as the result of some dispute that

Speaker: NA
Text: had occurred between himself and others

Speaker: NA
Text: in the military forces at Rabaul, he was

Speaker: NA
Text: not considered to have been a soldier at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of his death. Consequently,

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the fact that the estate of any-

Speaker: NA
Text: body who died as a soldier was exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: from estate duty, Mrs Edwards was

Speaker: NA
Text: charged duty amounting to £67 on her

Speaker: NA
Text: husband's estate which was valued at

Speaker: NA
Text: £700. She had to pay that duty because

Speaker: NA
Text: her husband was not considered to have

Speaker: NA
Text: been a soldier at the time of his death.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am in possession of the documents in

Speaker: NA
Text: the case and I shall be pleased to pass

Speaker: NA
Text: them on to the Minister. I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the following provision, which is set out

Speaker: NA
Text: in a letter which Mrs Edwards has

Speaker: NA
Text: received from Mr Clive Evatt, a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in the New South Wales Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: should apply in this instance-

Speaker: NA
Text: No death duty shall be payable in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the estate of a member of the naval, military

Speaker: NA
Text: or air forces of the Commonwealth of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia . . . who during the present war

Speaker: NA
Text: between His Majesty the K i ng and Germany

Speaker: NA
Text: and her allies or within one year after its

Speaker: NA
Text: termination dies on active service or as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of injury received or disease contracted

Speaker: NA
Text: on active service.

Speaker: NA
Text: Captain Edwards was at Rabaul when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese struck. He was the most

Speaker: NA
Text: highly decorated soldier at Rabaul and

Speaker: NA
Text: he lost his life because the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: refused permission for civilians to be

Speaker: NA
Text: evacuated. Because he was not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered to have been a soldier at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: of his death, his widow has had to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: the penalty. She has also been denied

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of pension payable to the widow

Speaker: NA
Text: of an officer, which is considerably more

Speaker: NA
Text: than that payable to widows of civilians.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government can do justice in this

Speaker: NA
Text: case. Evidence given in the New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: timber leases case revealed that the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister can apply the provisions of an

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinance retrospectively. The particular

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinance cited in that case was Ordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nance No. 5 of 1947, being " an ordinance

Speaker: NA
Text: to amend the Workers' Compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordinances 1941 of the Territory of New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea ". That ordinance increased the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of maximum compensation from

Speaker: NA
Text: £750 to £1,000. I t was dated the 14th

Speaker: NA
Text: May, 1947, under the signature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General and issued by " E. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ward, Minister of State for External

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories ". I n evidence given during

Speaker: NA
Text: r.he New Guinea timber leases case it

Speaker: NA
Text: was stated that one person who was favor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably affected by the back-dating of that

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinance was a friend, or relative, of the about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for External Territories. A

Speaker: NA
Text: notable feature of the amendment effected

Speaker: NA
Text: by that ordinance was that its commence-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was made retrospective to the lst

Speaker: NA
Text: January, 1947; that is, it was back-

Speaker: NA
Text: dated five months in order, so it was

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged in evidence given in the New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea timber leases case, to cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances of a friend, or relative, of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for External Territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no evidence to offer in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of that statement except the evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: was given in the course of the trial that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have mentioned. However, in view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts I have given I shall not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is not possible for the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to do justice to the widows of

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians who lost their lives when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese captured Rabaul. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: civilians were at Rabaul as the represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives of Australia. I shall not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government cannot recognize

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Edwards's, claim and refund the

Speaker: NA
Text: death duty that has been charged to her

Speaker: NA
Text: on account of the estate of her husband,

Speaker: NA
Text: or that she cannot be given the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension payable to the widow of an officer,

Speaker: NA
Text: because her case has been settled. I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: not accept these excuses when I find that

Speaker: NA
Text: remedial action can be taken to benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody who happens to enjoy a

Speaker: NA
Text: favoured position with the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are facts.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: The y do not get all their

Speaker: NA
Text: pension entitlement.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: The y get children's

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I am prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce to the Minister for Repatriacivilians

Speaker: NA
Text: tion ( Mr Barnard) a deputation of the war.

Speaker: NA
Text: widows of NewGuinea civilians.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am prepared to introduce him during

Speaker: NA
Text: to Mrs Edwards and I am preber

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to show him the commendations

Speaker: NA
Text: for gallantry of Captain Edwards by

Speaker: NA
Text: King, General Birdwood and General

Speaker: NA
Text: Rawlinson. Captain Edwards has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been treated as a soldier under the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Soldiers' Repatriation Act. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is the first opportunity that I have had

Speaker: NA
Text: of ventilating this matter for a very long

Speaker: NA
Text: time. The consideration of the Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: was " guillotined " last year, and I had

Speaker: NA
Text: no opportunity to ventilate it then.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now that I have ventilated it, I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government will do something

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: Adelaide-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Army) [12.41] - I feel that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Army is involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the case of Captain Edwards, who,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond ( Mr Anthony), took an active

Speaker: NA
Text: part in the defence of Rabaul when Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: struck there.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: H e was second in

Speaker: NA
Text: command of the New Guinea Volunteer

Speaker: NA
Text: Regiment.

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: Yes. . Apparently,,

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole case has been based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that he was not in uniform at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time. That involves my department.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the first I have heard of the

Speaker: NA
Text: case. I shall discuss it with the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member between now and the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the week. I should be glad if the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member would supply me with the

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant documents. I propose to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the case investigated by my own depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I will investigate it myself. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: there is any substance in the comments

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable gentleman and an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: justice has been done to the widow of

Speaker: NA
Text: Captain Edwards, the proper procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: will be followed, and the injustice will be

Speaker: NA
Text: rectified.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Balaclava) [12.43] -A s

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 have insufficient time to deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Immigration and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of External Territories, I

Speaker: NA
Text: content myself with saying that I strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: support the remarks of the honorable-

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Richmond ( Mr Anthony)

Speaker: NA
Text: about the treatment of the widows of

Speaker: NA
Text: killed in New Guinea during the

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Barnard), who was interjecting

Speaker: NA
Text: the speech of the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: for Richmond, knows that a few-

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago I asked why the widows and

Speaker: NA
Text: the dependants of men who had lost their

Speaker: NA
Text: Uvea i n the civil service of New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: had not received f u l l repatriation benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: I asked that he confer with the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for External Territories on the subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know on which Minister the

Speaker: NA
Text: blame lies, but I do know that i t lies on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governinent as a whole. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter knows that the widows of those men

Speaker: NA
Text: do not receive medical benefits; although

Speaker: NA
Text: war widows do. They do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to obtain a war

Speaker: NA
Text: service home, although war widows

Speaker: NA
Text: do. Those are just two instances

Speaker: NA
Text: of the disparity between the treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of those widows and

Speaker: NA
Text: widows. I hope that there w i ll be no

Speaker: NA
Text: further equivocation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I applaud what the Minister fo r

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration ( Mr Calwell) has done to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring foreign migrants to Australia, but

Speaker: NA
Text: we must have a greater ratio of British

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke) -Order ! The time allotted fo r

Speaker: NA
Text: the consideration of the proposed votes

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Department of External Terri -

Speaker: NA
Text: tories and the Department of Immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has expired.

Text: Proposed votes agreed to.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Wentworth) [2.15].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Befor e attempting to approve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed vote for the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization, which includes the provi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of £33,000 f o r investigation of

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear energy, the committee should pay

Speaker: NA
Text: close attention to circumstances connected

Speaker: NA
Text: with this organization. Although the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has placed the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Scientific and Industrial Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization under administrative con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol of the Public Service Board, quite

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously i t is still clouded with a certain

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of suspicion. A t the recent con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference i n Canada i n relation to atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: energy research, although representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United States of America, Canada

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United Kingdom were present,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is significant that Australia was not

Speaker: NA
Text: war represented. That highlights certain

Speaker: NA
Text: matters that were revealed i n this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber not long ago when i t was shown

Speaker: NA
Text: that there still exists i n the minds of

Speaker: NA
Text: people associated with atomic energy

Speaker: NA
Text: research a grave suspicion that i f secret

Speaker: NA
Text: developments i n the field of nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: energy were made available to Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: that information might leak out to Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia. That was the basis of a lengthy

Speaker: NA
Text: debate during .which certain, documents

Speaker: NA
Text: were produced that caused an immense

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of public interest. I t seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that that suspicion still exists i n

Speaker: NA
Text: the minds of people overseas. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is still excluded f r o m the inner councils

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world powers i n relation to atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: research for purposes of defence. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is not to be wondered at. Although.,

Speaker: NA
Text: SERVICE. under pressure, the Government removed

Speaker: NA
Text: the aeronautical section of the Council

Speaker: NA
Text: for Scientific and Industrial Research

Speaker: NA
Text: f r o m its matrix and placed i t under

Speaker: NA
Text: the administration of the Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Board, suspicion has not been allayed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the minds of our allies overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: who are closely associated w i th us

Speaker: NA
Text: i n preserving the peace of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason is not hard to discover. From

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time honorable members have

Speaker: NA
Text: learned of the appointment of Commu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nists to what was the Council f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the Minister for Post-war

Speaker: NA
Text: Reconstruction ( Mr Dedman) did not

Speaker: NA
Text: select the appointees, he approved

Speaker: NA
Text: of their appointment. He approved of

Speaker: NA
Text: a studentship being granted to Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Kaiser, who was sent overseas to further

Speaker: NA
Text: his studies i n the field of nuclear physics.

Speaker: NA
Text: A fte r he had attended at Oxford U n i -

Speaker: NA
Text: versity for about eighteen months, i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed that he was a Communist. He

Speaker: NA
Text: distinguished himself by taking part in

Speaker: NA
Text: a demonstration of Communists at Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia House i n London while still a

Speaker: NA
Text: student and under the control of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Oommonwealth Scientific and Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Research. Organization. That was a

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration by Communists against the

Speaker: NA
Text: action that had been taken by this Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment in connexion with the coal

Speaker: NA
Text: strike. By taking part i n that demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: stration he revealed himself as a militant

Speaker: NA
Text: Communist.

Speaker: NA
Text: Erom time to time honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Government side of the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: have declared that every care is taken to

Speaker: NA
Text: screen persons before they are appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: to positions in connexion with defence

Speaker: NA
Text: work investigation, about which secrecy

Speaker: NA
Text: must be maintained. I t is apparent that

Speaker: NA
Text: either this man was not screened before

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment, or that he was appointed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government i n the ful l know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge that he was a Communist, and

Speaker: NA
Text: was then deliberately sent overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: to take part in nuclear investigation.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was reported to have been a research

Speaker: NA
Text: officer with the Council for Scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrial Research for six years in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. Indeed the Minister for Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: war Reconstruction told honorable mem'

Speaker: NA
Text: bers on another occasion that during the

Speaker: NA
Text: war period Mr Kaiser had been engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: on very close investigations of these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters, and that there was no reason

Speaker: NA
Text: to believe that he had divulged any

Speaker: NA
Text: secrets about them.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: I said distinctly that

Speaker: NA
Text: no information had ever been divulged.

Speaker: NA
Text: MT. HARRISON -Unles s the Minishad

Speaker: NA
Text: ter knew what had transpired within

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Russia, he could not be so definite

Speaker: NA
Text: in that regard. However, I accept his

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance. Possibly he has some knowrefused

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge of matters that have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: availahle to Soviet Russia and can make

Speaker: NA
Text: that assertion with some degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: accuracy. A person with no knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: of what matters had been disclosed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet espionage service would

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to be so emphatic in that

Speaker: NA
Text: regard. I accept the Minister's assurance

Speaker: NA
Text: that nothing was made available to Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia. Apparently tbe Minister forgets

Speaker: NA
Text: that during the war Soviet Russia was

Speaker: NA
Text: an ally of ours and that at that time there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no talk of atomic warfare involving

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia. A t that time, also, secret infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation was held jointly by the Soviet, \

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom. However, Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia is now conducting a cold war

Speaker: NA
Text: against its former allies, and, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Chifley) has said,

Speaker: NA
Text: is seeking by sinister disruptive methods

Speaker: NA
Text: to undermine the democracies, including

Speaker: NA
Text: remote Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following the demonstration to which

Speaker: NA
Text: I have referred Mr Kaiser is reported

Speaker: NA
Text: to have said in England-

Speaker: NA
Text: The C.S.I.E. knew my views before I was

Speaker: NA
Text: sent here.

Speaker: NA
Text: This, in spite of the fact that he had been

Speaker: NA
Text: sent overseas by the organization to learn

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: During the war period, there was an agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada and the United States of America

Speaker: NA
Text: to share information on the development

Text: deliberations, or to assist in the project.

Speaker: NA

Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that publication he does not tell about

Speaker: NA
Text: the thousands of ex-servicemen who did

Text: not receive the vocational training that

Text: been trained had reached saturation

Text: facts and the figures. Members of the

Text: Government are claiming that they have

Text: clone well by Australia, whereas they

Text: stances of high prices for our exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: to adjust the difficulties. I object

Speaker: NA
Text: unethical way in which the Government

Text: Immigration blandly smiles. He thinks

Text: it is all in the game. Looking after the

Text: people's money is not a game, but a

Text: of the Government was provided in the

Text: tion that the cost of the Government's

Text: propaganda in connexion with a recent

Text: referendum were met from the vote

Text: for Post-war Education. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment is soft-pedalling on socialism

Speaker: NA
Text: these days. I t is concentrating on issuing

Speaker: NA
Text: booklets designed to tell the people what

Speaker: NA
Text: splendid men the Commonwealth Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters are. I f those gentlemen get

Speaker: NA
Text: The by in the general election, they

Speaker: NA
Text: The

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth Electoral Act provides

Speaker: NA
Text: that that no honorable members shall

Speaker: NA
Text: lost make certain payments within three

Speaker: NA
Text: months of the general election with a

Speaker: NA
Text: of ensuring their re-election. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet Minister is shooting out

Speaker: NA
Text: t sheaves of booklets that have that very

Text: purpose. I refer also to the booklet deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with social services. Last week, I

Speaker: NA
Text: asked how many copies of the booklet had

Text: been ordered, what they had cost, and why

Text: were finding their way into the offices

Text: for any more copies were to be ordered. I

Text: and that their cost was £8,000 and that

Text: anotlier 500,000, which would also cost

Speaker: NA
Text: £8,000, had been ordered. The gist of the

Text: reply to a question about the booklets

Text: Labour organizations was: " We did not

Text: deliberately send them to Labour organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: I f they stamp ' Vote Labour ' all

Text: over them, that is their business ". I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: than their business; it is the business

Text: of thing should be stopped. Government

Text: propaganda has poured from the printing

Text: presses for the eight years in which

Speaker: NA
Text: ganda before the general election. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: be stopped and it certainly should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be paid for by the people.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: Fremantle) [3.19] -

Speaker: NA
Text: to the The honorable member for Balaclava

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr White) has referred to certain

Speaker: NA
Text: publications. His references were most

Text: I n what way?

Text: I am going to dis-

Text: cuss that. The honorable gentleman made

Speaker: NA
Text: a specific reference to a recent publication

Speaker: NA
Text: issued under the authority of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Works and Housing ( Mr Lemmon)

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled Homes for Australia. That pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lication makes it perfectly clear that hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: in i is tho joint responsibility of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tmlian Government and the State

Speaker: NA
Text: governments. The reference in it to

Text: housing in Western Australia makes it

Text: is made about the part played by

Text: the Australian Government in that

Text: State, other than that it makes a finan-

Text: cial contribution, which is a perfectly

Text: tr-aid ful statement. Actually, that
