Text: material could be regarded as propaganda

Speaker: NA
Text: for the State Government. I t is factual

Speaker: NA
Text: information and has no regard for poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical complexions. The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber said that the booklet on social

Speaker: NA
Text: services was Labour party propaganda.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at this alleged propaganda.

Speaker: NA
Text: On page 7 of the booklet it states-

Speaker: NA
Text: In that year the Scullin Government reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: the allowance to £4, and introduced a means

Speaker: NA
Text: test as to iiiconre.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it " good propaganda" for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour party to talk about reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: social services ? The booklet gives a truly

Speaker: NA
Text: objective picture of the age pension. Then

Speaker: NA
Text: it says-

Speaker: NA
Text: Child endowment was introduced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies Government. Payments commenced

Speaker: NA
Text: in July, 1941, at the rate of 5s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t traces the whole history of child endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in a factual manner. That is also

Speaker: NA
Text: true of unemployment benefit, sickness

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit, widows' pensions and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are certain sections in the

Speaker: NA
Text: booklet that show that widows' pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions and certain other social services

Speaker: NA
Text: came into being under the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. That is fact. As honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite know, a great many

Speaker: NA
Text: social services have been introduced in the

Speaker: NA
Text: eight years of the existence of the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. To say that is simply to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak the truth. The booklet cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as propaganda in favour of any

Speaker: NA
Text: political party. I t gives the historical

Speaker: NA
Text: background of social services. I t explains

Speaker: NA
Text: the means tost. No one could regard an

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation of the means test as good pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: paganda for the Labour party.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Wentworth

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Harrison) was again happy in his

Speaker: NA
Text: role of cloak-and-dagger expert for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Beazley.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition when he found out that a

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman named Kaiser had been sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tematically betraying secrets. He implied

Speaker: NA
Text: that the secrets' of the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had been betrayed by Kaiser to a

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign country. I have to agree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman that one must infer

Speaker: NA
Text: from Kaiser's demonstration in front of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia House over the coal strike that

Speaker: NA
Text: he is a Communist. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: sense in quibbling about that. Whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not it can be proved that he is a Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist, I do not know. All I know is that

Speaker: NA
Text: no section of the community other than

Speaker: NA
Text: the Communists disapproved of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment's actions in connexion with

Speaker: NA
Text: the coal strike. My point, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, is that while in the Tjnited

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, Kaiser worked in British insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tutions. No evidence has been produced

Speaker: NA
Text: by tbe honorable member for Wentworth

Speaker: NA
Text: that those institutions were dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: anything secret. But, i f they were, and

Speaker: NA
Text: he was betraying the secret details, he

Speaker: NA
Text: should have come under the surveillance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the British Intelligence Service. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know certain people who, ih Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: during the war, were not prosecuted but

Speaker: NA
Text: who, immediately they reached the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, were arrested. One of them

Speaker: NA
Text: was a gentleman on whose behalf honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite were vocal recently.

Speaker: NA
Text: He would be well advised to keep away

Speaker: NA
Text: from the United Kingdom. The fact is

Speaker: NA
Text: that if tliere were any real evidence con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning subversive activities by Kaiser

Speaker: NA
Text: he would be arrested in Britain and

Speaker: NA
Text: charged in that country with the offences

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged, because such activities would

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken place in British scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions. I t is fantastic to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that while Kaiser is resident in Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: he is under the jurisdiction of the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Defence ( Mr Dedman). I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to deal with that subject at any

Speaker: NA
Text: great length.

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire to ask the Minister for some

Text: of the proposed vote for the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Scientific and Industrial Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Organization. The honorable member for

Text: cized the proposed expenditure for

Text: scientific and industrial research.

Text: I ' wanted a

Speaker: NA
Text: greater expenditure.

Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber criticized the allocation of the expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture. He complained that not enough

Text: was to be expended on scientific research

Text: connected with primary industries. The

Text: eclipsed the record of governments that

Speaker: NA
Text: on scientific research has risen from

Speaker: NA
Text: £339,000 a year to more than £2,000,000

Text: a year. The honorable member for Wide

Text: Bay made absurd claims about expendi-

Text: ture on astronomy and made fantastic

Text: statements about other research work

Text: which is not actually carried out. He

Text: plant industry, soils and irrigation,

Speaker: NA
Text: products and other activities connected

Text: with agriculture. Plant industry, animal

Text: health and production account for pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed expenditures of more than £200,000

Text: each. Proposed expenditure under item

Speaker: NA
Text: 6 of Division 113, relating to forest

Speaker: NA
Text: products, is given as £142,600.

Text: In presenting these Estimates the Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister has not explained at any great

Speaker: NA
Text: length the expenditure proposed under

Speaker: NA
Text: item 16, section C, of Division 113,

Speaker: NA
Text: " Biochemistry and general nutrition ".

Speaker: NA
Text: That item apparently refers to an ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity distinct from animal nutrition. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Minister i f his department is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking over research into human nutri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and biochemistry. There have been

Speaker: NA
Text: references in scientific journals for some

Speaker: NA
Text: time to a new line of research in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion with the growth of food crops in

Speaker: NA
Text: tbeir relation to human nutrition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tn the past, emphasis has been

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on wheat and plant breeding and

Speaker: NA
Text: upon prolificity and milling qualities of

Speaker: NA
Text: grain. I n the United States of America,

Speaker: NA
Text: which leads the world in such research,

Speaker: NA
Text: the emphasis is now upon vitamins and

Speaker: NA
Text: the nutritional content of plants. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: rather remarkable results have been an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced by various universities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States. I should like to know to

Speaker: NA
Text: what, degree, if any, these lines of

Speaker: NA
Text: research are being pursued by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Scientific and Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search Organization.

Speaker: NA
Text: Item 8 of section C of Division 113

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns radio research. I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister to explain whether the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Scientific and Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search Organization is engaging in any

Speaker: NA
Text: research in relation to television, or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the radio research mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: refers only to research in connexion with

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian present radio facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Estimates indicate some analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: research into food preservation and trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port. Can the Minister say whether any

Speaker: NA
Text: research is taking place into the claims

Text: made on behalf of patent medicines, also

Text: into the claims that are advanced by the

Text: sellers of certain foodstuffs and certain

Text: tonics ? We very badly need an objective

Text: analysis to be made of many such claims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of the industries upon the products

Text: of which the public spends many

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of pounds

Speaker: NA
Text: foTest annually are regarded by doctors as

Text: being engaged in lines of manufacture

Speaker: NA
Text: that amount to absolute quackery. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me that some research should be

Text: made regarding such claims, and also

Text: that consideration should be given to the

Text: advisability of requesting the States,

Speaker: NA
Text: under whose jurisdiction this matter

Text: comes, to enact legislation to prohibit

Text: advertisements based on falsehoods, in

Speaker: NA
Text: cases where it has been established by

Speaker: NA
Text: research that the claims made in such

Speaker: NA
Text: advertisements are bogus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Item 24 concerns fuel research. No

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt, during the recent coal strike, many

Speaker: NA
Text: honorahle members received a brochure

Speaker: NA
Text: from a gentleman who claimed to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: process whereby coal could be burned with

Text: much greater efficiency and with much

Text: greater utilization of its heating qualities

Speaker: NA
Text: than is the case at present. He called it

Speaker: NA
Text: the "Anderson Process for Smokeless

Speaker: NA
Text: Fuel". I should like to know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: that claim was investigated. The gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man concerned asked for an analysis of

Speaker: NA
Text: his claims. There are many countries of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world where such a claim would, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure, receive some kind of public

Speaker: NA
Text: attention. I should like to know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Scientific and Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial Research Organization, which

Speaker: NA
Text: carries out tests for the manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: of tractors and other machinery, would

Speaker: NA
Text: also carry out tests into this man's claims

Text: which are either outrageous, or, if true,

Text: mean that he has discovered a process

Text: the value of which is important enough

Speaker: NA
Text: to be investigated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Items 1 and 2 of section D of Division

Speaker: NA
Text: 113 refer to the provision of a total of

Speaker: NA
Text: £31,120 for research associations and

Speaker: NA
Text: research studentships. I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: know how much of this amount is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: directed towards the tenure of scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ships in Britain. "We have a British

Speaker: NA
Text: fixation regarding many of our overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: scholarships, regardless of the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the initiative in many lines of scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: research has gone from Britain, which

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly led in that respect during

Speaker: NA
Text: the nineteenth century, to the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. I sliould like the Minister to give

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee some information on how

Speaker: NA
Text: much is to be made available notwith-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing dollar differences for the tenure

Speaker: NA
Text: of scholarships in the United States. An

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely open attitude is displayed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States in respect of all lines

Speaker: NA
Text: of scientific research, despite the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: we are always hearing from honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite about how that country

Text: is keeping scientific developments secret

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as Australia is concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Item 20, section C, shows that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposed to spend £33,000 on

Speaker: NA
Text: research into nuclear energy, the very

Speaker: NA
Text: field in which, according to the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, the United States is most con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with secrecy. The Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: could well send students to the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States. It is suggested by honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite that such students

Speaker: NA
Text: would be denied access to information

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning American research on nuclear

Speaker: NA
Text: energy. I draw the attention of honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite to the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: General Eisenhower, the former Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mander-in-Chief of the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Army during the last war, who is now

Speaker: NA
Text: president of Columbia University in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America. The United

Speaker: NA
Text: States Government offered that university

Speaker: NA
Text: a grant of millions of dollars for research

Speaker: NA
Text: in atomic energy. Because of the urging

Speaker: NA
Text: of ite president, Columbia University

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to accept any money from the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States Government for that pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose. General Eisenhower urged that

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe offer be rejected on the ground that if

Speaker: NA
Text: the university accepted money from the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States Government for atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: energy research it would be obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: impose secrecy upon the men engaged at

Speaker: NA
Text: Ur. Beazley.

Speaker: NA
Text: that university in such research.

Speaker: NA
Text: Columbia University has the use of many

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of dollars from private funds

Speaker: NA
Text: and also has an unrivalled laboratory

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in fact, carried out much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: research that resulted in the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of the atomic bomb. So 1 stress that

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic research at the Columbia Uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity, the president of which was

Speaker: NA
Text: Commander-in-Chief of the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Army during the last war, is carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: under conditions of a complete absence

Speaker: NA
Text: of secrecy.

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: Nonsense !

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Text: I repeat that

Speaker: NA
Text: General Eisenhower urged Columbia

Speaker: NA
Text: University to refuse to accept the offer

Speaker: NA
Text: of that money from the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Government because he was determined

Speaker: NA
Text: that there should be no secrecy regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: atomic research conducted at the uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity. I am glad to hear the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: that member for Henty ( Mr Gullett) say

Speaker: NA
Text: " nonsense". I shall be very pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: to present him with a copy of a speech

Speaker: NA
Text: by General Eisenhower in which he

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to accept government money so

Speaker: NA
Text: that there should be no ties imposed on

Speaker: NA
Text: research in the university of which he is

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: Henty) [4.59] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to make several observations on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Estimates as they affect the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Army. I do not propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: offer any general criticism of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment's defence policy, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: as it affects the Army, because, on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of previous occasions I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said exactly what I think of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of defence as it is advanced by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Govemment. Briefly, I have always con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered the Government's defence policy

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate and an evasion of its re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility to defend the country

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately. Its policy is lacking in

Speaker: NA
Text: courage, and is indeed a coAvardly policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: That has been said time and time again

Speaker: NA
Text: and on this occasion I do not intend to

Speaker: NA
Text: attack the basis of this country's military

Speaker: NA
Text: defence which relies on a minute and

Speaker: NA
Text: understaffed permanent army. "We have

Speaker: NA
Text: a very much smaller volunteer army than

Speaker: NA
Text: we had before the last war. I wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: comment, however, on several aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: the militia scheme in which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has put its faith. The great body

Speaker: NA
Text: of the troops who are supposed to defend

Speaker: NA
Text: this country in time of emergency is

Speaker: NA
Text: what we loosely call the militia. We were

Speaker: NA
Text: bold that we were to Have a part-time

Speaker: NA
Text: army of 50,000 men, but at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly two years after the scheme was

Speaker: NA
Text: first introduced, only 13,000 men have

Speaker: NA
Text: been enlisted. I n effect we have to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: an army that is somewhat smaller than

Speaker: NA
Text: the country's police forces, and is of a

Speaker: NA
Text: contemptible strength.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Darwin

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dame Enid Lyons) earlier to-day raised

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of how even that very small

Speaker: NA
Text: force is being managed, and she ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed the opinion that even although its

Speaker: NA
Text: strength is so small, numbers of men bave

Speaker: NA
Text: recently resigned. I think that she cited

Speaker: NA
Text: the figure of 4,000 men who have ceased

Speaker: NA
Text: to engage in part-time training. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army ( Mr Chambers),

Speaker: NA
Text: as he always does when such criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: are levelled, said that there was no truth

Speaker: NA
Text: in her statement and that it was no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: some sort of newspaper gossip. He dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missed it as nonsense. As a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, there is a great deal of truth in

Speaker: NA
Text: statements that the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin advanced. The Minister knows

Speaker: NA
Text: very well that recruiting for the militia

Speaker: NA
Text: forces came to a standstill some months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, and that a large number of men have

Speaker: NA
Text: resigned or have simply ceased to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: parades; and thus have ceased to be effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive. I n some cases their commanding

Speaker: NA
Text: officers have had to ask such men to

Speaker: NA
Text: resign because it is of no benefit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: country to have men on the books when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are performing absolutely no service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n order, to discover how poor recruit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing now is we do not require to look any

Speaker: NA
Text: further than the battalion raised in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: an establishment of about 800 men,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the strength of which is actually, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest, below 200 men. That is a posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which existsright throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. Unit after unit goes into

Speaker: NA
Text: camp with only a handful of men

Speaker: NA
Text: to be trained. Yet the Minister expresses

Speaker: NA
Text: great satisfaction over that state of

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. He says, in effect, that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful that after two years we have

Speaker: NA
Text: 13,000 men ready to do part-time train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The militia scheme is so badly

Speaker: NA
Text: administered at the present time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: military authorities are unable to em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploy properly the men they have. They

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot attract more men and tbey cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: even hold those that they already have.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the reasons for that is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: small amount that those soldiers receive

Speaker: NA
Text: in payment as a result of their willingness

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake voluntary military training,

Speaker: NA
Text: is subject to taxation. A man who volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: teers for service in the militia finds at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of the financial year that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: earned perhaps £50 for his military

Speaker: NA
Text: service. That amount must be shown

Speaker: NA
Text: with his other income for the purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: of tax assessment, which frequently means

Speaker: NA
Text: that his voluntary service in the militia

Speaker: NA
Text: actually costs him money, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount that he earns thereby brings him

Speaker: NA
Text: into a higher taxation field. I raised

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter about two years ago when

Speaker: NA
Text: the scheme was first introduced and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said that he would give some

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to an adjustment of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I daresay that he did so, but the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: was unfavorable. I cannot see the least

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for taxing the amounts paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: the soldiers who have undertaken part-time

Speaker: NA
Text: training, and I ask tbe Minister once

Speaker: NA
Text: more i f he will reconsider this matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: which constitutes a gross injustice. A

Speaker: NA
Text: great many men who undertake part-time

Text: military duties find themselves out of

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket as a result of so doing. Many of

Text: tion, as the Minister knows, or ought to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of men than he is actually credited with.

Speaker: NA
Text: I again ask the Government to give

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to refer now to the manner

Speaker: NA
Text: in which the figures relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: strength of the armed forces have been

Speaker: NA
Text: presented in this chamber. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000 members of the so-called permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: army are really members of the interim

Speaker: NA
Text: army. I t is most misleading for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manent army of record numbers when,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, a great number of the men could

Speaker: NA
Text: do so, and another very large number

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Under present conditions it is very un-

Speaker: NA
Text: likely that it will attain the strength

Speaker: NA
Text: of a battalion for a considerable time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f that statement is not correct, let

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister state specifically how far

Speaker: NA
Text: below strength our permanent army units

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is indulging in great de-

Text: ception in painting such a false picture

Text: of tbe defence forces of this country.

Text: tion to defend their country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I propose now to say a few words

Text: the great Labour movement may have

Speaker: NA

Text: alone. Wars are now fought witb man-

Text: power, plus industrial capacity. Every

Speaker: NA
Text: well-informed person knows to-day that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tjnited States of America is so power-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful industrially that no other nation, nor

Speaker: NA
Text: any combination of nations, could success-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully wage war against it. The United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America would inevitably win

Speaker: NA
Text: any war that might be begun within the

Speaker: NA
Text: next 5, 10 or even 25 years. Russia

Speaker: NA
Text: is so far behind in industrial poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial that it will take at least ten

Speaker: NA
Text: years for that country to reach the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which the United States of America

Speaker: NA
Text: occupies to-day. By that time, the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America will be still

Speaker: NA
Text: as far ahead' as it is now.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition said that

Speaker: NA
Text: his government re-introduced compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: military service, and organized divisions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian Imperial Force to go

Speaker: NA
Text: 'overseas. I t is true that the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party opposed) the sending of so many

Speaker: NA
Text: troops overseas, because it was believed

Speaker: NA
Text: that they were needed at home, a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: which was admitted by some of the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the present Opposition at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time, or very soon afterwards. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example; the bonorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Warringa-h ( Mr Spender)-, when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army, said in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f one Japanese armoured division

Speaker: NA
Text: had landed in Australia it could have

Speaker: NA
Text: overrunthe whole country.

Speaker: Mr BI
Text: AIN -Tha t was said at a secret

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting of members of the Parliament.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Perhaps , but I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not disclosing information given at a

Speaker: NA
Text: secret meeting. I t is public property

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Warringah

Speaker: NA
Text: said that i f one Japanese armoured

Speaker: NA
Text: division had landed in Australia it could

Speaker: NA
Text: have overrun the country. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think that anything is to be gained by

Speaker: NA
Text: raking over old controversies. The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition spoke in a derogatory

Speaker: NA
Text: fashion of my colleague, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Works and Housing ( Mr Lemmon). He

Speaker: NA
Text: accused the Minister of shuffling on a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular issue. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and the Leader of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Country party ( Mr Fadden)

Speaker: NA
Text: deserted their posts during the most

Speaker: NA
Text: critical period in Australia's history.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their parties had amajority in the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives and in the Senate,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they both deserted their posts when

Speaker: NA
Text: the country was in danger. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Works and Housing cannot justly

Speaker: NA
Text: be accused of shuffling on any issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was not a member of the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: when the events to wbicb reference has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made took place. I t does not lie

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Leader of the Opposition or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Australian Country party

Speaker: NA
Text: to make accusations against one of my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues when they themselves have been

Speaker: NA
Text: convicted at the bar of public opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the crime of desertion. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: crime which, ordinarily, a man never gets

Speaker: NA
Text: a> second chance to commit. I f the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition and theLeader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: AustralianCountry party had been mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the armed! forces-whic h they

Speaker: NA
Text: neves were-an d had deserted, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been immediately sbot. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is incomprehensible that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: accuse any one on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee of shuffling over defence issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition also said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Labour Government had in-

Speaker: NA
Text: herited' an organization for the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture of munitions. That istrue, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it can also be said that the government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was led by the present Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, had as its slogan

Speaker: NA
Text: "Business as usual". The right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman's government organized

Speaker: NA
Text: the manufacture of munitions, and was

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for Australia's adherence to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Empire air training scheme; but

Speaker: NA
Text: side by side with that somewhat puny

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement, it evolved the slogan " Busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness as usual" during a critical period

Speaker: NA
Text: in the history of the country. At that

Speaker: NA
Text: that time 250,000 persons, who could have

Speaker: NA
Text: been doing something for the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, were unemployed. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the record of the Opposition parties as

Speaker: NA
Text: a government when the danger to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia was much greater than it is to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present Government is expending

Speaker: NA
Text: more money on defence, and expending

Speaker: NA
Text: it to better advantage, than did any

Speaker: NA
Text: previous government in peace-time. The

Speaker: NA
Text: money is not being expended merely upon

Speaker: NA
Text: enlisting persons iii the armed forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is being expended c a the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: new weapons, and on research, whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: the strength of the armed services is

Speaker: NA
Text: being maintained at a level higher than

Speaker: NA
Text: that of 1938. This Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good record in regard to defence

Speaker: NA
Text: preparations, and I repeat that the threat

Speaker: NA
Text: of war is much less imminent now than i t

Speaker: NA
Text: was at the time during which a previous

Speaker: NA
Text: government did less to prepare for the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Capricornia) [8.0].

Speaker: NA
Text: -Afte r the honorable member for Henty

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Gullett) had trenchantly criticized

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's defence training policy this

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon, the Minister for the Army

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Chambers) accused him of having in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dulged in party political propaganda and

Speaker: NA
Text: of having made a personal attack upon

Speaker: NA
Text: himself. Neither charge can rightly be

Speaker: NA
Text: levelled against the honorable member,

Speaker: NA
Text: because, for the last couple of years, ever

Speaker: NA
Text: since the Government enunciated its de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence policy, we have criticized it, not for

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe sake of indulging in party political

Speaker: NA
Text: propaganda, but because we have a deep

Speaker: NA
Text: concern about what we consider to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequacy of the training programme,

Speaker: NA
Text: livery honorable gentleman on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: who, by virtue of his own military service,

Speaker: NA
Text: is, in some way, qualified to speak, has

Speaker: NA
Text: completely condemned the policy. Surely

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister will realize that the criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: is directed as something far transcending

Speaker: NA
Text: political propaganda, and therefore that

Speaker: NA
Text: it be heeded. But the Minister and his

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet colleagues refuse to listen to the

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism. The Minister buries his bead

Speaker: NA
Text: ostrich-like in the sands of complacency,

Speaker: NA
Text: and refuses to face facts that ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious to any one witb knowledge of

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of defence. I n reply to criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism of Australia's defence policy, we

Speaker: NA
Text: hear, from time to time, from bonorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite, the statement that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, has never been better prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to defend itself than it is at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers are particularly adept at mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that claim. The Minister for De-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence ( Mr Dedman) is very fond of

Speaker: NA
Text: booming it forth, but it will take more

Speaker: NA
Text: than, tbat to convince the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, especially those with knowledge of

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation, that the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policy provides for the adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia. Another justifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for its attitude that is advanced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government is that Australia, in

Speaker: NA
Text: conjunction with Great Britain, is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: a big job in developing the guided

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons testing range. That is essential

Speaker: NA
Text: and the development cannot be decried,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it cannot take the place of a complete

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policy. I t is only a part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole picture, many aspects of which are

Speaker: NA
Text: missing. The Government's attitude is

Speaker: NA
Text: based on the belief that the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of the atomic bomb and guided weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: has, in some way, changed the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: character of warfare and Tendered un-

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary trained soldiers, sailors and

Speaker: NA
Text: airmen.

Speaker: NA
Text: We often hear remarks about "push

Speaker: NA
Text: "button warfare" and other similar

Speaker: NA
Text: fatuities. Throughout history, every

Speaker: NA
Text: time a revolutionary weapon has been

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced, the same opinion has been

Speaker: NA
Text: voiced. I t was voiced when the blunder-

Speaker: NA
Text: bus replaced bows and arrows, when

Speaker: NA
Text: cannons were developed and when air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft and tanks were developed. Now

Speaker: NA
Text: that science has developed the atomic

Speaker: NA
Text: bomb and guided weapons, we hear the

Speaker: NA
Text: same contention. Time has proved

Speaker: NA
Text: suoh an attitude to be fallacious,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it will continue to be fal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lacious. Every one with a knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: cf warfare knows that once ground has

Speaker: NA
Text: been taken highly-trained men are needed

Speaker: NA
Text: to hold it. No nation has been de-

Speaker: NA
Text: feated without being overrun by enemy

Speaker: NA
Text: troops. Therefore, regardless of the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of new weapons, we must

Speaker: NA
Text: have men trained to throw out an invader

Speaker: NA
Text: should one attempt to conquer us. The

Speaker: NA
Text: present system is entirely inadequate,

Speaker: NA
Text: not only to defend Australia properly,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also to enable i t to meet its obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions as a major nation in the efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: preserve world peace. I propose

Speaker: NA
Text: to refer only to the Army and

Speaker: NA
Text: to leave references to the Navy

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Air Force, which I believe are

Speaker: NA
Text: similarly placed, to other honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers, with experience in those arms, who

Speaker: NA
Text: are more competent than I am to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about tbem. I t is not my intention to

Speaker: NA
Text: offer much criticism of the broad defence

Speaker: NA
Text: plan as distinct from tbe defence policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is the policy that I regard as erroneous.

Speaker: NA
Text: The broad plan is that there shall be

Speaker: NA
Text: establislied in Australia a regular army

Speaker: NA
Text: consisting of a small highly trained

Speaker: NA
Text: force, which, in peace-time will carry out

Speaker: NA
Text: all the functions necessarily carried out

Speaker: NA
Text: by a regular army in peace-time, but

Speaker: NA
Text: whicli, iu war-time, will be the nucleus

Speaker: NA
Text: of an army capable of adequately defend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Australia. I n addition, a citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: force is to be established. I t will consist

Speaker: NA
Text: of men who will remain citizens, but

Speaker: NA
Text: will be sufficiently trained to enable them

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently to take their place in the army

Speaker: NA
Text: at short notice to defend Australia. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: must be remembered that, in an emer-

Speaker: NA
Text: gency, the fate o f ' Australia would

Speaker: NA
Text: depend, not on the small regular army,

Speaker: NA
Text: but on the citizen army, of whioh the-

Speaker: NA
Text: regular army would be the nucleus. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: order to determine the success of our

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policy, we must assess the success

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have had in recruiting and train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the citizen army. First, I point out

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are still operating on the volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary system. I have condemned the

Speaker: NA
Text: system before, and I condemn it again.

Speaker: NA
Text: TJnder it, the cream of our youth, those

Speaker: NA
Text: who love Australia and have a sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility, are the ones who answer

Speaker: NA
Text: the call. That means that we are train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing them to take the first blow.

Speaker: NA
Text: M.r. DEDMAN -"Wil l compulsory mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary training be advocated by the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition ( Mr Menzies) in hi=

Speaker: NA
Text: policy speech?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr DAVIDSON" -Th e Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence will know what is in the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: speech when it has been delivered. I

Speaker: NA
Text: need all the time that I have available to

Speaker: NA
Text: me to deal with the Government's defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. That policy has had a fair trial

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last eighteen months or so. Every

Speaker: NA
Text: one with any knowledge must admit tliat

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been found wanting. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for thc Army ( Mr Chambers) said

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day, in reply to a question, that of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 50,000 men whom it was hoped to

Speaker: NA
Text: enlist in the Militia, only 15,000 had been

Speaker: NA
Text: enlisted.

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: I t is a five-year plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: M!r. DAVIDSON -Yes , the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment hopes to develop a militia force of

Speaker: NA
Text: 50.000 men in five years. On that basis,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Army contended that

Speaker: NA
Text: the enlistment of 15,000 in the first year

Speaker: NA
Text: or so was a good effort. I challenge that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot afford to sit back complacently

Speaker: NA
Text: for five years hoping that we shall then

Speaker: NA
Text: have reached the stage at which we might

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to defend ourselves. Every one

Speaker: NA
Text: realizes that a force of 50,000 men is

Speaker: NA
Text: too small for the defence of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must have a reasonable force trained

Speaker: NA
Text: as quickly as possible. We cannot sit

Speaker: NA
Text: back and wait for four or five years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence said that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that there would be no war

Speaker: NA
Text: witbin five years. I hope that he is right,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we must face the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Russian bear may attack at any time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreover, the Government cannot expect

Speaker: NA
Text: the enlistment rate of 15,000 a year to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue. I t is obvious that no progress

Speaker: NA
Text: is being made with enlistments and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the force has reached its maximum under

Speaker: NA
Text: present conditions. My inquiries have

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed that infantry battalions, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have an establishment of 700 or 800 men,

Speaker: NA
Text: have a maximum strength of about

Speaker: NA
Text: 200. I n other words, the battalions are

Speaker: NA
Text: at about 25 per cent. strength.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amazingly, the support units, such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: artillery, are not attracting the enlist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that infantry battalions are attract-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. Incoming troops barely balance the

Speaker: NA
Text: outgoing. Troops cannot be trained on

Speaker: NA
Text: imagination. I t is practically impossible

Speaker: NA
Text: to train a skeleton force. We must have

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable numbers of men to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: training to be carried on, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the higher branches. I n an under-manned

Speaker: NA
Text: unit, elementary training, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: rifle drill, can proceed, but there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: definite line, not much higher than that,

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond wbich instructors cannot go.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of a question that was asked

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning the fact was elicited that

Speaker: NA
Text: about 5,000 men had left the Militia

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces. I have found that that decrease

Speaker: NA
Text: is going on steadily all the time, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the first flush of enthusiasm that existed

Speaker: NA
Text: when the recruiting programme started

Speaker: NA
Text: has gone. Men are beginning to drop out

Speaker: NA
Text: and unit commanders can do nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. Apparently the only source left

Speaker: NA
Text: from wbich to make up the gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: 15,000 men and 50,000 men will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: young men who are now reaching

Speaker: NA
Text: military age. But I fear very much that

Speaker: NA
Text: the majority of those young men are not

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to offer themselves for voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: military service because of the fact that,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the present system is staggering to a

Speaker: NA
Text: stop, the comment made to any one pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posing to join up will be, "Don't be a

Speaker: NA
Text: fool! Why offer? I t is not necessary".

Speaker: NA
Text: Another reason that will operate against

Speaker: NA
Text: further enlistments is, as the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Henty ( Mr Gullett) rightly

Speaker: NA
Text: said earlier to-day, the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government used troops as strike breakers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the recent coal strike. I join with

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Henty in say-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that no other action could have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken that would have had such calamitous

Speaker: NA
Text: effects on our defence policy as the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: those troops had. That action should

Speaker: NA
Text: never have been taken except as a last

Speaker: NA
Text: resort to prevent the country from being

Speaker: NA
Text: thrown into chaos, and I cannot accept

Speaker: NA
Text: any assertion tbat that was tbe position.

Speaker: NA
Text: The serious effects of that action on tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: recruiting programme are obvious to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: bably all honorable members. When a

Speaker: NA
Text: young man informs his mother that he

Speaker: NA
Text: intends to join the Militia she will say,

Speaker: NA
Text: "What for? To be used as a strike

Speaker: NA
Text: breaker?" The Government's action in

Speaker: NA
Text: using soldiers as strike breakers must,

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat, have a serious effect on an

Speaker: NA
Text: already unsuccessful scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n his reply to the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Henty the Minister, in an attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: justify as far as possible the present de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fence policy claimed that there was plenty

Speaker: NA
Text: of equipment available. He had started

Speaker: NA
Text: out to say how splendidly the present

Speaker: NA
Text: position compared with the position before

Speaker: NA
Text: the last war, but I noticed that he stopped

Speaker: NA
Text: at the subject of equipment. I am quite

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to concede that the equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: now available for the training of both

Speaker: NA
Text: the Regular Army and the Militia Forces

Speaker: NA
Text: has never been better. But it is not tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: slightest use having a lot of splendid

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment i f it is only to lie in drill

Speaker: NA
Text: and ordnance stores. I f we have not the

Speaker: NA
Text: men to train in the use of that equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: we might as well not have it. I consider

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore that although it is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulation that we at last have some

Speaker: NA
Text: decent equipment, i t cannot be claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that i t is something for which the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment should receive credit.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Som e of that equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is surplus war material.

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Som e of it is. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen a great deal of valuable equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and i f men were trained in its use

Speaker: NA
Text: a great step forward would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken. I n addition to equipment, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of fine instructors available at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time to train the Militia. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are men wbo served in tbe last war and

Speaker: NA
Text: whose outlook is such that they are pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to offer themselves as instructors

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Citizen Forces, and many of them

Speaker: NA
Text: are indeed at present acting as instructors.

Speaker: NA
Text: They command the great respect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: young men whom they are training. The

Speaker: NA
Text: experience of tbese men sbould be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to the utmost while it is available, but

Speaker: NA
Text: their enthusiasm is waning. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: spirit of frustration growing among them

Speaker: NA
Text: because they are becoming' weary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: round of night parades and week-end

Speaker: NA
Text: bivouacs without sumcient men to train.

Speaker: NA
Text: We sball find that unless we do some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about getting men for those instruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors to train we shall lose their services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the Government's present policy con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues I consider that we shall be lucky

Speaker: NA
Text: if we have even the present 15,000 militia-

Speaker: NA
Text: men at the end of the five-year period.

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot accept the Minister's com-

Speaker: NA
Text: placent assurance that because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that in the first year we got 15,000

Speaker: NA
Text: recruits we sball obtain the required

Speaker: NA
Text: 50,000 by the end of another four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: All the evidence points to the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the momentum that was developed at the

Speaker: NA
Text: start of the scheme has now been lost,

Speaker: NA
Text: and recruiting is actually now working

Speaker: NA
Text: in reverse because so many men are leav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Citizen Forces. I said at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of my remarks that my criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cism does not arise from any desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: make political propaganda. This is far

Speaker: NA
Text: too serious a matter to be used as a basis

Speaker: NA
Text: for political propaganda, because I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that Australia is facing a steadily

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing menace. We were told by the

Speaker: NA
Text: halls Minister for the Army this afternoon

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was no particular menace

Speaker: NA
Text: facing us. He told us that Italy was

Speaker: NA
Text: " out" as a nation and that J apan was

Speaker: NA
Text: completely destroyed as a fighting force.

Speaker: NA
Text: He made various other statements of a

Speaker: NA
Text: like nature which suggested that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no particular threat facing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I need not deal with that matter

Speaker: NA
Text: at great length because tbe Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ( Mr Menzies) has dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: it very successfully and conclusively, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I draw the attention of the committee to

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that a red tide is steadily surging

Speaker: NA
Text: down through China at this very moment

Speaker: NA
Text: and there is no knowing when i t will

Speaker: NA
Text: stop moving. Already Great Britain has

Speaker: NA
Text: been forced to reinforce the defences of

Speaker: NA
Text: Hong Kong because of tnat threat. The

Speaker: NA
Text: position in the Netherlands East Indies

Speaker: NA
Text: is, at the moment, indeterminate, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know what will develop there.

Speaker: NA
Text: The statement that Japan has been com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely destroyed as a military power is

Speaker: NA
Text: a most dangerous one to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: by a man who holds the position of Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for the Army.

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: I t is true never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless.

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: I do not know how

Speaker: NA
Text: any one who knows how Japan emerged

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 years ago from the dark ages and was

Speaker: NA
Text: able to develop itself to a position where

Speaker: NA
Text: it could do what it did in the last war

Speaker: NA
Text: can say that that nation has been com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely destroyed as a fighting force.

Speaker: NA
Text: From what I have seen, Japan, i f given

Speaker: NA
Text: a free leg, could become in ten years

Speaker: NA
Text: a serious menace to Australia. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious that it will not he long before

Speaker: NA
Text: a peace treaty with Japan will be signed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The feelers are out already and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously the desire of the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: to finalize such a peace treaty so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: may develop Japan into something in

Speaker: NA
Text: the nature of an ally. There have

Speaker: NA
Text: already been suggestions that Japan may

Speaker: NA
Text: be permitted a certain degree of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: armament. That is the thin end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wedge. Let us remember that greedy eyes

Speaker: NA
Text: in Japan are turned towards New Guinea.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those honorable members who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: to Japan will bear me out in that

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. There are Americans in

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan who consider that one of the out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lets for surplus Japanese population lies

Speaker: NA
Text: in the direction of Australia. I n view

Speaker: NA
Text: of these facts-an d they are facts-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: statement that Japan has heen completely

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyed as a possible threat to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia cannot be sustained.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n addition to the menace facing

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia which I have briefly outlined i

Speaker: NA
Text: must also be remembered that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has certain obligations under the North

Speaker: NA
Text: Atlantic Pact, and lately there have been

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestions that a Pacific pact should

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into being. According to recent

Speaker: NA
Text: statements that have been published

Speaker: NA
Text: appears as i f the United .States,

Speaker: NA
Text: previously was not very favorable to

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion for a Pacific pact, is now

Speaker: NA
Text: ing its thoughts to the development

Speaker: NA
Text: such a pact somewhat along tbe lines of

Speaker: NA
Text: the North Atlantic Pact. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to play a major part in such

Speaker: NA
Text: a pact. Having regard to Australia's pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent capacity for defence I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: whether we could expect America

Speaker: NA
Text: to place any great reliance upon

Speaker: NA
Text: this country as a partner in the Pacific.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should certainly not be in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to do anything of a major nature in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of taking any great share of the

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations which we might incur under

Speaker: NA
Text: such a pact. Yet the development of such

Speaker: NA
Text: a pact is vastly important. I f we could

Speaker: NA
Text: show that we were moving towards a

Speaker: NA
Text: realization of our obligations, as New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand has done, the likelihood of such

Speaker: NA
Text: a pact coming into existence would be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by placing a plea before the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army to pay some atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to tbe opinions expressed by honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on this side of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee. I assure him that those opinions

Speaker: NA
Text: are not voiced for purely political pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses. They are based on sound know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge. I f the Minister would care to

Speaker: NA
Text: appoint a select committee of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Eepresentatives to investigate charges

Speaker: NA
Text: that the training of the militia forces is

Speaker: NA
Text: not proceeding as it should be doing, and

Speaker: NA
Text: call in service chiefs who would not

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise be in a position to speak their

Speaker: NA
Text: minds, he would discover that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a substantial basis for our charges. I m -

Speaker: NA
Text: provements in the scheme which would

Speaker: NA
Text: result from sucb an inquiry would lead

Speaker: NA
Text: to a development of Australia's defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy so that this country could claim

Speaker: NA
Text: eventually that it was in a position to

Speaker: NA
Text: defend itself. That is not the position

Speaker: NA
Text: at present.

Speaker: Mr SHEEHY
Text: Boothby) [8.25] -I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is necessary to take a thorough overall

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the whole defence position and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ausnot only one small aspect of it because

Speaker: NA
Text: t after all we speak here as the represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives of a member of the British Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth of Nations. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers opposite have displayed recently a

Speaker: NA
Text: be really anti-British attitude on every

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion on which we, on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: i t of the chamber, have mentioned the

Speaker: NA
Text: which British Empire. We must study this

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter in a large sense. The British

Speaker: NA
Text: turnEmpire is founded on a strong fighting

Speaker: NA
Text: of navy and a strong merchant navy. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: would be futile to say that defence of such

Speaker: NA
Text: a scattered Empire as ours could be main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained without tbe existence of a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: British Navy. The Government has been

Speaker: NA
Text: criticized because of its attitude towards

Speaker: NA
Text: defence. An examination of the relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: figures will show that there is no basis

Speaker: NA
Text: for such criticism. Tbe Eoyal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy now has a strength of 10,000 effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive personnel compared with a strength

Speaker: NA
Text: of 5,000 effective personnel in 1939.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Fiv e thousand of them

Speaker: NA
Text: are non-combatants.

Speaker: Mr SHEEHY
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Balaclava ( Mr White) has been

Speaker: NA
Text: at sea all his life, and so I can

Speaker: NA
Text: put a true value on his remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f any one who has never been

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Navy can be said to be always

Speaker: NA
Text: at sea, it is the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Balaclava. The figure of 10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: members in the Eoyal Australian Navy

Speaker: NA
Text: is exactly double the number of men in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Navy when the defence magnates

Speaker: NA
Text: on the opposite side of the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: controlled the government prior to and

Speaker: NA
Text: for the first two years of the last war,

Speaker: NA
Text: when they told us that the Pacific area

Speaker: NA
Text: was safe. Now those gentlemen say that

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government is not applying itself

Speaker: NA
Text: to the defence problem.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: I thought from the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman's remarks that he

Speaker: NA
Text: did not intend to adopt a party political

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude to this matter.

Speaker: Mr SHEEHY
Text: I am not adopting a

Speaker: NA
Text: party political attitude. I am merely

Speaker: NA
Text: stating facts. The point is that as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as we on this side advance concrete facts

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite start to

Speaker: NA
Text: squeal or laugh like hyenas. Let us con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider what has been done by the

Speaker: NA
Text: present Government in respect of naval

Speaker: NA
Text: defence. The Menzies Government spent

Speaker: NA
Text: struction, but since 1947 the present Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has expended £60,000,000 on

Speaker: NA
Text: naval defence. Honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site would have the people believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government has not played its part

Speaker: NA
Text: in taking measures for the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. I n the Anzac Pact we

Speaker: NA
Text: have agreed with our sister dominion,

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand, to take joint measures

Speaker: NA
Text: for our protection and security. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that the fleets of the two dominions

Speaker: NA
Text: are now engaged on joint manceuvres.

Speaker: NA
Text: off the Australian coast, in which they will

Speaker: NA
Text: gain experience in joint operations which

Speaker: NA
Text: would be of inestimable value should our

Speaker: NA
Text: countries again be plunged into war.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is merely another step that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the Labour Government in dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charging its responsibilities for the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia. We have also

Speaker: NA
Text: reached an understanding with our great

Speaker: NA
Text: ally, the Tjnited States of America, with

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the defence of the Pacific area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members opposite have in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dulged in a good deal of criticism regard-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the aircraft carrier H.M.A.S. Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the latest addition to the Eoyai

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Navy. They have said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the vessel is already obsolete. Nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: could be further from the truth. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: well known to most honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that after the laying of the keel of a

Speaker: NA
Text: vessel alterations are' frequently made

Speaker: NA
Text: in design and construction before the

Speaker: NA
Text: vessel is completed. I had an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to inspect a number of large air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft carriers in Great Britain the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction of which had been deferred

Speaker: NA
Text: because of alterations in the original

Speaker: NA
Text: design. That is occurring continually in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Mother Country, which is the home

Speaker: NA
Text: of the British Navy and which has taught

Speaker: NA
Text: the peoples of other nations howto man

Speaker: NA
Text: and use ships to the best advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t i l l becomes honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site to criticize the efforts that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: made by this Government to honour its

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations to safeguard the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth. During World War

Speaker: NA
Text: II . , when our fighting forces returned

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Middle East, they had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: re-trained in order that they would be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to acquit themselves adequately in

Speaker: NA
Text: jungle warfare, for which they had not

Speaker: NA
Text: previously been trained. Similarly, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the building of warships, frequent

Speaker: NA
Text: changes of design are made, either to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the requirements of service in cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain waters or to provide for variations

Speaker: NA
Text: in the design of armaments. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite would have the people

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that because a Labour govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is in oflice in this country i t can

Speaker: NA
Text: not be trusted with the secrets of scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: warfare. I have never before listened

Speaker: NA
Text: to such claptrap as that. The simple fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that Australia is to play an important

Speaker: NA
Text: part in the construction and development

Speaker: NA
Text: of secret war weapons. I had the privi-

Speaker: NA
Text: lege of listening to the British Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister outline his views on the future

Speaker: NA
Text: of secret weapons in the defence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Commonwealth. No suggestion

Speaker: NA
Text: was made by him that Australia was

Speaker: NA
Text: mistrusted in this matter. On the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary, he said that we must all work

Speaker: NA
Text: with those with whom we knew we can

Speaker: NA
Text: work amicably. The truth of that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is borne out by the fact that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia was subsequently selected as the

Speaker: NA
Text: proving ground for long-range weapons

Speaker: NA
Text: which are on the secret list. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite cloud and misconstrue

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts to suit their own purposes. They

Speaker: NA
Text: would have the Government reveal all its

Speaker: NA
Text: defence plans. I f that were done our

Speaker: NA
Text: potential enemies would be jubilant. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe British Commonwealth is to survive

Speaker: NA
Text: every member of i t must develop a virile

Speaker: NA
Text: naval force. The British Navy has

Speaker: NA
Text: always played an important part, not

Speaker: NA
Text: only in the winning of wars, but also

Speaker: NA
Text: in the maintenance of peace. No one can

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the British Navy did not play

Speaker: NA
Text: a very important part in maintaining

Speaker: NA
Text: peace in tbe world in tbe period between

Speaker: NA
Text: the two world wars. I t is useless for

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite to indulge in

Speaker: NA
Text: destructive criticism of the kind that

Speaker: NA
Text: has marked their contribution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on these Estimates. For the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: servation of our scattered Empire, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential that all its component parts

Speaker: NA
Text: shall play their part in developing naval

Speaker: NA
Text: strength to the utmost of tbeir ability.

Speaker: NA
Text: At least the Australian Labour Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment can claim that it has played its part

Speaker: NA
Text: in that direction.

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Text: Moreton) [8.38] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: propose to reply briefly to some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks that were made by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Boothby ( Mr Sheehy).

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody can be satisfied that any branch

Speaker: NA
Text: of our armed services is satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day. Everybody realizes that the future

Speaker: NA
Text: is fraught with great difficulties and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the possession of one aircraft carrier and

Speaker: NA
Text: a limited number of naval craft does not

Speaker: NA
Text: give us any cause for satisfaction. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Boothby is

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied with that state of affairs he bas

Speaker: NA
Text: no cognizance of the problems that beset

Speaker: NA
Text: us. The Government is much too com-

Speaker: NA
Text: placent in this matter. I n the very limited

Speaker: NA
Text: time at my disposal I propose to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: briefly with the failure of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to adopt an adequate and sound

Speaker: NA
Text: defence policy. The mere fact that a

Speaker: NA
Text: guided weapons range has been established

Speaker: NA
Text: at Woomera, in South Australia, does not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfy me that the Government is doing

Speaker: NA
Text: everything possible to take advantage

Speaker: NA
Text: of the latest developments in scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: warfare. The Minister for the Army ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chambers) has said that the permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: forces now number 15,500 personnel. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to a question which I asked on

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject the honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted that more than one-third of that

Speaker: NA
Text: . number are non-combatants. That means

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have only approximately 10,500

Speaker: NA
Text: combatant personnel. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman also admitted that 5,000 men

Speaker: NA
Text: had recently left the forces. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very sad story which does not justify

Speaker: NA
Text: the complacency that has been exhibited

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government in relation to defence

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. On every occasion on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Defence ( Mr Dedman) bas

Speaker: NA
Text: answered questions relating to defence or

Speaker: NA
Text: has dealt with matters relating to defence,

Speaker: NA
Text: he has boasted that Australia now has a

Speaker: NA
Text: larger defence force than it has ever

Speaker: NA
Text: had in its history during a time of peace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such statements can be characterized as

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible and dangerous nonsense.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1938, just prior to the outbreak of

Speaker: NA
Text: World War II . , the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for North Sydney ( Mr Hughes) was

Speaker: NA
Text: requested by the Lyons Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase our militia forces from a total

Speaker: NA
Text: strength of 30,000 to 75,000. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman's request I was

Speaker: NA
Text: given the task of assisting him in Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. As the result of his efforts the

Speaker: NA
Text: militia forces of this country were

Speaker: NA
Text: increased beyond the target strength to

Speaker: NA
Text: a total of 85,000. After three months'

Speaker: NA
Text: training those 85,000 young men became

Speaker: NA
Text: the nucleus of the 2nd Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial Force which played such a

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent part in World War II . I

Speaker: NA
Text: invite honorable members to compare the

Speaker: NA
Text: strength of the militia forces in those days

Speaker: NA
Text: with the pitifully small permanent army

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have to-day. Surely the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Defence cannot be satisfied with his

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts. How can he claim that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly satisfied with the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government's five-year defence

Speaker: NA
Text: programme is being implemented? Dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the eighteen months in which that

Speaker: NA
Text: programme has been in operation he has

Speaker: NA
Text: succeeded in enlisting a permanent army

Speaker: NA
Text: of a total strength of only 15,000 of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: one-third are non-combatants. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on this side of the chamber and

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia generally are dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied with the Government's defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: A great deal of time has been wasted by

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite in trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: convince the people that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: derive a great deal-of satisfaction from

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that, in conjunction with the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Government, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: has established a guided weapons range

Speaker: NA
Text: in South Australia. That project will

Speaker: NA
Text: make little or no contribution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia for some time to

Speaker: NA
Text: -come. I t is merely experimental, and i f

Speaker: NA
Text: it is successful a long time will elapse

Speaker: NA
Text: before practical advantage can be taken of

Speaker: NA
Text: it. What this country wants more tban

Speaker: NA
Text: anything else at the moment is an army

Speaker: NA
Text: of skilled specialists to use the mechanized

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment with which modern wars are

Speaker: NA
Text: fought. Large numbers of trained per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonnel wbo served in World War II . are

Speaker: NA
Text: willing and anxious to help to train young

Speaker: NA
Text: men in the use of modern equipment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should do everything possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure their services by making tbe con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions of service in the armed forces

Speaker: NA
Text: attractive. I have a gr'eat regard for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lieutenant-General Savige, who is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known to every member of tbis Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Lieutenant-General Savige has

Speaker: NA
Text: been most forthright in his condemna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the state of our military forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: He does not bandy words. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the press, this great soldier, who served

Speaker: NA
Text: witb distinction in the two world wars,

Speaker: NA
Text: is unequivocally dissatisfied with our

Speaker: NA
Text: militia forces as they exist to-day. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: reported to bave said recently-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Government's failure to train

Speaker: NA
Text: an adequate number of men to use modern

Speaker: NA
Text: weapons of war was a menace to the safety

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: How can Ministers remain complacent in

Speaker: NA
Text: the face of such a statement by a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinguished Australian soldier?

Speaker: NA
Text: tenant-General Savige has spent a life-

Speaker: NA
Text: time in the service of his country. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was a member of the militia forces prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to World War I. and in the period

Speaker: NA
Text: between the two world wars. He rendered

Speaker: NA
Text: brilliant service to his country in both

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Francis.

Speaker: NA
Text: world wars. The report to which I bave

Speaker: NA
Text: referred continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: Since tlie second world war there had been

Speaker: NA
Text: some big changes i n the science of war. Only

Speaker: NA
Text: by universal training would i t be possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep enough men abreast of these developments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lieutenant-General Savige was commenting

Speaker: NA
Text: on a statement by the Prime Minister ( Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley) that the Government had considered

Speaker: NA
Text: universal training and was of opinion that the

Speaker: NA
Text: present defence policy provided the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: of security within the resources available.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said the present voluntary system of

Speaker: NA
Text: training was most obviously a failure-no t

Speaker: NA
Text: enough men were being trained.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those who were in charge of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: forces early in the last war knew how dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: it was to t r y to properly t r a in men for battle

Speaker: NA
Text: after the enemy was on the march.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the future i t would be more dangerous.

Speaker: NA
Text: There would be less time for men to learn how

Speaker: NA
Text: to use weapons of more intricate and scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: design.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the last war the infantryman had dropped

Speaker: NA
Text: his old role as a foot-slogger, and had become

Speaker: NA
Text: a highly-trained specialist, using a great

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of scientific weapons.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t took a. long time to train these specialists.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia was desperately short of them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Universal military training was the only

Speaker: NA
Text: answer.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the Minister, in the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of Australia, to take note of the

Speaker: NA
Text: observations that have been made from

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time by a number of senior Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian officers who served in World War

Speaker: NA
Text: II . I appeal to tbe bonorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that we have forces that are

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate for the defence of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 17th September, tbe American

Speaker: NA
Text: combined Senate Foreign Relations and

Speaker: NA
Text: Armed Services Committees stated that

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia had more than 5,000,000 men in

Speaker: NA
Text: its armed forces. I n a joint report on

Speaker: NA
Text: President Truman's arms programme, the

Speaker: NA
Text: committees said tbat Soviet ground

Speaker: NA
Text: forces were in a better condition now than

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time since tbe war. Other points

Speaker: NA
Text: in the committees' report were that

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia had increased its military budget

Speaker: NA
Text: of by 19 per cent, since last year, tbat tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: number of Soviet troops in Germany had

Speaker: NA
Text: increased from 70,000 to 100,000, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet had intensified security

Speaker: NA
Text: Lieumeasures along its borders and those of

Speaker: NA
Text: its satellites. The Minister must be

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the Russian advance in Asia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Russia was thwarted in Europe and has

Speaker: NA
Text: now turned to the east. Communist

Speaker: NA
Text: forces are advancing in China, and are

Speaker: NA
Text: present in considerable numbers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Netherlands East Indies and South-East

Speaker: NA
Text: Asia generally. This country cannot re-

Speaker: NA
Text: main complacent while Eussia is expand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing its military forces and bringing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Iron Curtain closer to our coasts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eussia is trying to ensure that nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: shall learn of what is being done behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the Iron Curtain. "We must strengthen

Speaker: NA
Text: our defence forces. We owe a duty to our

Speaker: NA
Text: young men to ensure that they are given

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity to receive military train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. We cannot expect that in the future

Speaker: NA
Text: otber countries will keep the enemy away

Speaker: NA
Text: from us while we are establishing our

Speaker: NA
Text: own defence forces.

Speaker: Mr CHAMBERS
Text: Di d the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman say that we cannot get behind

Text: the Iron Curtain?

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Text: I say tbat i t is dim-

Speaker: NA
Text: cut to learn what is being done there.

Text: I f we cannot get be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hind the Iron Curtain, how does the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: formation that he has given to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee is correct?

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Text: I have confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in the efficiency of the American military

Speaker: NA
Text: organization. We saw i t in operation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We are indebted to i t for

Speaker: NA
Text: part that i t played i n the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country and for the lessons that

Speaker: NA
Text: bave been able to learn from it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that the American combined Foreign done so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations and Armed Services Committees

Speaker: NA
Text: are very alarmed about the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of the maintenance of the future peace

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world. I believe that the report

Speaker: NA
Text: that they made to President Truman was

Text: made with the object of ensuring tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: steps will be taken to maintain the forces

Text: of the Tjnited States of America at tho

Speaker: NA
Text: highest possible degree of efficiency.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the Minister for tho

Speaker: NA
Text: Army, we have a regular army of 19,000

Speaker: NA
Text: men. I regard that force as a nucleus

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which to build. We must increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the size of the militia forces, which

Speaker: NA
Text: in my opinion, be required to shoulder

Speaker: NA
Text: the greatest burden i f war occurs. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: approach this problem properly, we shall

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: will be worthy of Australia. I n 1938

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the size of the militia to

Speaker: NA
Text: 85,000 men, and I believe tbat we could

Speaker: NA
Text: do so again i f the necessary effort were

Speaker: NA
Text: made. Nobody who has the interests of

Text: this country at heart can be satisfied with

Text: tbe present position. I appeal to the

Speaker: NA
Text: General Savige, who has stated that the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of men in Australia who bave been

Speaker: NA
Text: trained in the use of modern weapons is

Speaker: NA
Text: a menace to the safety of this country.

Text: I want the honor-

Text: Ther e has been
