Text: the ample opportunity for honorable gentle-

Text: men opposite to state plainly their inten-

Text: we tions i n connexion with compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the sitting was suspended the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Menzies)

Speaker: NA
Text: made a good speech. The right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman was forced into the position

Speaker: NA
Text: of having to do his utmost to justify the

Text: actions before the war of the Government

Text: of which he was a member and to attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: to explain its failure i n the early years

Speaker: NA
Text: of the war. The right honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man tried to blame the Labour party for

Speaker: NA
Text: the condition of the defence forces of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country at the outbreak of war in 1939.

Speaker: NA
Text: He quoted tbe words that were used by

Speaker: NA
Text: will, some members of the Labour party when

Speaker: NA
Text: they were opposing proposals of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: we vernment that was i n office at that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Neither tbe right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: that nor bis predecessor as Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: we was game enough then to do what he

Speaker: NA
Text: thought should be done. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people will surely be puzzled by the

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt of the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: to blame a party that was in a minority

Speaker: NA
Text: in both houses of the Parliament for the

Speaker: NA
Text: failure of the Government prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: outbreak of war to establish adequate and

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient defence forces in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable gentleman referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to the late John Curtin and his opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to certain proposed defence measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n 1936 I served with Mr Curtin on

Speaker: NA
Text: a committee that drew up the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of the Labour party for presenta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the people at the 1937 general

Speaker: NA
Text: election. What Mr Curtin desired was

Speaker: NA
Text: an efficient air force. I ask honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentlemen opposite how efficient our air

Speaker: NA
Text: force was i n 1939.

Speaker: Mr CONELAN
Text: W e had five Wirra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: A t outbreak of

Speaker: NA
Text: war in 1939 the air defences of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country were practically non-existent. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the night when it was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that Prince of Wales and

Speaker: NA
Text: Repv,lse had been sunk. Tbose ships were

Speaker: NA
Text: lost because we had no aircraft available

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect them from the attacks of

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese aircraft.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable gentleman opposite are

Speaker: NA
Text: now claiming that there are not enough

Speaker: NA
Text: men in the defence forces. On other

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions, as we know, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: said that there are not sufficient men

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in industry and that we are not

Speaker: NA
Text: constructing enough houses and ships.

Speaker: NA
Text: They blame the Government because there

Speaker: NA
Text: are not sufficient men to do the work that'

Speaker: NA
Text: is needed for the development of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I believe in an efficient defence

Speaker: NA
Text: force

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: O f course the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member does not.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman may make statements of thai

Speaker: NA
Text: kind i f he desires to do so. I repeat that

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe in an efficient defence force

Speaker: Mr GULLETT
Text: Tha t is utter humbug.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: I t was humbug

Speaker: NA
Text: for the bonorable meinber for Henty to

Speaker: NA
Text: attack the Minister for the Army ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chambers) in the way in which he did,

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the Leader of the Opposition .to

Speaker: NA
Text: claim that the government of which he

Speaker: NA
Text: was a member was not responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: condition of our defence forces in 1939,-

Speaker: NA
Text: and to attempt to lay the blame for it on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour party, wbich was then in

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. I n the debate on these Esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates honorable gentlemen opposite have

Speaker: NA
Text: been indulging in the tactics in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they have indulged for the last three

Speaker: NA
Text: years. On every occasion wben a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition makes a speech in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber he endeavours to sow in the

Speaker: NA
Text: minds of the people the seeds of distrust

Speaker: NA
Text: and suspicion of the Government. He

Speaker: NA
Text: suggests that the Government will not

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the country by doing what is neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary for our defence and that i t will ruin

Speaker: NA
Text: us. Honorable gentlemen opposite must

Speaker: NA
Text: have a very poor opinion of the intelli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence of the people i f they think that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be misled by statements of that kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why was there a change of minis \ry

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1941? Honorable gentlemen opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: talk of unity, but when the present Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition was Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: party ( Mr Fedden) also wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: occupy the post and the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney ( Mr Hughes)

Speaker: NA
Text: said that he was the man for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The people of Australia were wonder-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing who would be the man who would

Speaker: NA
Text: lead them in the war. Eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: two of the supporters of that Government

Speaker: NA
Text: said, in effect, " I f you are going to make

Speaker: NA
Text: such a poor showing by arguing amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: yourselves, and i f you are going to

Speaker: NA
Text: jeopardize the defence of Australia, we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall turn you out of office ". They did so,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a minority party, the Labour party,

Speaker: NA
Text: formed the Government. That minority

Speaker: NA
Text: party did such a wonderful job that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: returned to office witb a record majority

Speaker: NA
Text: at the 1943 general election. A t that tim«

Speaker: NA
Text: [ remember talking to men in trains and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the streets. They said to me, "We

Speaker: NA
Text: want John Curtin". They gave the

Speaker: NA
Text: party that was led by John Curtin a

Speaker: NA
Text: majority in this House that it had never

Speaker: NA
Text: had before. There were no fights in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ranks of the Labour party. Our fight was

Speaker: NA
Text: with the enemy. The members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies Government did not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: guts to say to the people of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: " We are going to make this an all-in

Speaker: NA
Text: war. Every man in the country must

Speaker: NA
Text: play his part". We did that in spite of

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition of some members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: own party. We were prepared to do what

Speaker: NA
Text: was necessary for the defence of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, and to take risks. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentlemen opposite often talk about tak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing risks, but when the parties to which

Speaker: NA
Text: they belong were i n power they were not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to take the risk of saying to

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody i n Australia, whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: were serving i n the forces or engaged i n

Speaker: NA
Text: industry or business, that they would have

Speaker: NA
Text: to play their part i n the war. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary they adopted the attitude,

Speaker: NA
Text: " Business as usual f or the business man

Speaker: NA
Text: and let the volunteers carry on with the

Speaker: NA
Text: fight". The people of Australia are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that the Labour Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: shown, by deeds and not by words, that i t

Speaker: NA
Text: is prepared to do the job.

Speaker: NA
Text: MT . HARRISON (Wentworth) [9.1] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not propose at tbis juncture

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the administration of the Ministhat

Speaker: NA
Text: ter f or Repatriation ( Mr Barnard)

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the War Pensions Entitlement

Speaker: NA
Text: Appeal Tribunal and the War Pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: Assessment Appeal Tribunal. I pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out on a previous occasion that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister decided to dismiss a tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: for having questioned his administrareports,

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, and that he refused to accept a

Speaker: NA
Text: report f r o m a tribunal, under threat

Speaker: NA
Text: of dismissal, unless i t was prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: alter the document to conform to his

Speaker: NA
Text: own opinions. I mention those matters

Speaker: NA
Text: only to show that the remarks whieh T

Speaker: NA
Text: shall make about war pensions generally

Speaker: NA
Text: are completely consistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's failure to administer the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Repatriation i n a proper manner.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Soldiers' Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, i n my opinion and in the opinion of

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a number of those who have some

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of this matter, should be

Speaker: NA
Text: completely overhauled. The original act

Speaker: NA
Text: has been amended piece-meal since its

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction i n 1920 by the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member f or Nort h Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Hughes). However, the act and the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations promulgated thereunder

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been completely overhauled,

Speaker: NA
Text: and as the result of two world wars, a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable number of anomalies have

Speaker: NA
Text: arisen, the general effect of which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been to penalize ex-service men and

Speaker: NA
Text: women. I t appears to me that ex-service

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women constitute one class

Speaker: NA
Text: which should receive sympathetic con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration fro m the Government. Unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately, they receive scant considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from this Government, and possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: less consideration than otlier sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community receive. That impres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion is held so widely among ex-service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men that the joint organization of

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen's associations has pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared what i t describes as a 33-point

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for submission to the Government.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: A 36-point plan.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: I accept the cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rection, because i t shows that the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: serviceinen's organizations are dissatisfied

Speaker: NA
Text: about three other points i n addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: the 33 that are known to me. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the representatives of ex-servicemen can

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate 36 points of the act which bear

Speaker: NA
Text: . harshly upon them and worsen their posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion compared with that of otlier sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: to tions of the community my contention

Speaker: NA
Text: the act should be completely over-

Speaker: NA
Text: i n hauled must stand unchallenged. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister stated that he informed the

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of the joint organization

Speaker: NA
Text: of ex-servicemen's associations that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government would not increase the rates

Speaker: NA
Text: of repatriation pensions. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister ( Mr Chifley)

Speaker: NA
Text: later confirmed the Minister's statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is more concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: to providing social services benefits than

Speaker: NA
Text: with rendering simple justice to ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: service men and women by increasing the

Speaker: NA
Text: rates of the various categon'ps of war pnn-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. I t seems that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Minisprefers that war pensions should be

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished aad that repatriation bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits and social services generally should

Speaker: NA
Text: be paid from the National Welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund. That impression seems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: .borne out by the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is keeping the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: the war pensions static. While the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government succeeds in doing so, it

Speaker: NA
Text: will be diverting to the National Wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare Fund money that should rightly be

Speaker: NA
Text: .allocated to increasing war pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall cite some examples. The per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of the national income which was

Speaker: NA
Text: expended in 1939 on pensions for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who had fought in the Boer War and

Speaker: NA
Text: World War I . is almost equal to tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of the national income that is

Speaker: NA
Text: now being expended on tbe payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions to those who served in tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Boer War, World War I . and World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II . I t is a misnomer to refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: " war pensions ". A war pension should

Speaker: NA
Text: be regarded as compensation to men who

Speaker: NA
Text: lost limbs or were broken in health as

Speaker: NA
Text: the result of serving their country in wars.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe payment is an obligation that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the people should

Speaker: NA
Text: assume. Of course, the Government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not reeognize that fact aiid, in my opinion,

Speaker: NA
Text: it regards war pensions merely as an obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gation to be met by the payment, in many

Speaker: NA
Text: instances, of the minimum rate. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of World War II . , the increase

Speaker: NA
Text: of war pensions has lagged far behind tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: soaring cost of living, and the steady de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cline of the purchasing power of the war

Speaker: NA
Text: pension is quite evident. However, the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage and tbe age and invalid pension

Speaker: NA
Text: have frequently been adjusted to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the increasing cost of living. I mention

Speaker: NA
Text: tbose points, because later I shall compare

Speaker: NA
Text: the increase of age and invalid pensions in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the basic wage, with the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of war pensions in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the basic wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the anomalies which inflicts the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest degree of hardship is that war

Speaker: NA
Text: pension rates are not suflicient to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: the recipients to maintain a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living. Obviously, if wages

Speaker: NA
Text: and costs rise, but war pensions remain

Speaker: NA
Text: static, the recipients are penalized. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: consider how the purchasing power of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 per cent, war pension has been allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: to fall, notwithstanding the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: national income per capita has increased

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1939 by approximately 86 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Harrison.

Speaker: NA
Text: Age and invalid .pensions have increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by approximately the same percentage,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the 100 per cent, war pension and the

Speaker: NA
Text: special war pension bave been increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by only 30 per cent, in 10 years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 10.0 per cent, war pension in 1939 was

Speaker: NA
Text: £2 2s. a week, and at present i t is £2 15s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a week, an increase of 31 per cent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of the special war pension in 1939

Speaker: NA
Text: was £4 a week and to-day i t is £5 6s. a

Speaker: NA
Text: week, an increase of 32.5 per cent. Honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members will see that my statements

Speaker: NA
Text: about the decline of the purchasing power

Speaker: NA
Text: of wav pensions are borne out by those

Speaker: NA
Text: figures. I shall now examine war pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the basic wage in 1939

Speaker: NA
Text: and in August of this year. The 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, war pension was £2 2s. a week, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the basic wage was £3 19s. a week in 1939.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, tbe 100 per cent war pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion was 53 per cent, of the basic wage at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time. I n August, 1949, the basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: was £6 7s. a week and tbe 100 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: war pension was £2 15s., or only 43

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, of the basic wage. Those of us

Speaker: NA
Text: who watch economic trends know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage will continue to be further in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased. I have no doubt that, before

Speaker: NA
Text: thc general election on tbe 10th December

Speaker: NA
Text: next, the basic wage will be increased to

Speaker: NA
Text: £6 10s. a week. The 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, war pension will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased to 70s. a week if it is to

Speaker: NA
Text: bear tbe same relation to the basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: now as it bore to the basic wage i n 1939.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe case for tbe increase is unanswerable.

Speaker: NA
Text: All civilian pensions and the basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: have been adjusted in accordance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: increased cost of living, but ex-servicemen,

Speaker: NA
Text: who have lost a limb or who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: broken in health through helping to

Speaker: NA
Text: preserve our democratic way of life and

Speaker: NA
Text: our standard of living, are not being

Speaker: NA
Text: treated so sympathetically as civilian

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners are. I do not desire to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that war pensions should rise or

Speaker: NA
Text: fall according to fluctuations in the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of living. I do not suggest that the 100

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, pension rate should be adjusted

Speaker: NA
Text: automatically in accordance with varia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in cost of living figures. Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: us the Minister, calling upon his imagina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, could evolve some other method of

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the problem. At any rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is clearly our duty to honour our obli-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations to the ex-servicemen wbo answered

Speaker: NA
Text: the call to defend their country. They

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be placed in a worse position

Speaker: NA
Text: than other sections of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1939, the full war pension represented

Speaker: NA
Text: 53 per cent, of the basic wage; now it

Speaker: NA
Text: .represents only 43 per cent., and i f an

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment is not made soon the disparity

Speaker: NA
Text: will be still greater. I f the Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: whose coffers are overflowing, can grant

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions to other sections of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity, he can well afford to do justice

Speaker: NA
Text: to ex-servicemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before the war, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers'' Repatriation Act was amended

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide that wives of ex-service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men, who married ' after the 30th

Speaker: NA
Text: June, 1938, should be excluded from bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits under the act. The Minister, no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt, will remind me that the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was made while a government which

Speaker: NA
Text: I supported was in power. That is so,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the amendment has led to some

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies, and I have here particulars of

Speaker: NA
Text: a case in point. An ex-serviceman has

Speaker: NA
Text: written to me in these terms-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 w i l l t r y to point out the injustice by

Speaker: NA
Text: stating my own case.

Speaker: NA
Text: I married i n December 1941 and refrained

Speaker: NA
Text: from doing so earlier because I felt, i n justice

Speaker: NA
Text: to any woman I should not add further respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities, either from a health or financial

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view, unti l the doctors told me i t was

Speaker: NA
Text: safe to marry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The writer was suffering from tuber-

Speaker: NA
Text: culosis. The letter continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: For taking the commonsense point of view

Speaker: NA
Text: I am now ineligible for any assistance for my

Speaker: NA
Text: wife.

Speaker: NA
Text: My action thus prevented the spreading of

Speaker: NA
Text: infection, and also saved the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: financial liability for a wife for all those years

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1919 to my marriage i n 1941.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t seems hard that privileges should be

Speaker: NA
Text: granted to those men who, often very un-

Speaker: NA
Text: wisely married quite early i n their T.B. life,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that penalties be imposed on those who,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the wisdom of their doctors, felt their health

Speaker: NA
Text: prevented them from taking on the responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities of a married life earlier than they did.

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned men feel that this section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act sliould be amended by deleting that section,

Speaker: NA
Text: after which date, 30th June, 1938, a man

Speaker: NA
Text: may not receive help for his wife i f he marries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall give this letter to the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, but I do not know whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: has power to do anything about it, The

Speaker: NA
Text: writer was suffering from tuberculosis,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was at an infectious stage. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: a. man of some standing, and his doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: advised him tbat i f he married he would

Speaker: NA
Text: be doing a disservice to the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: He would be likely to infect his wife, and

Speaker: NA
Text: if there were children they might be

Speaker: NA
Text: infected too. His doctor advised him

Speaker: NA
Text: not to marry until he was given a

Speaker: NA
Text: clean bill of health. He could have

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to accept his doctor's advice. He

Speaker: NA
Text: could have married, and possibly spread

Speaker: NA
Text: the infection, thereby imposing, upon tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Government additional liabilities. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, he refrained from marrying until he

Speaker: NA
Text: was given a clean bill of health. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: now married, and complains that, because

Speaker: NA
Text: he faced his responsibilities as a citizen,

Speaker: NA
Text: he has been penalized. That is an

Speaker: NA
Text: anomaly which ought to be corrected. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should be given discretionary

Speaker: NA
Text: power to, deal with cases of the kind.

Speaker: NA
Text: There cannot be many of them, and no

Speaker: NA
Text: great demand would be made on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury by giving favorable considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to applications of ex-servicemen in

Speaker: NA
Text: such a position. I appreciate the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the aet was amended to cover cases in

Speaker: NA
Text: which women married ex-servicemen for

Speaker: NA
Text: the sole purpose of deriving benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: under the act. I am not quarreling

Speaker: NA
Text: with the general provision. The prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple of the amendment was sound, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the anomalies created by it have become

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent only since the provision has been

Speaker: NA
Text: in operation, and something should be

Speaker: NA
Text: done to correct those anomalies. I make

Speaker: NA
Text: no apology for my general remarks on

Speaker: NA
Text: war pensions. I believe that, compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with other persons in the community,

Speaker: NA
Text: the position of ex-servicemen is worse

Speaker: NA
Text: than i t used to be. The Minister should

Speaker: NA
Text: have pressed for increased rates in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain the same relation between war

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions and the basic wage as obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1939. Because he failed to do so, he

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen down on bis job.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Bass-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation) [9.25] - I congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Wentworth ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harrison) on the temperate way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: he stated his case. Such behaviour is

Speaker: NA
Text: most unusual for him. On this occasion,

Speaker: NA
Text: he tiptoed through the tulips because he

Speaker: NA
Text: knew very well that there would be little

Speaker: NA
Text: justification for his remarks i f he were

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying the responsibility that now rests

Speaker: NA
Text: upon me as Minister. He kept very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully away from one aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation that has been Qf special

Speaker: NA
Text: interest to him in recent years. He

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned it in only a casual way, because

Speaker: NA
Text: he does not wish to have much to say

Speaker: NA
Text: about it. seeing that the election is so

Speaker: NA
Text: close. I refer to the question of the onus

Speaker: NA
Text: of proof in cases that come up for

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing before the War Pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlement Appeal Tribunal. I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mind the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth tbat he was one of those

Speaker: NA
Text: who voted against the proposal to place

Speaker: NA
Text: the onus of proof on the Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, the 'State repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: boards, and on the entitlement tribunal.

Speaker: NA
Text: tLe poserf as the champion of ex-service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men, but when the Labour party, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was then in opposition, wished to place

Speaker: NA
Text: the onus of proof upon the various bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: that deal with applications for war pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, he vofced against the proposal.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: An d we subsequently

Speaker: NA
Text: put that piovision in the act.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Yes , but with what

Speaker: NA
Text: reluctance! The honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bendigo ( Mr Rankin) was one of tbose

Speaker: NA
Text: who voted for the proposal, 'but the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Richmond ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony) voted with the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Wentworth against it. I can read

Speaker: NA
Text: the division list to the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber if he wants me to. The Labour Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has put tbe amending provision

Speaker: NA
Text: into operation with great pleasure, so tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of men, who had been denied

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions when the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Wentworth was Minister for Repatriation,

Speaker: NA
Text: have received tbem since I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. However, I do not propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue that point further, nor to place on

Speaker: NA
Text: record once more the relevant division

Speaker: NA
Text: list. That was done as recently as June

Speaker: NA
Text: last. The honorable meinber for Went-

Speaker: NA
Text: worth put his case very temperately,

Speaker: NA
Text: but some of his statements need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be appropriately replied to.

Speaker: NA
Text: he said that the Australian Soldiers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation Act should be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely overhauled, and that it had

Speaker: NA
Text: not been overhauled since its introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: by the right honorable member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney ( Mr Hughes). The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member knows that that is untrue, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause an almost completely new act was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by my predecessor, Mr Frost,

Speaker: NA
Text: who then represented Franklin.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Practicall y no altera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions were made.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I t was almost a

Speaker: NA
Text: completely new act.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: I t was not.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I f the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member reads it, be will find i t almost

Speaker: NA
Text: a completely new act. Between-1920 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1943, so many anomalies came to light

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was decided to redraft the legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation in order to remove them. All the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments of the principal act were

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidated as recently as 1943. So the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member draws a very long bow

Speaker: NA
Text: when he talks about the need for a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete overhaul of the act. I remind him

Speaker: NA
Text: that the amendments that were made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1943 act were based on the report and

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of a committee com-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed of returned soldiers from all sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of the Parliament. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: was presided over by my honorable friend,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Commerce and Agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: provided for an increase of pensions by

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent. The honorable member went

Speaker: NA
Text: on to talk about a 33-point plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Actually, the plan presented to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Chifley) and

Speaker: NA
Text: myself is a 36-point plan. A good

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of time has been spent on examining

Speaker: NA
Text: the document. I presume that the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman wanted to reduce it to a

Speaker: NA
Text: 33-point plan, because several of the

Speaker: NA
Text: requests made in i t were adopted and

Speaker: NA
Text: passed into law about 12 months ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not propose to take up the

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the committee in enumerat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing them, but half a dozen sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan have already been given legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: force in compliance with a request made

Speaker: NA
Text: by ex-service organizations at least a

Speaker: NA
Text: year ago. So much for the plan. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: still examining other proposals which it

Speaker: NA
Text: Eirst. contains. We hope to be able to reach

Speaker: NA
Text: a decision on some of the other re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quests contained in it as soon as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet, is able to have a look at it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable gentleman went on to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that returned soldiers' pensions had been

Speaker: NA
Text: kept static. For the benefit of honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members, I am getting out a document

Speaker: NA
Text: that gives a complete picture of pensions.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Wil l i t have the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's photograph on it?

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: No , I am not so

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of my photograph as all that.

Speaker: NA
Text: There may be photographs of some re-

Speaker: NA
Text: patriation institutions that we are proud

Speaker: NA
Text: of. Between 1914 and 1916, when soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: were paid 6s. a day, the rate of pension

Speaker: NA
Text: was £2 a week. I t was not until the 6th

Speaker: NA
Text: May, 1943, that the rate was increased to

Speaker: NA
Text: £2 10s. The honorable member criticizes

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government for not having done

Speaker: NA
Text: anything for ex-servicemen. I n effect, he

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that since 1939 we have not done

Speaker: NA
Text: this or ought to have done that. But he

Speaker: NA
Text: ignores the fact that, between 1914 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1943, the pension of returned soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: was not increased. I could quote the

Speaker: NA
Text: ngures to show the increase granted by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government. A good deal has been

Speaker: NA
Text: said about the 100 per cent, pension, that

Speaker: NA
Text: is the pension paid to an ex-serviceman

Speaker: NA
Text: whose disability is assessed at 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, incapacity. Whereas he formerly

Speaker: NA
Text: received a pension of £2, he now re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceives £2 15s. a week, and he can earn

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever pay he is able to earn. I n other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, there is no means test.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Surel y a person in

Speaker: NA
Text: receipt of a 100 per cent, pension could

Speaker: NA
Text: not earn anything.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: T h e 100 por cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: man should not be confused with the

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-serviceman who receives a special

Speaker: NA
Text: pension.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Th e " T . P . I . " ? .

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Yes , and the

Speaker: NA
Text: ' " T.T.I.". The totally and permanently

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacitated and totally temporarily

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacitated men are in an entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: different category from the 100 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: men. The man on the 100 per cent, pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion may earn whatever he is physically or

Speaker: NA
Text: mentally capable of earning without

Speaker: NA
Text: interference to his pension. He is not

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to the means test. The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Wentworth makes the

Speaker: NA
Text: astounding claim that ex-servicemen

Speaker: NA
Text: who work in industry, and have

Speaker: NA
Text: had the benent of increases of the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage, should have their pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions fixed at a higher rate to accord

Speaker: NA
Text: with the increase of the cost of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension has no relation whatever to

Speaker: NA
Text: the basic wage. Ex-service organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions-a t least, the Returned Sailors.

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers and Airmen's Imperial League of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, wbich is the parent organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and which has looked after the

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare of ex-servicemen ever since World

Speaker: NA
Text: War I -hav e always argued against the

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment of pensions on a sliding scale

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with rises or falls of the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Explai n why!

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Th e reason is that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not desire the basic wage and the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension to be related as far as increases

Speaker: NA
Text: or decreases of the cost of living are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. They are prepared to rely on the

Speaker: NA
Text: generosity or lack of generosity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in determining tbe rate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. We have never applied falls

Speaker: NA
Text: or rises of the cost of living to any

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-service pensioner, from the " 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent-er" to the "10 per cent-er". The

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of the pension was decided on

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government, that is the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, because no other govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment gave an increase at all. Non-

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour governments applied the means

Speaker: NA
Text: test to war widows. Until 1943, a widow

Speaker: NA
Text: who had a little property and let a couple

Speaker: NA
Text: of rooms to supplement her pension by a

Speaker: NA
Text: small amount, received the handsome pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of £1 3s. 6d. a week. The means

Speaker: NA
Text: test was always applied to widows until

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour came to the treasury bench in

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Th e Minister is talk-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing about the widows of soldiers?

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Yes . Ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: widows did not receive a pension at all

Speaker: NA
Text: until we took office. We entirely re-

Speaker: NA
Text: moved the means test from war widows.

Speaker: NA
Text: No means test is applied to tbe 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, pensioner who, without suffering a

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction of his pension, may earn what-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever his physical or mental condition

Speaker: NA
Text: allows him to earn. I n earning that

Speaker: NA
Text: money, he reaps the benefit of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases of the basic wage in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the increase of the cost of living.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Tb e means test is still

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to the parents of deceased soldiers.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I shall come to that

Speaker: NA
Text: in a moment. I t seems fallacious tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension should be increased because

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe basic wage has been increased.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Wh y did the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment not maintain the pension that

Speaker: NA
Text: operated in 1939?

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman should ask himself that ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Why did his Government not.

Speaker: NA
Text: apply it?

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: W e did.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Returne d soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: did not receive an increase of tlieir pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion until we gave it to them.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: The y were better off in

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: A lot of people

Speaker: NA
Text: say, " Take us back to the good old days

Speaker: NA
Text: but I notice that every one has more

Speaker: NA
Text: money in bis pocket to-ilay than he had

Speaker: NA
Text: then.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Th e golden age?

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: W e have got nearer

Speaker: NA
Text: the golden age.

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Th e pension is like a

Speaker: NA
Text: wage; i t is worth only what it will pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: chase.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I t is a pity tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite cannot make

Speaker: NA
Text: up their minds. The right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney ( Mr Hughes)

Speaker: NA
Text: argues along one line and tbe honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wentworth along another

Speaker: NA
Text: line.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: W e are arguing along

Speaker: NA
Text: the same line.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Th e arguments run

Speaker: NA
Text: counter to each other. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wentworth said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension should be regarded as compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Tha t is right.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member agrees. Tbe right bonorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney said tbat tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: pension should increase according to tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: H e did not.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Honorabl e gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: men opposite have never been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: make un their minds to agree on anything.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Ca n the Minister not

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that we use the basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: as an illustration?

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Tbe honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Wentworth describes the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension as compensation for services

Speaker: NA
Text: rendered. He talked about pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: being revised periodically. Pension rates

Speaker: NA
Text: were revised in 1943 and they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: revised at least twice since I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. Increases of pensions during

Speaker: NA
Text: my term of office have meant that an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional amount of £2,000,000 is now

Speaker: NA
Text: circulating among ex-servicemen.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: -Th e increases have been

Speaker: NA
Text: offset by the increase of the cost of living.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Tha t applies to

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody. Surely tbe honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber would not argue that a man who is

Speaker: NA
Text: in receipt of the basic wage and who re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceives a 100 per cent, war pension, should

Speaker: NA
Text: ", have it both ways. As far as special

Speaker: NA
Text: rate pensioners are concerned I agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is some validity in the argument

Speaker: NA
Text: that a man who is in receipt of a pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of £5 6s. a week for himself and

Speaker: NA
Text: £1 4s. a week for his wife, and who has

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay rent, must be having a struggle

Speaker: NA
Text: to live.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Ag e pensioners can earn

Speaker: NA
Text: more.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: I agree with that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of these special rate pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: earn some proportion of the basic wage,

Speaker: NA
Text: but what about the man who gets £3

Speaker: NA
Text: or £4 a week from a superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: fund? That amount is not taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: account because it is not produced by

Speaker: NA
Text: personal exertion. Wliat about the man

Speaker: NA
Text: who is a director of a firm and who has

Speaker: NA
Text: an income that is not produced by per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal exertion? We cannot measure all

Speaker: NA
Text: cases by the same yardstick. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: a concession is given to one person it

Speaker: NA
Text: must be given all down the line.

Speaker: Mr HARRISON
Text: Th e Minister insists

Speaker: NA
Text: upon calling it a pension. I t is really a.

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr 'BARNARD -I t is described in

Speaker: NA
Text: the relevant act as a pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everybody refers to it as a pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion and it has been referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: by that name rigbt down through the

Speaker: NA
Text: years. The honorable member has raised

Speaker: NA
Text: an objection to the term used only be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause he wants to be critical about tbis

Speaker: NA
Text: whole subject. I t is not of much use for

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member to shake his head

Speaker: NA
Text: about it, because that will not alter the

Speaker: NA
Text: position. The honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the special case of a tuber-

Speaker: NA
Text: culous ex-serviceman. I deal with special

Speaker: NA
Text: cases every day. Special cases are

Speaker: NA
Text: always with us. The yardstick used in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of other cases is not suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: for tubercular cases. Only recently the

Speaker: NA
Text: president of the Tubercular Sailors and

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers Association came to me and

Speaker: NA
Text: offered me his congratulations upon what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government had done in the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustment of pension rates for tuber-

Speaker: NA
Text: culous ex-servicemen. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman mentioned a case of a man who

Speaker: NA
Text: married after a certain date, but he anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipated my answer because that was a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter that was decided long before a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour government came into office.

Speaker: NA
Text: When returned servicemen's organiza-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions made a recommendation to this Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment regarding what they considered

Speaker: NA
Text: should be provided in tbe new act of 1943

Speaker: NA
Text: they did not recommend the abolition

Speaker: NA
Text: of that particular section. They recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended that the maximum period in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of soldiers from World War I .

Speaker: NA
Text: should be twenty years and tbat for

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers of World War II . i t should be

Speaker: NA
Text: fifteen years. Tbat recommendation was

Speaker: NA
Text: made by returned soldiers, some of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: are still members of this Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government accepted the recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation and that provision remains in

Speaker: NA
Text: the act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us return for a moment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of totally and permanently in-

Speaker: NA
Text: capacitated ex-servicemen. I t is true

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat a totally and permanently incapaci-

Speaker: NA
Text: tated ex-serviceman with no children

Speaker: NA
Text: must be finding it hard to live on his rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of pension. But that is not all we do for

Speaker: NA
Text: him. We have a very excellent system

Speaker: NA
Text: of education for the children of such

Speaker: NA
Text: people. As soon as a child living at home

Speaker: NA
Text: starts to go to school he is enabled to get

Speaker: NA
Text: tram fares, books and so on until he

Speaker: NA
Text: reaches the age of thirteen years. The rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of educational allowance paid in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of a child was formerly 6s. a week, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been increased by this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to 9s. a week for children between the

Speaker: NA
Text: ages of thirteen and fourteen. We also

Speaker: NA
Text: provide school hooks and sporting

Speaker: NA
Text: requisites for such children.

Speaker: NA
Text: educational allowance in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: children between the ages of four-

Speaker: NA
Text: teen and sixteen is 12s. a week and

Speaker: NA
Text: at sixteen years of age, when the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: ceases to bc payable, educational assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: goes up to 33s. a week i f tbe child is living

Speaker: NA
Text: at home, and 50s. a week i f living away

Speaker: NA
Text: from home. While children are at school

Speaker: NA
Text: we pay for books and provide sporting

Speaker: NA
Text: requisites. We even make an allowance to

Speaker: NA
Text: them i f tbey go to a university. The

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance for a boy learning a trade is

Speaker: NA
Text: 45s. a week in bis first year of appren-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeship, and for a girl it is 40s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the young people are living, away from

Speaker: NA
Text: home the rates are 60s. and 55s.

Speaker: NA
Text: respectively. The pension rate is not

Speaker: NA
Text: a maximum rate but it is a minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: rate, in effect, because of additional bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits available. Tbe Government regards

Speaker: NA
Text: itself as not being ungenerous .to

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen. I agree that some sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of exHservicemen have some d&fficuPty

Speaker: NA
Text: in making ends meet, but I hope that a

Speaker: NA
Text: little later on we shall be able to review

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter and make spme provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for those who find themselves in great

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty because of rising prices. As far

Speaker: NA
Text: as the 36-poi.nt plan of the Returned

Speaker: NA
Text: Servicemen's League is concerned I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that we shall be able to do something more

Speaker: NA
Text: about that matter in the very near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has a record of achieve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ef service to ex-servicemen since

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been in office of which it can be

Speaker: NA
Text: justly proud.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Member s of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would be the only ones who would

Speaker: NA
Text: be proud of it.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman may say tbat, but returned

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen, especially those who have had

Speaker: NA
Text: some responsibility as officials of

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen's organizations, would tell

Speaker: NA
Text: the bonorable member that they approve

Speaker: NA
Text: of what the Government has done for them

Speaker: NA
Text: in removing anomalies in the act and in

Speaker: NA
Text: providing more generous pensions, allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ances, educational benefits and medical

Speaker: NA
Text: attention. I think that in many cases

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen recognize that while they

Speaker: NA
Text: may desire to have more, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: lias not been ungenerous to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week we heard some criticism of

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation hospitals and of the Heidel-

Speaker: NA
Text: berg Military Hospital in particular.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Some general reference was made to

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation hospitals by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Henty ( Mr Gullett). The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman is usually fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: generous in his comments on those

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. I f he desires to level criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: at repatriation hospitals I consider that

Speaker: NA
Text: be should cite specific instances. Almost

Speaker: NA
Text: daily I receive letters of commendation,

Speaker: NA
Text: not only from people high up in the

Speaker: NA
Text: social world who visit repatriation hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pitals, but also from people lower down in

Speaker: NA
Text: the social scale. They commend tbe Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment for the services rendered by the

Speaker: NA
Text: staffs of repatriation hospitals. I con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fess that in a big institution where there

Speaker: NA
Text: are perhaps 1,600 patients and a very

Speaker: NA
Text: big staff, there may be from time to time

Speaker: NA
Text: some matters that require tightening up.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f such cases were brought to the notice

Speaker: NA
Text: of the department i t would have an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to deal with them. I say in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion that as far as repatriation hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pitals are concerned the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: real grounds for pride, and so have the

Speaker: NA
Text: returned soldiers.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Corio-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence and Minister for Post-war Eeoon-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction) [9.56] -Th e group of Esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mates that we are debating covers the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure that is to be incurred by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Goverment for benefits of ex-service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men. I wish to examine what this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is doing, and to compare it with

Speaker: NA
Text: what a previous non-Labour Government

Speaker: NA
Text: did after World War I . I shall also com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pare the measure of prosperity now being

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by ex-servicemen -with tbeir

Speaker: NA
Text: plight four years after World War 1.

Speaker: NA
Text: ended. The total expenditure incurred by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth on all forms of bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits to ex-servicemen of World War II . ,

Speaker: NA
Text: up to the present time, amounts to

Speaker: NA
Text: £88,000,000. That amount is accounted

Speaker: NA
Text: for under various headings. Eirst of all

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth reconstruction train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing scheme provides university-type train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing covering many thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen wbo take professional

Speaker: NA
Text: courses to become doctors, dentists, scien-

Speaker: NA
Text: tists, engineers and so on, and has involved

Speaker: NA
Text: an expenditure, up to the 31st July

Speaker: NA
Text: last, of approximately £11,000,000. That

Speaker: NA
Text: amount includes almost £7,000,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: living allowances and £1,600,000 for

Speaker: NA
Text: tuition fees. [Quorum, formed."] The

Speaker: NA
Text: amount also includes more than £1,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for additional courses and more than

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,000,000 for accommodation and equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. An amount has been provided for

Speaker: NA
Text: technical and vocational-type training

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Commonwealth reconstruction

Speaker: NA
Text: training scheme wbich includes training

Speaker: NA
Text: for all types of trades. A sum total of

Speaker: NA
Text: £24,000,000 has been expended on that

Speaker: NA
Text: activity up to the 31st July last. That sum

Speaker: NA
Text: included £8,000,000 for living allowances,

Speaker: NA
Text: £5,000,000 for tuition fees, and more than

Speaker: NA
Text: £9,000,000 for subsidies to employers. As

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members know bow this scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: is operated, I shall not go into details

Speaker: NA
Text: with regard to it. It is a magnificent

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme for the rehabilitation and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of ex-servicemen, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: far excels any scheme that was put into

Speaker: NA
Text: operation by anti-Labour governments

Speaker: NA
Text: after World War I. In connexion with

Speaker: NA
Text: rural type training an amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately £1,000,000 has already

Speaker: NA
Text: been expended. There are certain liabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties in relation to pensions but as that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has been dealt with by the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Eepatriation ( Mr Barnard), I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall not deal with it now. On the sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementation of apprentices' wages an

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of £3,500,000 has been expended.

Speaker: NA
Text: Grants bave also been made of

Speaker: NA
Text: furniture loans. Small business loans

Speaker: NA
Text: and agricultural loans of less than

Speaker: NA
Text: £250 have accounted for approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately £5,000,000. There are many

Speaker: NA
Text: other items such as medical treat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for war-caused disabilities, free

Speaker: NA
Text: passages to and from the Commonwealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: re-employment allowances and removal

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses, on which heavy expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: has been incurred. A total of

Speaker: NA
Text: £88,000,000 has been expended on the

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation and re-establishment of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen. The Labour Government

Speaker: NA
Text: realized, in drawing up all these plans for

Speaker: NA
Text: re-establishment and rehabilitation

Speaker: NA
Text: of ex-servicemen, tbat they could be

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented only if the community as

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole was prosperous. Consequently,

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole plan was envisaged in an

Speaker: NA
Text: economy enjoying full employment. It

Speaker: NA
Text: can be truthfully said that there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-servicemen in the community who

Speaker: NA
Text: have not already been re-established or

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitated or who are not now in the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of being successfully re-established

Speaker: NA
Text: or rehabilitated. I ask honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members to contrast that position

Speaker: NA
Text: with the position tbat existed four years

Speaker: NA
Text: after the termination of World War I.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have taken the trouble to examine the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates for 1921-22 in order to make

Speaker: NA
Text: such a comparison. [Quorum formed.]

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: A s two Ministers are

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavouring to take up the remainder

Speaker: NA
Text: of tbe time allotted for the consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Estimates now before the Chair,

Speaker: NA
Text: thus preventing Opposition members

Speaker: NA
Text: from participating in the debate, I

Speaker: NA
Text: move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the honorable member for Corio ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dedman) be not further heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question put. The committee divided.

Speaker: NA
Text: ( THE TEMPORARY CHAIBMAN-MB .

Speaker: NA
Text: T. BT. SHEEHY.)

Text: .Anthony, H . L . Menzies, B. G.

Text: Hamilton, L . W. Tellers:

Text: Harrison, Ti. J. Davidson, C. W.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCEwen, J. Falkinder, C. W. .1 .

Speaker: NA
Text: Barnard, H . C. Lawson, George

Speaker: NA
Text: Beazley, K . IC. Liizzai iiii, H P.

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke, T. J'. Lemmon. N.

Speaker: NA
Text: Calwell, A. A. MCLeod, D.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chambers, C. Mulcahy, D.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley, J. B. O'Connor, W. V.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conelan, W. P. Pollard, B. T.

Speaker: NA
Text: Daly, F. M . Kiordan. VV. J. F.

Text: Doduian, J. J. Scully, W. J.

Text: Drakeford, A. S. Thompson, A. V.

Speaker: NA
Text: Edmonds, F. W. Wtard, E. J.

Text: Hiiylen, L . C.

Text: Holloway. IS. .T. Tellers:

Speaker: NA
Text: Question so resolved in the negative.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: W e have only to turn

Speaker: NA
Text: to the newspapers of 1922 to ascertain the

Speaker: NA
Text: desperate plight of ex-servicemen during

Speaker: NA
Text: the regime of a government formed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition parties. The Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Argus of 4th April, 1922, reports the

Speaker: NA
Text: visit of a deputation of mayors repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting 26 municipalities, headed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord Mayor of Melbourne, to the Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: torian Premier to urge the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to co-operate in pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding as much work as possible

Speaker: NA
Text: for unemployed ex-servicemen. The

Speaker: NA
Text: deputation also tried to see the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, Mr Hughes, but was unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so. The Lord Mayor informed the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier that between 1,100 and 1,200

Speaker: NA
Text: returned men with families were on the

Speaker: NA
Text: verge of starvation.

Speaker: Mr FULLER
Text: Whic h Australian Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment was in office then? .

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: The Hughes GovernThese

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was then in office. The Argus

Speaker: NA
Text: reported the Lord Mayor of Melbourne as

Speaker: NA
Text: having said-

Speaker: NA
Text: With the approach of winter their outlook

Speaker: NA
Text: .. 13 is not a happy one. They want work, not

Speaker: NA
Text: charity. . . . It is necesary for the

Speaker: NA
Text: .. 30 Government to take a serious view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed " Digger" and assist the muni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipalities in tiieir efforts to find him work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Melbourne Argus of the 6th April,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1922 contained a statement relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 4YES.

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of the employment bureau estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished by the Returned Sailors, Soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: and Airmen's Imperial League of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I n the Melbourne Age on the 26th

Speaker: NA
Text: May, 1922, the report of the Repatria-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion Department is quoted as having

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that at the 30th April, 1922, there

Speaker: NA
Text: were 1,086 unemployed returned soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: NOES. on its register, an increase of 265 on the

Speaker: NA
Text: number awaiting employment at the 31st

Speaker: NA
Text: March. I n the Melbourne Age of the.

Speaker: NA
Text: 13th June, 1922, when the Nationalist

Speaker: NA
Text: Government led by the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney was in office,

Speaker: NA
Text: there appeared an article under the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: minent headline, " The burden of taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. Huge army in government employ."

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to some extracts from tho

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney press. I n the Sydney Morning

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald of the 17th March, 1922, there

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared this statement-

Speaker: NA
Text: There are indications of a revolt among

Speaker: NA
Text: soldier settlers to whom liens have heen issued

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Bepatriation Department. The soldiers

Speaker: NA
Text: at Tooles Creek Settlement have called an

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent meeting to deal with the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . The lien is similar to that served upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the settlors of the Walbundry Soldiers'

Speaker: NA
Text: Settlement . . . A general conference of

Speaker: NA
Text: all soldier settlers in this part of the State is

Speaker: NA
Text: being summoned to ho held i n Wagga on

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday next to consider what action is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the Sydney Morning Herald of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 12th May, 1922, the following passage

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared:-

Speaker: NA
Text: A conference of Mayors was convened by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord Mayor to consider measures for providing

Speaker: NA
Text: employment for returned soldiers. The Lord

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayor said the League and associations in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terested in returned soldiers had agreed to form

Speaker: NA
Text: a confederacy. The idea was that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be only one central organization dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed soldiers.

Speaker: Mr EDMONDS
Text: Wha t period was this?

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: I t was in 1922, four

Speaker: NA
Text: years after the end of World War I .

Speaker: NA
Text: extracts from newspapers that were

Speaker: NA
Text: published during that period indicate the

Speaker: NA
Text: desperate plight of the returned service-

Speaker: NA
Text: men then.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: The y were not Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Tha t is so. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: 15th May, 1922; the following report

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales Government will meet

Speaker: NA
Text: to-morrow to decide the steps to be taken to

Speaker: NA
Text: overcome trade depression and unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a difference of opinion amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers as to the best way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem should be dealt with.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 23rd May, 1922, the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald stated-

Speaker: NA
Text: The number of unemployed in the State of

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales is shown by the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Department to be 14,500.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 27th May of that year this extract

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared-

Speaker: NA
Text: A deputation of soldier settlers on dairying

Speaker: NA
Text: lands in the Bellingen Shire waited

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wher e is that?

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: I t is i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Rivers district of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: I rise to order. Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in order in quoting at length

Speaker: NA
Text: extracts from newspaper articles pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished in 1922 ? The honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: is stone-walling.

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Sheehy) -Ther e is no point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order involved.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: O h the 27th May,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1922, this report appeared in the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald-

Speaker: NA
Text: A deputation of soldier settlers on dairying

Speaker: NA
Text: lands in the Bellingen shire waited on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistant Minister for Lands to-day . . . a

Speaker: NA
Text: further deputation from soldier settlers en-

Speaker: NA
Text: gaged in poultry farming at Bankstown and

Speaker: NA
Text: Campbelltown was received by Mr Chaffey.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Campbelltown soldiers asked

Speaker: NA
Text: ation oi their land, stock and plant. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Bankstown settlers asked for a tribunal to

Speaker: NA
Text: inquire into their grievances.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 31st May of that year this state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment appeared-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Thomas Buckland presided at the hall

Speaker: NA
Text: yearly meeting at the Bank of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales yesterday. Two facts too evident to

Speaker: NA
Text: ignore he said were that industries were

Speaker: NA
Text: languishing and unemployment abounded.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 15th June, 1922, i t was reported-

Speaker: NA
Text: Dissatisfaction is expressed by officials of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Eeturned Soldiers League at the poor

Speaker: NA
Text: response to appeals for employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the 27th June, 1922, the following

Speaker: NA
Text: statement appeared in the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald-

Speaker: NA
Text: The serious aspect of the industrial situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in Newcastle has been increased by the closing

Speaker: NA
Text: down of the works of Bylands Bro6. The

Speaker: NA
Text: works have been devoted mainly to the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture of wire netting.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard a number of complaints

Speaker: NA
Text: from honorable gentlemen opposite that

Speaker: NA
Text: soldier settlers cannot get sumcient wire

Speaker: NA
Text: netting to meet their requirements. Tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: reason is that, because of tbe pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: perity of primary producers generally,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is sucb a great demand for wire

Speaker: NA
Text: netting now that supplies are insufficient.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is in marked contrast with

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe situation i n 1922 wben farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: had not suflicient money to buy

Speaker: NA
Text: enough wire netting to keep the wire

Speaker: NA
Text: netting works in production. Tbe present

Speaker: NA
Text: situation is entirely different from that

Speaker: NA
Text: which existed in 1922. I have given

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe committee a description of tbe plight

Speaker: NA
Text: of returned servicemen in 1922. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the federal president of the Returned

Speaker: NA
Text: Servicemen's League visited me in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra not very long ago he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: he had not one criticism to make of what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Post-war Reconstruc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was doing for returned servicemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only matters that he had to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the welfare of returned

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen were matters that were taken

Speaker: NA
Text: up with the Minister for Repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Barnard). I t can be said that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has looked after the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the returned servicemen of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: on this occasion very much better than

Speaker: NA
Text: they were looked after by anti-Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: governments after World War I .

Speaker: Mr HAMILTON
Text: D o not some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reconstruction trainees complain about

Speaker: NA
Text: for a revalutheir living allowances?

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Som e trainees have-

Speaker: NA
Text: complained about their living allowances,,

Speaker: NA
Text: -but the vast majority of them know that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are being very generously treated.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat for tbe information of the-

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Swan ( Mr-

Speaker: NA
Text: Hamilton) that the amount that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: expended upon living allowances for uni-

Speaker: NA
Text: versity trainees is £7,000,000. Approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately £8,000,000' has been expended

Speaker: NA
Text: upon living allowances for trainees under-

Speaker: NA
Text: going technical and vocational training.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is true that some trainees have com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plained of the scale of the allowances,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the vast majority of them are

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that they are being treated very

Speaker: NA
Text: generously by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I propose to make one or two remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: about land settlement. After World

Speaker: NA
Text: War I. land settlement was undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the State governments. It was so

Speaker: NA
Text: badly managed that it cost the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth approximately £30,000,000 to

Speaker: NA
Text: write off debts that were incurred. The

Speaker: NA
Text: main reason for that situation was that

Speaker: NA
Text: land was bought at prices that were far

Speaker: NA
Text: too high. Returned servicemen who were

Speaker: NA
Text: settled on the land after World War I.

Speaker: NA
Text: were left with a millstone of debt hanging

Speaker: NA
Text: round their necks. [Quorum formed?]

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I rise to order. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: there any special reason why the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Hume ( Mr Fuller)

Speaker: NA
Text: should rush from the chamber im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately a quorum is called?

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! Tbere is no point of order

Speaker: NA
Text: involved.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Afte r World War I . ,

Speaker: NA
Text: many returned servicemen spent many

Speaker: NA
Text: years of their lives in trying to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: success of the properties that ha'd been

Speaker: NA
Text: allotted to them under the war service

Speaker: NA
Text: land settlement schemes of that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: They incurred huge debts. Eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: they found tbat it was quite impossible

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a living, and they had to leave

Speaker: NA
Text: their blocks and start life afresh. After

Speaker: NA
Text: a period of years, debts to the value of

Speaker: NA
Text: over £30,000,000 were written off by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. On this occasion we have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken steps to ensure that returned

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen who go on the land will get

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair deal. We bave also taken steps

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure tbat tbe valuations of tbeir

Speaker: NA
Text: properties will be sucb as to enable tbem

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn a reasonable personal income,

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay all their expenses and eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a great success of the blocks on

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have been established.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Whe n will tbey know

Speaker: NA
Text: what they bave to pay?

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Tha t is a matter for

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion between the State governments

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth. The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth bas arrived at an agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: with Western Australia, South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and Tasmania in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: valuations. The same remark applies

Speaker: NA
Text: to Queensland. The New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government has indicated that

Speaker: NA
Text: it does not wish to fix the valua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions for another five years. Victoria

Speaker: NA
Text: is the only State with wliich I have had

Speaker: NA
Text: any difficulty in relation to land valua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall give to the committee some

Speaker: NA
Text: details of the war service land settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment scheme. Up to the 30th June this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, the proposals submitted by State

Speaker: NA
Text: governments related to an area of

Speaker: NA
Text: 9,235,000 acres. The area approved by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealtb as suitable for war

Speaker: NA
Text: service land settlement was over 7,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: acres. Tbe number of properties

Speaker: NA
Text: approved for acquisition was over 1,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: involving an area of almost 7,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: acres. Tbe number of properties

Speaker: NA
Text: acquired by State governments for war

Speaker: NA
Text: service land settlement was S37, cover-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing an area of 6,000,000 acres. The

Speaker: NA
Text: number of properties approved for sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: division was 551, covering 3,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: acres. The number of single farm units

Speaker: NA
Text: approved by the Commonwealth, tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: great majority of which are in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, was 468, covering an area

Speaker: NA
Text: of 3,000,000 acres.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Th e Minister was

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to single farm units.

Speaker: Mr DEDMAN
Text: Tha t is not true.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Wimmera

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Turnbull) does not know what he is

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about. I have always been pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to accept single farm propositions

Speaker: NA
Text: provided they are submitted to me within

Speaker: NA
Text: the terms of the War Service Land Settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Agreements. I f the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman knew anything about tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements he would know that I bave no

Speaker: NA
Text: power to refuse to consider single farm

Speaker: NA
Text: unit propositions provided they are

Speaker: NA
Text: within tbe terms of the agreements. I

Speaker: NA
Text: did object to considering propositions

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat were not put forward within the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the agreements. I refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: have anything to do with propositions bf

Speaker: NA
Text: that kind. None of them has been

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted by me. That is not because

Speaker: NA
Text: of my objection to them, but because they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not come within the terms of tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant legislation. Some single farm

Speaker: NA
Text: propositions have been dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: by tbe Victorian Government outside

Speaker: NA
Text: the War Service Land Settlement

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement altogether. The fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are being dealt with by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian Government does not mean

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f tbat Government bad put

Speaker: NA
Text: them up to me within the terms of its

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement, I should not have accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: them. State governments are bound to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the terms of the agreements

Speaker: NA
Text: in the same way as I am bound to comply

Speaker: NA
Text: with them. The total sum of money

Speaker: NA
Text: that bas been expended upon war service

Speaker: NA
Text: land settlement to date is approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: £16,000,000. Approximately one-half of

Speaker: NA
Text: that sum of money has been expended

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the acquisition and development of

Speaker: NA
Text: estates generally and upon rural train-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for the settlers who will occupy the

Speaker: NA
Text: blocks. The remainder of the money has

Speaker: NA
Text: been expended unon re-establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: loans for returned servicemen who are

Speaker: NA
Text: ou the land. That is' tbe £1,000 loan

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition. That is entirely a Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth scheme and the State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are not called upon to bear any

Speaker: NA
Text: of that expenditure. I express my

Speaker: NA
Text: gratitude to the State governments for

Speaker: NA
Text: making available to me facilities such as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Rural Bank of New Soutb Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Soldier Settlement Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: in Victoria for the purpose of organiz-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in connexion witb the scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: doing the necessary inspections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the properties and generally assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Commonwealth in allocating

Speaker: NA
Text: the money. Administrative expenses

Speaker: NA
Text: of that kind are borne by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth, but I express my thanks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments for having made those

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities available to us. Soldier settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: and in fact all ex-servicemen of World

Speaker: NA
Text: War II . have heen given very generous

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment by this Government and there

Speaker: NA
Text: it not any section of the community which

Speaker: NA
Text: does not recognize that to be so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Sheehy) -Order ! The time allotted

Speaker: NA
Text: for the consideration of the proposed votes

Speaker: NA
Text: for Miscellaneous Services, Refunds of

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue, Advance to the Treasurer, War

Speaker: NA
Text: '1914-18) Services and War (1939-45)

Speaker: NA
Text: Services, has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed votes agreed to.

Text: Progress reported.

Text: Mr Dedman.
