Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT.

Speaker: NA
Text: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY : DISCIPLINARY

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTION.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr DEDMAN) proposed-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Balaclava) [10.32] -1

Speaker: NA
Text: direct attention to a matter affecting a

Speaker: NA
Text: former naval officer in the hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Navy ( Mr Riordan)

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that justice shall be done to

Speaker: NA
Text: him. I did not consider that this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: should be raised when the Estimate*

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Department of the Navy were

Speaker: NA
Text: under consideration, even if I had been

Speaker: NA
Text: given an opportunity to speak on that occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. I propose to relate the experience

Speaker: NA
Text: of a former Lieutenant-Commander in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Navy who was court-

Speaker: NA
Text: martialled on five charges, found not

Speaker: NA
Text: guilty on the two most serious ones and

Speaker: NA
Text: reprimanded on the other three. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of that reprimand he has forfeited

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of his deferred pay amounting

Speaker: NA
Text: to some hundreds of pounds. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: the naval regulations provide for for-

Speaker: NA
Text: feiture in such circumstances, the punish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in this instance does not fit the

Speaker: NA
Text: crime. That is an unwritten law which

Speaker: NA
Text: is older than all the naval regulations

Speaker: NA
Text: and the regulations that have been pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mulgated under the defence Act. I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: cite the details of the case. This man is

Speaker: NA
Text: the son of a retired bank manager

Speaker: NA
Text: and is himself a senior bank officer. Every

Speaker: NA
Text: member of his family, including himself,

Speaker: NA
Text: had an excellent war record. He volun-

Speaker: NA
Text: teered and served in the Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy on the lower deck, was promoted to

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-lieutenant in fourteen months, to

Speaker: NA
Text: lieutenant three months later, and to act-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing lieutenant-commander after a further

Speaker: NA
Text: four years. Whilst serving as an officer

Speaker: NA
Text: he carried out naval secretarial duties

Speaker: NA
Text: ashore and afloat in Arunta, Shropshire

Speaker: NA
Text: and Bataan. He joined Bataan in April,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1946, as secretary to the commanding

Speaker: NA
Text: officer, who was in charge in the Tenth

Speaker: NA
Text: Destroyer Flotilla. His duties were of a

Speaker: NA
Text: secretarial nature and were concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with the flotilla of six destroyers. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: officer in charge of public moneys on

Speaker: NA
Text: Bataan, but he had nothing whatever to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with victualling. I shall describe what

Speaker: NA
Text: happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n December, 1946, Bataan paid an

Speaker: NA
Text: official visit to Shanghai for four days.

Speaker: NA
Text: Upon arrival he drew local currency

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian legation. Prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to sailing twelve days later, he returned

Speaker: NA
Text: the balance of unexpended Chinese

Speaker: NA
Text: currency. At this eleventh-hour visit tb

Speaker: NA
Text: the legation on the day of sailing, he was

Speaker: NA
Text: confronted with three accounts for

Speaker: NA
Text: victualling stores presumed to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: purchased from Chinese providors during

Speaker: NA
Text: the stay of the vessel in Shanghai. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was requested to sign them, because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: short time that would elapse before

Speaker: NA
Text: Bataan sailed. The supply petty officer in

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of victualling claimed that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be possible for him to return

Speaker: NA
Text: on board in order to obtain the signature

Speaker: NA
Text: of the requisite authority. He has written

Speaker: NA
Text: to me as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: These facts are hazy to me now and i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible I signed the three documents in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ship immediately before being asked to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: the documents ashore to the legation office,

Speaker: NA
Text: fact of my visit being known to the supply

Speaker: NA
Text: petty officer. The difference in times of sign-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing would be only half or one hour. The

Speaker: NA
Text: supply - petty officer was a recommended and

Speaker: NA
Text: trusted rating and my banking experience

Speaker: NA
Text: would make me believe the woTd of a senior

Speaker: NA
Text: rating.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eventually the legation copies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: victualling accounts were received in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Navy, and they dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed with the amount of provisions that

Speaker: NA
Text: were actually taken on charge in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ship's account. Earlier, the ship's account

Speaker: NA
Text: was " missing" and when the supply

Speaker: NA
Text: petty officer was asked to make out a

Speaker: NA
Text: duplicate copy, the account which he

Speaker: NA
Text: handed in was the " missing" original.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that the supply petty officer

Speaker: NA
Text: was prosecuted on otber charges at a court

Speaker: NA
Text: of inquiry, and it became evident to tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: former commander whose case I am

Speaker: NA
Text: voicing that a circumstantial case

Speaker: NA
Text: had been woven around bim. The

Speaker: NA
Text: senior rating was later discharged from

Speaker: NA
Text: the service and deprived of his good con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct badges. The officer claims that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was the unfortunate victim of circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances. I do not know the facts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter other than as they have been given

Speaker: NA
Text: to me, but I am informed that the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of the trial of the officer amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately £10,000. I think that this

Speaker: NA
Text: officer, having spent many years of his

Speaker: NA
Text: life in the service, should have received

Speaker: NA
Text: more sympathetic consideration from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Navy. I am not one

Speaker: NA
Text: of those who believe in breaking down

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline, and I agree tbat a man who

Speaker: NA
Text: commits a crime must take his punish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. However, the punishment should

Speaker: NA
Text: always fit the crime. The officer has

Speaker: NA
Text: written as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: After the Sydney Board of Inquiry i n July,

Speaker: NA
Text: my previously approved demobilization was

Speaker: NA
Text: deferred. I was kept inactive i n Sydney until

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of August and then allowed to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceed home to Melbourne. I n mid September

Speaker: NA
Text: I was flown to Japan to rejoin Bataan. One

Speaker: NA
Text: uf the two officers referred to above was

Speaker: NA
Text: trained to Melbourne from Cairns and accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: panied me to Japan. From here Bataan sailed

Speaker: NA
Text: to Shanghai where a second Board of Inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: was held in a British cruiser which had come

Speaker: NA
Text: up from Hong Kong. The Chinese providors

Speaker: NA
Text: were witnesses.

Speaker: NA
Text: From Shanghai, Bataan spent fourteen days

Speaker: NA
Text: in Hong Kong before returning to Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n mid November I was informed I was to be

Speaker: NA
Text: court-martialled and so Bataan returned to

Speaker: NA
Text: Shanghai and Australia arrived from Hong

Speaker: NA
Text: such Kong. I was charged on two alternate charges

Speaker: NA
Text: of defrauding the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and three charges of signing documents when

Speaker: NA
Text: I had no authority to do so. I was found

Speaker: NA
Text: not guilty of the two serious charges and as

Speaker: NA
Text: my signature was on the accounts my solicitor

Speaker: NA
Text: instructed me to admit the other three charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: T h e other three charges were l a i d under

Speaker: NA
Text: the a l l - e m b r a c i ng p r o v i s i o n of " con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct to the p r e j u d i c e o f n a v a l d i s c i p l i n e " ,

Speaker: NA
Text: w h i c h is a k i n d of drag-net section t h a t

Speaker: NA
Text: is employed w h e n charges under otber

Speaker: NA
Text: sections f a i l . I do n o t question the

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness of the t r i a l , but I k n o w t h a t tlie

Speaker: NA
Text: officer i n c u r r e d considerable expense i n

Speaker: NA
Text: d e f e n d i ng h i m s e l f . T h e letter con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues-

Speaker: NA
Text: For several months at the end of 1!)47

Speaker: NA
Text: Bataan was almost entirely engaged i n this

Speaker: NA
Text: case, going or coming from Shanghai. She

Speaker: NA
Text: was sent thence, ostensibly on a courtesy visit,

Speaker: NA
Text: a request being sent to the Australian Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in Nanking on both occasions for the visits

Speaker: NA
Text: to be approved by the Chipese Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The following further expenses were

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred to bring nie to trial:-(1 )

Speaker: NA
Text: An officer travelled by train from Cairns

Speaker: NA
Text: to Melbourne and thence was flown to Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) I was flown to Japan. (3) A shorthand

Speaker: NA
Text: writer aud another officer were flown from

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney to Japan to assist at the court-martial.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) An officer was flown from Hong Kong

Speaker: NA
Text: to Japan to assist the prosecutor at the trial.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) tlie prosecutor (the captain of Bataan)

Speaker: NA
Text: took himself from Southern Japan to Yoko-

Speaker: NA
Text: hama to receive advice in conducting his

Speaker: NA
Text: case. (6) Fuel for consumption iu taking

Speaker: NA
Text: Bataan to Shanghai twice for inquiries. The

Speaker: NA
Text: foregoing expenses amount to almost £10,000

Speaker: NA
Text: yet a request by me to have a retired naval

Speaker: NA
Text: officer flown ironi Sydney to Japan to assist me

Speaker: NA
Text: wns turned down unless I held myself

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for his fare. Arriving in Shanghai

Speaker: NA
Text: 3(1 hours before ray trial I had to go ashore

Speaker: NA
Text: in a eity of almost 7,000,000 people and find

Speaker: NA
Text: a solicitor. There were four British solicitors

Speaker: NA
Text: in the city and I eventually obtained an

Speaker: NA
Text: U.N.B.B.A. man. After my trial he charged

Speaker: NA
Text: me £150. To comply with naval procedure I

Speaker: NA
Text: was offered one of tlie junior officers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bataan.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should not be necessary for me to place

Speaker: NA
Text: any additional facts before tbe Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Navy. As I bave stated, I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not know this man personally, other than

Speaker: NA
Text: through this case. After five

Speaker: NA
Text: service in tbe Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: he attained the rank of acting

Speaker: NA
Text: commander. As an accountant

Speaker: NA
Text: signed certain documents and he realizes

Speaker: NA
Text: that be must accept the

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for the sins of another.

Speaker: NA
Text: documents that had been placed before

Speaker: NA
Text: him without being able to check them.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the result of the findings of the court-

Speaker: NA
Text: martial, he bas forfeited between £500

Speaker: NA
Text: and £600 in deferred pay. Tbat

Speaker: NA
Text: is too harsh. This could not happen in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Army or in the Air Force.

Speaker: NA
Text: deferred pay of a soldier or an airman

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be touched. It is contended,

Speaker: NA
Text: I know, that deferred naval pay is good

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct pay, but I am sure that no mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of this Parliament would agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: a man who suffers a reprimand in any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the armed services should lose pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that have accumulated during many

Speaker: NA
Text: years of service. As I have said, I havo

Speaker: NA
Text: already taken this matter up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. I know that he is merely a

Speaker: NA
Text: cipher. He is the servant of the Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Board. He sends matters such as this to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Naval Board, and the board provides

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe answers. But this is a special case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The serious charges were not proved.

Speaker: NA
Text: am diffident about mentioning the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: at all because I rather lean the other way,

Speaker: NA
Text: and believe that a man must take what is

Speaker: NA
Text: coming to him. I have sat on many

Speaker: NA
Text: ilfr. White.

Speaker: NA
Text: courts-martial i n the A r m y and i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: A i r Force, but I believe that human con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations must be taken into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat that the punishment must fit the

Speaker: NA
Text: crime. That principle is older than any

Speaker: NA
Text: military, air force, or naval law. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remind the Minister that there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrated case i n England i n which a

Speaker: NA
Text: midshipman, Archer Shee, was accused of

Speaker: NA
Text: a dishonest act while attending a naval

Speaker: NA
Text: college. He was expelled f r o m the Navy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Edward Carson, later Lord Carson,

Speaker: NA
Text: took up his case years afterwards. The

Speaker: NA
Text: incident was dramatized i n a recent very

Speaker: NA
Text: fine British film called The Winslow Boy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The film showed how that boy was dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: graced, but, through the persistency of his

Speaker: NA
Text: father and other relatives and with tbe.

Speaker: NA
Text: able advocacy of Sir Edward Carson, he

Speaker: NA
Text: was finally cleared, although he never

Speaker: NA
Text: returned to the Navy. The demand

Speaker: NA
Text: made by Sir Edward Carson i n that case

Speaker: NA
Text: was " Let rigbt be done". I t took a

Speaker: NA
Text: years' hide-bound Admiralty a long time to

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy recognize the claim, but finally right

Speaker: NA
Text: lieutenant- was done. I ask the Vice-President of

Speaker: NA
Text: he the Executive Council ( Mr Scully) to

Speaker: NA
Text: take this matter up w i t h the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: responsi- the Navy, who is absent f r o m tbe chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: He signed at present. I am not pleading f or the

Speaker: NA
Text: man. Probably I do not know him anv

Speaker: NA
Text: better than any other honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: do, but he bas come to me with his case,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I feel that the punishment imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty upon h i m was harsh. The matter sbould

Speaker: NA
Text: be reviewed to ensure tbat right is done.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Question resolved i n the affirmative.

Text: the Priine Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Text: 1. Did he or his department receive a letter

Text: from Mr H . J. Rivers, a married returned

Text: soldier with five children, stating that his

Text: £1,000 launch, which was his sole means of

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihood, had been stolen from Darwin by two

Speaker: NA
Text: rutin, and that the launch had been traced

Speaker: NA
Text: to Soumalaki, Netherlands East Indies?

Text: 2. I n view of the department's reply on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 24th January,- 1949, to representations by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: lias been taken up with the Attorney-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: Department and necessary action in connexion

Text: with the recovery of the vessel and the extradi-

Text: tion from Soumalaki to Darwin of the persons

Text: concerned has been initiated", will he state

Text: whetlier Mr Rivers in his letter to the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister or his department, said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: magistrate at Darwin had refused his applica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for thc extradition of the two men on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ground that a prima facie ease against them

Speaker: NA
Text: would first have to he made out?

Text: 3. Did Mr Rivers further explain to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister that the Crown Law authori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties at 'Darwin had 'notified him that, to get

Text: the necessary evidence for the extradition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the two men, thc permission of the Dutch

Speaker: NA
Text: would be needed for police officers and a

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Law representative to land

Speaker: NA
Text: Soumalaki?

Text: 4. Did the Prime Minister, i n a personally

Speaker: NA
Text: signed letter to Mr Rivers, dated the 3rd

Speaker: NA
Text: June, 1949, say-

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomatic channels was made to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dutch authorities for permission for a

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian A i r Force Catalina

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying police officers and a Crown Law

Speaker: NA
Text: representative, to land at Soumalaki, ancl

Speaker: NA
Text: a reply is now awaited from the authori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties at Batavia, who have been asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: expedite their decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: As soon as permission to land is

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained, the Catalina will proceed to

Speaker: NA
Text: Soumalaki without delay and immedi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately all necessary evidence has been

Text: collected the extradition proceedings will

Speaker: NA
Text: be instituted.

Speaker: NA

Text: ter's request for a Catalina to land at

Speaker: NA
Text: Soumalaki?

Speaker: NA
Text: fi. I f jwrmission has been granted, what is

Speaker: NA
Text: the delay in arranging for the extradition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the two men from the Netherlands, thereby

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting Mr Rivers, as an Australian citizen,

Speaker: NA
Text: to recover his stolen property?

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Text: Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorahle member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:- .

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Several letters have been received by me

Speaker: NA
Text: from Mr Rivers containing the information

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned together with representations con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning his desire to obtain the return of the

Speaker: NA
Text: vessel from Soumalaki, Dutch East Indies.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Mr Bivers did not convey the informations

Speaker: NA
Text: to me concerning the refusal of the magistrate-

Speaker: NA
Text: to issue a warrant but I have learned that such,

Speaker: NA
Text: was the case. The ruling was made (after the-

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Law authorities had proceeded against,

Speaker: NA
Text: the two men concerned on a charge, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect that on or about the ls t May, 1949, they

Speaker: NA
Text: had stolen the vessel), for the reason that the-

Speaker: NA
Text: vessel had originally been delivered to the-

Speaker: NA
Text: accused by Mr Bivers under an agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: dated the 4th August, 1948, i n which the-

Speaker: NA
Text: latter leased his vessel to those men for a

Speaker: NA
Text: period expiring on the 30th April, 1949. The-

Speaker: NA
Text: magistrate ruled that there was insufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence before him to establish larceny and

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned the case sine die. The vessel was

Speaker: NA
Text: not returned to the lessor on the date agreed',

Speaker: NA
Text: upon and i t was later located at Soumalaki in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tanimbar Islands from whence i t was-

Speaker: NA
Text: towed to Ambon. To enable a prima facie-

Speaker: NA
Text: case to hc made out i t was necessary to put

Speaker: NA
Text: before the court evidence of-intent to steal by

Speaker: NA
Text: the accused.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. No, but that, nevertheless, was the

Speaker: NA
Text: position.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5 and G. After the date of my letter of the-

Speaker: NA
Text: 3rd June, 1949, to Mr Rivers, a report of the-

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing before the magistrate was received by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Crown Law authorities, Canberra, from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Law Officer, Darwin, from which i t

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared that the purpose of the proposed visit

Speaker: NA
Text: at of the police was to interrogate the accused

Speaker: NA
Text: with the object of obtaining admissions from

Speaker: NA
Text: them of their guilt. As one of the accused

Speaker: NA
Text: had constantly maintained to the Netherlands

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities that he had bought the vessel from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bivers in August, 1948, i t was considered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Crown Law authorities that no useful

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose would be served by making the visit.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Dutch autliorities have been informed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government no longer desires

Speaker: NA
Text: to send police representatives to Batavia

Speaker: NA
Text: (where i t is understood the accused now are).

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is regretted that owing to international

Speaker: NA
Text: and legal difficulties the proceedings for the

Speaker: NA
Text: extradition of the accused cannot be advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: any further.

Text: market; i f so, with what result?

Text: honorable member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: GUIDED " WEAPO NS TESTING RANGE.

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Text: the M i n i s t e r f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: I m m i g r a t i o n , u p o n notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Has his attention heen drawn to allega-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions by a correspondent in a 'Sydney -weekly

Speaker: NA
Text: 'newspaper that Maltese brought to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: for urgent Commonwealtli projects " have been

Speaker: NA
Text: insulted and pushed around" at the rocket

Speaker: NA
Text: Tange?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. W i l l Ihe investigate these 'allegations .and

Speaker: NA
Text: also 'inquire into -the complaints of these -men,

Speaker: NA
Text: who claim .to be experienced carpenters, that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were rejected by a board on the range and

Speaker: NA
Text: advised to get work in a city f .

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. In 'fairness to Aus'tralia and because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: -splendid record of the Maltese during the war,

Speaker: NA
Text: -will he'take steps to-ensure that-these men aie

Speaker: NA
Text: not subjected to further hardships and .that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a -proper examination of the qualifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of such tradesmen'before they are sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australiaf

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr OALWBLI , - T h e answers t o the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1, 2 and 3. The press statement to which thc

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member refers is based on a mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the conditions under which

Speaker: NA
Text: .Maltese settlers were brought to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The standards of skill -within the trades asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated with .building in Australia have always

Speaker: NA
Text: beon jealously guarded, not only in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of the workers themselves, but also in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the public generally. Since other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries 'use different ^techniques in building

Speaker: NA
Text: and work largely i n different materials, i t

Speaker: NA
Text: follows that a skilled tradesman from another

Speaker: NA
Text: country does not necessarily immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: measure up to Australian standards of skill,

Speaker: NA
Text: iit ui realized, therefore, that i t is -unlikely

Speaker: NA
Text: to be possible to carry out trade teste abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: which will bc acceptable to a l l unions and

Speaker: NA
Text: employers i n Australia. Nevertheless, i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: still necessary 'to guard against -men w i t h no

Speaker: NA
Text: -skill or experience posing as tradesmen in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to be granted passages to this country, and -the

Speaker: NA
Text: Maltese Government, in consultation with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government, instituted a system

Speaker: NA
Text: of trade testing of men who have applied for

Speaker: NA
Text: emigration from Malta as tradesmen. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 'trade tests are conducted by the Maltese trade

Speaker: NA
Text: -training authority and, while they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: .permit absolute deGnition of skill by Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: standards, they do -serve as. a guide to the

Speaker: NA
Text: skill of applicants. AU the Maltese settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: employed at Woomera who were formerly

Speaker: NA
Text: employed us tradesmen i n .Malta were warned

Speaker: NA
Text: ..prior to embarkation for Australia, that irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective of tlieir previous experience, their

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition as tradesmen here would depend

Speaker: NA
Text: upon their ability to establish the requisite

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of skill under Australian conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: After their arrival at Woomera the men were

Speaker: NA
Text: given several months to settle down and were

Speaker: NA
Text: then trade tested by a board -consisting of a

Speaker: NA
Text: senior works supervisor of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Works and Housing, a union representative,

Speaker: NA
Text: and a leading hand carpenter. Only a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of the men so tested were successful

Speaker: NA
Text: in satisfying the board that their skill was up

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australian standards. Those who did not

Speaker: NA
Text: pass thc test .are-employed as unskilled workers

Speaker: NA
Text: on tlie job, and were not advised to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: employment elsewhere. I n view of these cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances, I do not feel that any further

Speaker: NA
Text: investigation is necessary, for the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to employment of the Maltese settlers

Speaker: NA
Text: at Woomera is similar to that in Canberra and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere, and is well known not only to me

Speaker: NA
Text: and my officers but also to the Maltese Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I may say that while the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: of -this situation have been known for some

Speaker: NA
Text: 'time, I have not been complacent concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: them, and as a result of a suggestion made

Speaker: NA
Text: by me, through my representative in Malta i n

Speaker: NA
Text: May of this year, a technical expert from Malta

Speaker: NA
Text: asttt pnesent-on his way to -Australia to survey

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of Australian trade training in each

Speaker: NA
Text: State w i th a view to ensuring that future

Speaker: NA
Text: arrivals from Malta do measure up to OUT

Speaker: NA
Text: -standards of skill.

Speaker: NA
Text: CURRENCY : IMPORTS FROM DOLLAR

Speaker: NA
Text: AREAS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CHIFLEY,-O n the 22nd Septem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber, the honorable member for Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Conelan) asked me questions con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning the position of importers who ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained licences for the importation of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods from dollar areas before devalua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion occurred. I n reply I desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform him that importers would not

Speaker: NA
Text: -be required to pay for the goods at the

Speaker: NA
Text: higher rate i f the relative dollar funds

Speaker: NA
Text: -were purchased in full (spot or forward)

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to the 19th September; otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: payment at the higher rate would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be made. Any importer in doubt on this

Speaker: NA
Text: -question should consult his 'banker.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where holders of import licences issued

Speaker: NA
Text: before the 19th September had not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted purchase of dollars against their

Speaker: NA
Text: licences and now have to purchase them

Speaker: NA
Text: at the new rate of exchange, an adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Australian currency values

Speaker: NA
Text: shown on their licences will be necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: As announced by the Minister for Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and Customs on the 23rd September, this

Speaker: NA
Text: -adjustment will be made.by issuing sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementary licences, where required, to

Speaker: NA
Text: .allow the importation of the same quan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tity of goods as would have been imported

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to devaluation. Importers when

Speaker: NA
Text: applying for supplementary licences

Speaker: NA
Text: -should support their applications with

Speaker: NA
Text: certificates from their bankers indicating

Speaker: NA
Text: that no exchange has been purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: against ths original licence, or, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: -case of licences requiring partial adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the actual amount of exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: which had already been purchased against

Speaker: NA
Text: -each licence.
